	<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Russia</h1>
	
	<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
		<div id="siteSub" class="noprint">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
		<div id="contentSub"></div>
		
		
		
		<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
		<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>
		<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Russia_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Russia (disambiguation)">Russia (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">transcontinental country in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia</div>
<p><span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a class="external text" href="//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Russia&amp;params=60_N_90_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">60°N</span> <span class="longitude">90°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">&#xfeff; / &#xfeff;</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">60°N 90°E</span><span style="display:none">&#xfeff; / <span class="geo">60; 90</span></span></span></a></span></span></span>

</p>

<p><b>Russia</b> (<a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>&#58; <span lang="ru" title="Russian language text">Росси́я</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">tr.</a></small> <i lang="ru-Latn" title="Russian language text">Rossiya</i>, <small>IPA:&#160;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[rɐˈsʲijə]</a></span>), or the <b>Russian Federation</b><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">&#91;12&#93;</a></sup> (Russian&#58; <span lang="ru" title="Russian language text">Росси́йская Федера́ция</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Russian" title="Romanization of Russian">tr.</a></small> <i lang="ru-Latn" title="Russian language text">Rossiyskaya Federatsiya</i>, <small>IPA:&#160;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Russian" title="Help:IPA/Russian">[rɐˈsʲijskəjə fʲɪdʲɪˈratsɨjə]</a></span>), is a <a href="/wiki/List_of_transcontinental_countries" title="List of transcontinental countries">transcontinental</a> <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">country</a> in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Asia" title="North Asia">North Asia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-17">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> At 17,125,200 square kilometres (6,612,100&#160;sq&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">&#91;14&#93;</a></sup> Russia is, by a considerable margin, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">largest country in the world</a> by area, covering more than one-eighth of the Earth's inhabited land area,<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">&#91;15&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">&#91;16&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">&#91;17&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">ninth most populous</a>, with about 146.79&#160;million people as of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, including <a href="/wiki/Crimea" title="Crimea">Crimea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-rbc.ru_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rbc.ru-12">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup> About 77% of the population live in the <a href="/wiki/European_Russia" title="European Russia">western, European part</a> of the country. Russia's capital, <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, is one of the <a href="/wiki/Largest_cities_in_the_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Largest cities in the world">largest cities in the world</a> and the second largest city in Europe; other major <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Russia_by_population" title="List of cities and towns in Russia by population">cities</a> include <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk" title="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a>. Extending across the entirety of <a href="/wiki/North_Asia" title="North Asia">Northern Asia</a> and much of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, Russia spans <a href="/wiki/Time_in_Russia" title="Time in Russia">eleven time zones</a> and incorporates a wide range of <a href="/wiki/Environment_of_Russia" title="Environment of Russia">environments</a> and landforms. From northwest to southeast, Russia <a href="/wiki/Borders_of_Russia" title="Borders of Russia">shares land borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Norway" title="Norway">Norway</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Poland" title="Poland">Poland</a> (both with <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad Oblast</a>), <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mongolia" title="Mongolia">Mongolia</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Korea" title="North Korea">North Korea</a>. It shares <a href="/wiki/Maritime_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Maritime border">maritime borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japan</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">U.S.</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Alaska" title="Alaska">Alaska</a> across the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Strait" title="Bering Strait">Bering Strait</a>. However, Russia recognises two more countries that border it, <a href="/wiki/Abkhazia" title="Abkhazia">Abkhazia</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Ossetia" title="South Ossetia">South Ossetia</a>, both of which are internationally recognized as parts of Georgia.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavs</a> emerged as a recognizable group in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> between the 3rd and 8th centuries AD.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-22">&#91;18&#93;</a></sup> Founded and ruled by a <a href="/wiki/Varangian" class="mw-redirect" title="Varangian">Varangian</a> warrior elite and their descendants, the <a href="/wiki/Medieval" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval">medieval</a> state of <a href="/wiki/Rus_(state)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus (state)">Rus</a> arose in the 9th century. In 988 it adopted <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Christianity</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Curtis_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curtis-23">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> beginning the synthesis of Byzantine and Slavic cultures that defined <a href="/wiki/Russian_culture" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a> for the next millennium.<sup id="cite_ref-Curtis_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curtis-23">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> Rus ultimately disintegrated into a number of smaller states; most of the Rus' lands were overrun by the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus&#39;">Mongol invasion</a> and became tributaries of the nomadic <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> in the 13th century.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">&#91;20&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> gradually reunified the surrounding Russian principalities and achieved independence from the Golden Horde. By the 18th century, the nation had greatly expanded through conquest, annexation, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_explorers" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian explorers">exploration</a> to become the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>, which was the third <a href="/wiki/Largest_empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Largest empire">largest empire</a> in history, stretching from <a href="/wiki/Congress_Poland" title="Congress Poland">Poland</a> on the west to <a href="/wiki/Russian_Alaska" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Alaska">Alaska</a> on the east.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">&#91;21&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">&#91;22&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic</a> became the largest and leading constituent of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Union of Soviet Socialist Republics</a>, the world's first constitutionally <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">&#91;23&#93;</a></sup> The Soviet Union played <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">a decisive role</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> victory in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War&#160;II</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">&#91;24&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">&#91;25&#93;</a></sup> and emerged as a recognized <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">superpower</a> and rival to the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>. The Soviet era saw some of the <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">most significant technological achievements</a> of the 20th century, including the world's <a href="/wiki/Sputnik" class="mw-redirect" title="Sputnik">first human-made satellite</a> and the launching of the <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">first humans in space</a>. By the end of 1990, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> had the world's second largest economy, largest standing military in the world and the largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction.<sup id="cite_ref-GDPinfobox1990_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GDPinfobox1990-30">&#91;26&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">&#91;27&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">&#91;28&#93;</a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a> in 1991, twelve independent republics emerged from the USSR: Russia, <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uzbekistan" title="Uzbekistan">Uzbekistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moldova" title="Moldova">Moldova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tajikistan" title="Tajikistan">Tajikistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkmenistan" title="Turkmenistan">Turkmenistan</a> and the Baltic states regained independence: <a href="/wiki/Estonia" title="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lithuania" title="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian SFSR</a> reconstituted itself as the Russian Federation and is recognized as the continuing legal personality and a successor of the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Government of the Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-uk_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uk-33">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> It is governed as a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential">semi-presidential</a> republic.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Russia's economy</a> ranks as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">twelfth largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">sixth largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">&#91;30&#93;</a></sup> Russia's extensive mineral and energy resources are the largest such reserves in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">&#91;31&#93;</a></sup> making it one of the leading <a href="/wiki/Oil_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil producer">producers of oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas producer">natural gas</a> globally.<sup id="cite_ref-IEA-Oil_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEA-Oil-36">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-cia-gas_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-gas-37">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> The country is one of the five <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_Non-Proliferation_Treaty" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty">recognized</a> <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_states" class="mw-redirect" title="Nuclear weapons states">nuclear weapons states</a> and possesses the <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">largest stockpile of weapons of mass destruction</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-fas_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fas-38">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup> Russia is a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a> as well as a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> and has been characterised as a <a href="/wiki/Potential_superpower" class="mw-redirect" title="Potential superpower">potential superpower</a>. It is a <a href="/wiki/Permanent_members_of_the_United_Nations_Security_Council" title="Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and an active global partner of <a href="/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations" title="Association of Southeast Asian Nations">ASEAN</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">&#91;35&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">&#91;36&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">&#91;37&#93;</a></sup> as well as a member of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation</a> (SCO), the <a href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" class="mw-redirect" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation</a> (APEC), the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE), and the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">World Trade Organization</a> (WTO), as well as being the leading member of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (CIS), the <a href="/wiki/Collective_Security_Treaty_Organization" title="Collective Security Treaty Organization">Collective Security Treaty Organization</a> (CSTO) and one of the five members of the <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Union" title="Eurasian Economic Union">Eurasian Economic Union</a> (EEU), along with <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kyrgyzstan" title="Kyrgyzstan">Kyrgyzstan</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_people" title="Rus&#39; people">Rus' people</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_(name)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus&#39; (name)">Rus' (name)</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Russian (disambiguation)">Russian (disambiguation)</a></div>
<p>The name <i>Russia</i> is derived from <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_(name)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus&#39; (name)">Rus'</a>, a medieval state populated mostly by the <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavs</a>. However, this proper name became more prominent in the later history, and the country typically was called by its inhabitants "Русская Земля" (russkaja zemlja), which can be translated as "Russian Land" or "Land of Rus'". In order to distinguish this state from other states derived from it, it is denoted as <i><a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus&#39;">Kievan Rus'</a></i> by modern historiography. The <a href="/wiki/Rus_(name)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus (name)">name <i>Rus</i></a> itself comes from the early medieval <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_people" title="Rus&#39; people">Rus' people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swedes_(Germanic_tribe)" title="Swedes (Germanic tribe)">Swedish</a> merchants and warriors<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">&#91;38&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">&#91;39&#93;</a></sup> who relocated from across the Baltic Sea and founded a state centered on <a href="/wiki/Novgorod" class="mw-redirect" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> that later became <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus" class="mw-redirect" title="Kievan Rus">Kievan Rus</a>.
</p><p>An old Latin version of the name Rus' was <a href="/wiki/Ruthenia" title="Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a>, mostly applied to the western and southern regions of Rus' that were adjacent to Catholic Europe. The current name of the country, Россия (Rossija), comes from the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Greek" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine Greek">Byzantine Greek</a> designation of the <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_(name)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rus&#39; (name)">Rus'</a>, Ρωσσία <i>Rossía</i>—spelled Ρωσία (<i>Rosía</i> <small>pronounced&#160;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Greek" title="Help:IPA/Greek">[roˈsia]</a></span>) in <a href="/wiki/Modern_Greek" title="Modern Greek">Modern Greek</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">&#91;40&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The standard way to refer to citizens of Russia is "<a href="/wiki/Citizens_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Citizens of Russia">Russians</a>" in English<sup id="cite_ref-merriamwebster_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-merriamwebster-45">&#91;41&#93;</a></sup> and <i>rossiyane</i> (<a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>&#58; <span lang="ru" title="Russian language text">россияне</span>) in Russian. There are two <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a> words which are commonly translated into English as "Russians". One is "русские" (<i>russkiye</i>), which most often means "ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a>". Another is "россияне" (<i>rossiyane</i>), which means "<a href="/wiki/Citizens_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Citizens of Russia">citizens of Russia</a>, regardless of ethnicity". Translations into other languages often do not distinguish these two groups.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Russia" title="History of Russia">History of Russia</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_colonies" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greek colonies">Ancient Greek colonies</a>, <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavs" title="Early Slavs">Early Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkic_expansion" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic expansion">Turkic expansion</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Prehistory_of_Siberia" title="Prehistory of Siberia">Prehistory of Siberia</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Proto-Indo-European" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Indo-European">Proto-Indo-European</a> and <a href="/wiki/Proto-Uralic" class="mw-redirect" title="Proto-Uralic">Proto-Uralic</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Nomadic_pastoralism" title="Nomadic pastoralism">Nomadic pastoralism</a> developed in the <a href="/wiki/Pontic-Caspian_steppe" class="mw-redirect" title="Pontic-Caspian steppe">Pontic-Caspian steppe</a> beginning in the <a href="/wiki/Chalcolithic" title="Chalcolithic">Chalcolithic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Belinskij_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Belinskij-46">&#91;42&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Classical_antiquity" title="Classical antiquity">classical antiquity</a>, the Pontic Steppe was known as <a href="/wiki/Scythia" title="Scythia">Scythia</a>. Beginning in the 8th century BC, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> traders brought their civilization to the trade emporiums in <a href="/wiki/Tanais" title="Tanais">Tanais</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phanagoria" title="Phanagoria">Phanagoria</a>. Ancient Greek explorers, most notably <a href="/wiki/Pytheas#discovery_of_the_baltic" title="Pytheas">Pytheas</a>, even went as far as modern day <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad_Oblast" title="Kaliningrad Oblast">Kaliningrad</a>, on the Baltic Sea. <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> settled on the western part of the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>, where their <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">empire</a> stretched towards the east.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Accuracy_dispute#Disputed_statement" title="Wikipedia:Accuracy dispute"><span title="The material near this tag is possibly inaccurate or nonfactual. (May 2015)">dubious</span></a>&#32;<span class="metadata"> &#8211; <a href="/wiki/Talk:Russia#Dubious" title="Talk:Russia">discuss</a></span></i>&#93;</sup><sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">&#91;43&#93;</a></sup> In the 3rd to 4th centuries AD a semi-legendary Gothic kingdom of <a href="/wiki/Oium" title="Oium">Oium</a> existed in Southern Russia until it was overrun by <a href="/wiki/Huns" title="Huns">Huns</a>. Between the 3rd and 6th centuries AD, the <a href="/wiki/Bosporan_Kingdom" title="Bosporan Kingdom">Bosporan Kingdom</a>, a Hellenistic polity which succeeded the Greek colonies,<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">&#91;44&#93;</a></sup> was also overwhelmed by nomadic invasions led by warlike tribes, such as the Huns and <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Avars" title="Pannonian Avars">Eurasian Avars</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">&#91;45&#93;</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Turkic_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic people">Turkic people</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a>, ruled the lower <a href="/wiki/Volga" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga">Volga</a> basin steppes between the <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Seas</a> until the 10th century.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">&#91;46&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The ancestors of modern <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> are the <a href="/wiki/Slavic_tribes" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic tribes">Slavic tribes</a>, whose original home is thought by some scholars to have been the wooded areas of the <a href="/wiki/Pinsk_Marshes" title="Pinsk Marshes">Pinsk Marshes</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">&#91;47&#93;</a></sup> The East Slavs gradually settled Western Russia in two waves: one moving from <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a> toward present-day <a href="/wiki/Suzdal" title="Suzdal">Suzdal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Murom" title="Murom">Murom</a> and another from <a href="/wiki/Polotsk" title="Polotsk">Polotsk</a> toward <a href="/wiki/Novgorod" class="mw-redirect" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rostov" title="Rostov">Rostov</a>. From the 7th century onwards, the East Slavs constituted the bulk of the population in Western Russia<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">&#91;48&#93;</a></sup> and assimilated the native <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">Finno-Ugric peoples</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Merya" class="mw-redirect" title="Merya">Merya</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Muromians" class="mw-redirect" title="Muromians">Muromians</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Meshchera" class="mw-redirect" title="Meshchera">Meshchera</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Kievan_Rus.27"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kievan_Rus'">Kievan Rus'</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_Khaganate" title="Rus&#39; Khaganate">Rus' Khaganate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus&#39;">Kievan Rus'</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_early_East_Slavic_states" class="mw-redirect" title="List of early East Slavic states">List of early East Slavic states</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kievan_Rus_en.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kievan_Rus_en.jpg/220px-Kievan_Rus_en.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kievan_Rus_en.jpg/330px-Kievan_Rus_en.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Kievan_Rus_en.jpg/440px-Kievan_Rus_en.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1384" data-file-height="1368" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kievan_Rus_en.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kievan Rus' in the 11th century</div></div></div>
<p>The establishment of the first East Slavic states in the 9th century coincided with the arrival of <a href="/wiki/Varangians" title="Varangians">Varangians</a>, the traders, warriors and settlers from the Baltic Sea region. Primarily they were <a href="/wiki/Vikings" title="Vikings">Vikings</a> of <a href="/wiki/Scandinavia" title="Scandinavia">Scandinavian</a> origin, who ventured along the waterways extending from the eastern Baltic <a href="/wiki/From_the_Varangians_to_the_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="From the Varangians to the Greeks">to the Black</a> <a href="/wiki/Volga_trade_route" title="Volga trade route">and Caspian</a> Seas.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">&#91;49&#93;</a></sup> According to the <i><a href="/wiki/Primary_Chronicle" title="Primary Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a></i>, a Varangian from <a href="/wiki/Rus%27_people" title="Rus&#39; people">Rus' people</a>, named <a href="/wiki/Rurik" title="Rurik">Rurik</a>, was elected ruler of <a href="/wiki/Novgorod" class="mw-redirect" title="Novgorod">Novgorod</a> in 862. In 882, his successor <a href="/wiki/Oleg_of_Novgorod" title="Oleg of Novgorod">Oleg</a> ventured south and conquered <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">&#91;50&#93;</a></sup> which had been previously paying tribute to the <a href="/wiki/Khazars" title="Khazars">Khazars</a>. Oleg, Rurik's son <a href="/wiki/Igor_of_Kiev" title="Igor of Kiev">Igor</a> and Igor's son <a href="/wiki/Sviatoslav_I_of_Kiev" title="Sviatoslav I of Kiev">Sviatoslav</a> subsequently subdued all local <a href="/wiki/East_Slavs" title="East Slavs">East Slavic</a> tribes to Kievan rule, destroyed the <a href="/wiki/Khazar_khaganate" class="mw-redirect" title="Khazar khaganate">Khazar khaganate</a> and launched several military expeditions to <a href="/wiki/Paphlagonian_expedition_of_the_Rus%27" title="Paphlagonian expedition of the Rus&#39;">Byzantium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caspian_expeditions_of_the_Rus%27" title="Caspian expeditions of the Rus&#39;">Persia</a>.
</p><p>In the 10th to 11th centuries Kievan Rus' became one of the largest and most prosperous states in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">&#91;51&#93;</a></sup> The reigns of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Vladimir the Great</a> (980–1015) and his son <a href="/wiki/Yaroslav_the_Wise" title="Yaroslav the Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> (1019–1054) constitute the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age" title="Golden Age">Golden Age</a> of Kiev, which saw <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus&#39;">the acceptance of</a> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox Christianity</a> from <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantium</a> and the creation of the first East Slavic written <a href="/wiki/Legal_code" class="mw-redirect" title="Legal code">legal code</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Russkaya_Pravda" title="Russkaya Pravda">Russkaya Pravda</a></i>.
</p><p>In the 11th and 12th centuries, constant incursions by nomadic Turkic tribes, such as the <a href="/wiki/Kipchaks" title="Kipchaks">Kipchaks</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Pechenegs" title="Pechenegs">Pechenegs</a>, caused a massive migration of Slavic populations to the safer, heavily forested regions of the north, particularly to the area known as <a href="/wiki/Zalesye" title="Zalesye">Zalesye</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">&#91;52&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lebedev_baptism.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Lebedev_baptism.jpg/220px-Lebedev_baptism.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Lebedev_baptism.jpg/330px-Lebedev_baptism.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Lebedev_baptism.jpg/440px-Lebedev_baptism.jpg 2x" data-file-width="992" data-file-height="715" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lebedev_baptism.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The <a href="/wiki/Baptism_of_Kievans" class="mw-redirect" title="Baptism of Kievans">Baptism of Kievans</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/Klavdy_Lebedev" title="Klavdy Lebedev">Klavdy Lebedev</a></div></div></div>
<p>The age of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> and decentralization was marked by constant in-fighting between members of the <a href="/wiki/Rurik_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Rurik Dynasty">Rurik Dynasty</a> that ruled Kievan Rus' collectively. Kiev's dominance waned, to the benefit of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal" title="Vladimir-Suzdal">Vladimir-Suzdal</a> in the north-east, <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod Republic</a> in the north-west and <a href="/wiki/Galicia-Volhynia" class="mw-redirect" title="Galicia-Volhynia">Galicia-Volhynia</a> in the south-west.
</p><p>Ultimately Kievan Rus' disintegrated, with the final blow being the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Rus%27" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol invasion of Rus&#39;">Mongol invasion</a> of 1237–40<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">&#91;53&#93;</a></sup> that resulted in the destruction of Kiev<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">&#91;54&#93;</a></sup> and the death of about half the population of Rus'.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">&#91;55&#93;</a></sup> The invading Mongol elite, together with their conquered Turkic subjects (Cumans, Kipchaks, Bulgars), became known as <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>, forming the state of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a>, which pillaged the Russian principalities; the Mongols ruled the <a href="/wiki/Cumania" title="Cumania">Cuman-Kipchak confederation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volga_Bulgaria" title="Volga Bulgaria">Volga Bulgaria</a> (modern-day southern and central expanses of Russia) for over two centuries.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">&#91;56&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Galicia-Volhynia was eventually assimilated by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Poland_(1025%E2%80%931385)" title="Kingdom of Poland (1025–1385)">Kingdom of Poland</a>, while the Mongol-dominated Vladimir-Suzdal and Novgorod Republic, two regions on the periphery of Kiev, established the basis for the modern Russian nation.<sup id="cite_ref-Curtis_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Curtis-23">&#91;19&#93;</a></sup> The Novgorod together with <a href="/wiki/Pskov" title="Pskov">Pskov</a> retained some degree of autonomy during the time of the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_yoke" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol yoke">Mongol yoke</a> and were largely spared the atrocities that affected the rest of the country. Led by Prince <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Nevsky" title="Alexander Nevsky">Alexander Nevsky</a>, Novgorodians repelled the invading Swedes in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Neva" title="Battle of the Neva">Battle of the Neva</a> in 1240, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Crusades" title="Northern Crusades">Germanic crusaders</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Ice" class="mw-redirect" title="Battle of the Ice">Battle of the Ice</a> in 1242, breaking their attempts to colonize the Northern Rus'.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/220px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/330px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg/440px-Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2016" data-file-height="1400" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Lissner_TroiceSergievaLavr.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sergius_of_Radonezh" title="Sergius of Radonezh">Sergius of Radonezh</a> blessing <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Donskoy" title="Dmitry Donskoy">Dmitry Donskoy</a> in <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sergius_Lavra" class="mw-redirect" title="Trinity Sergius Lavra">Trinity Sergius Lavra</a>, before the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kulikovo" title="Battle of Kulikovo">Battle of Kulikovo</a>, depicted in a painting by <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Lissner" title="Ernst Lissner">Ernst Lissner</a></div></div></div>
<p>The most powerful state to eventually arise after the destruction of Kievan Rus' was the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Duchy_of_Moscow" title="Grand Duchy of Moscow">Grand Duchy of Moscow</a> ("Muscovy" in the Western chronicles), initially a part of <a href="/wiki/Vladimir-Suzdal" title="Vladimir-Suzdal">Vladimir-Suzdal</a>. While still under the domain of the <a href="/wiki/Mongol" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol">Mongol</a>-<a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> and with their connivance, Moscow began to assert its influence in the Central Rus' in the early 14th century, gradually becoming the leading force in the process of the Rus' lands' reunification and expansion of Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">&#91;57&#93;</a></sup> Moscow's last rival, the <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod Republic</a>, prospered as the chief <a href="/wiki/Fur_trade" title="Fur trade">fur trade</a> center and the easternmost port of the <a href="/wiki/Hanseatic_League" title="Hanseatic League">Hanseatic League</a>.
</p><p>Times remained difficult, with frequent <a href="/wiki/Mongol-Tatar_raids" class="mw-redirect" title="Mongol-Tatar raids">Mongol-Tatar raids</a>. <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">Agriculture</a> suffered from the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Little_Ice_Age" title="Little Ice Age">Little Ice Age</a>. As in the rest of Europe, <a href="/wiki/Plague_(disease)" title="Plague (disease)">plague</a> was a frequent occurrence between 1350 and 1490.<sup id="cite_ref-Byrne_p.62_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Byrne_p.62-62">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup> However, because of the lower population density and better hygiene—widespread practicing of <a href="/wiki/Banya_(sauna)" title="Banya (sauna)">banya</a>, a wet steam bath—the death rate from plague was not as severe as in Western Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-banya_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-banya-63">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> and population numbers recovered by 1500.<sup id="cite_ref-Byrne_p.62_62-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Byrne_p.62-62">&#91;58&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Led by Prince <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Donskoy" title="Dmitry Donskoy">Dmitry Donskoy</a> of Moscow and helped by the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>, the united army of Russian principalities inflicted a milestone defeat on the Mongol-Tatars in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kulikovo" title="Battle of Kulikovo">Battle of Kulikovo</a> in 1380. Moscow gradually absorbed the surrounding principalities, including formerly strong rivals such as <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Tver" title="Principality of Tver">Tver</a> and <a href="/wiki/Novgorod_Republic" title="Novgorod Republic">Novgorod</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ivan_III" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan III">Ivan&#160;III</a> ("the Great") finally threw off the control of the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a> and consolidated the whole of Central and Northern Rus' under Moscow's dominion. He was also the first to take the title "Grand Duke of all the Russias".<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">&#91;60&#93;</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a> in 1453, Moscow <a href="/wiki/Third_Rome" title="Third Rome">claimed succession to the legacy</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>. Ivan&#160;III married <a href="/wiki/Sophia_Palaiologina" title="Sophia Palaiologina">Sophia Palaiologina</a>, the niece of the last <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_emperor" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine emperor">Byzantine emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Constantine_XI" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine XI">Constantine&#160;XI</a>, and made the Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Double-headed_eagle" title="Double-headed eagle">double-headed eagle</a> his own, and eventually Russia's, coat-of-arms.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tsardom_of_Russia">Tsardom of Russia</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a></div>
<p>In development of the <a href="/wiki/Third_Rome" title="Third Rome">Third Rome</a> ideas, the Grand Duke <a href="/wiki/Ivan_IV" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan IV">Ivan&#160;IV</a> (the "Terrible")<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">&#91;61&#93;</a></sup> was officially crowned first <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia"><i>Tsar</i></a> ("<a href="/wiki/Caesar_(title)" title="Caesar (title)">Caesar</a>") of Russia in 1547. The <i>Tsar</i> <a href="/wiki/Promulgation" title="Promulgation">promulgated</a> a new code of laws (<a href="/wiki/Sudebnik_of_1550" title="Sudebnik of 1550">Sudebnik of 1550</a>), established the first Russian feudal representative body (<a href="/wiki/Zemsky_Sobor" title="Zemsky Sobor">Zemsky Sobor</a>) and introduced local self-management into the rural regions.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">&#91;62&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">&#91;63&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg/170px-Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="318" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg/255px-Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg/340px-Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="2996" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Ioann_4.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tsar <a href="/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible" title="Ivan the Terrible">Ivan the Terrible</a>, portrait by <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Vasnetsov" title="Viktor Vasnetsov">Viktor Vasnetsov</a>, 1897</div></div></div>
<p>During his long reign, Ivan the Terrible nearly doubled the already large Russian territory by annexing the three Tatar khanates (parts of the disintegrated <a href="/wiki/Golden_Horde" title="Golden Horde">Golden Horde</a>): <a href="/wiki/Khanate_of_Kazan" title="Khanate of Kazan">Kazan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Astrakhan_Khanate" title="Astrakhan Khanate">Astrakhan</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Volga_River" title="Volga River">Volga River</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Siberian_Khanate" class="mw-redirect" title="Siberian Khanate">Siberian Khanate</a> in southwestern Siberia. Thus, by the end of the 16th century Russia was transformed into a <a href="/wiki/Multiethnic" class="mw-redirect" title="Multiethnic">multiethnic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religious_denomination" title="Religious denomination">multidenominational</a> and <a href="/wiki/Transcontinental_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Transcontinental state">transcontinental state</a>.
</p><p>However, the Tsardom was weakened by the long and unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Livonian_War" title="Livonian War">Livonian War</a> against the coalition of Poland, Lithuania, and Sweden for access to the Baltic coast and sea trade.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">&#91;64&#93;</a></sup> At the same time, the Tatars of the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, the only remaining successor to the Golden Horde, continued to raid Southern Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">&#91;65&#93;</a></sup> In an effort to restore the Volga khanates, Crimeans and their <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> allies <a href="/wiki/Russo-Crimean_Wars" title="Russo-Crimean Wars">invaded central Russia</a> and were even able to <a href="/wiki/Fire_of_Moscow_(1571)" title="Fire of Moscow (1571)">burn down parts of Moscow</a> in 1571.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">&#91;66&#93;</a></sup> But in the next year the large invading army was thoroughly defeated by Russians in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Molodi" title="Battle of Molodi">Battle of Molodi</a>, forever eliminating the threat of an Ottoman–Crimean expansion into Russia. The <a href="/wiki/Crimean-Nogai_raids_into_East_Slavic_lands" class="mw-redirect" title="Crimean-Nogai raids into East Slavic lands">slave raids of Crimeans</a>, however, did not cease until the late 17th century though the construction of new fortification lines across Southern Russia, such as the <a href="/wiki/Great_Abatis_Line" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Abatis Line">Great Abatis Line</a>, constantly narrowed the area accessible to incursions.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">&#91;67&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Appeal_of_Minin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Appeal_of_Minin.jpg/170px-Appeal_of_Minin.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Appeal_of_Minin.jpg/255px-Appeal_of_Minin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Appeal_of_Minin.jpg/340px-Appeal_of_Minin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1416" data-file-height="1666" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Appeal_of_Minin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kuzma_Minin" title="Kuzma Minin">Kuzma Minin</a> appeals to the people of <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a> to raise a volunteer army against the <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Muscovite_War_(1605%E2%80%9318)" class="mw-redirect" title="Polish–Muscovite War (1605–18)">Polish invaders</a></div></div></div>
<p>The death of Ivan's sons marked the end of the ancient <a href="/wiki/Rurik_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Rurik Dynasty">Rurik Dynasty</a> in 1598, and in combination with the <a href="/wiki/Famine_of_1601%E2%80%9303" class="mw-redirect" title="Famine of 1601–03">famine of 1601–03</a><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">&#91;68&#93;</a></sup> led to civil war, the rule of pretenders, and foreign intervention during the <a href="/wiki/Time_of_Troubles" title="Time of Troubles">Time of Troubles</a> in the early 17th century.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">&#91;69&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian_Commonwealth" title="Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> occupied parts of Russia, including Moscow. In 1612, the Poles were forced to retreat by the Russian volunteer corps, led by two national heroes, merchant <a href="/wiki/Kuzma_Minin" title="Kuzma Minin">Kuzma Minin</a> and Prince <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Pozharsky" title="Dmitry Pozharsky">Dmitry Pozharsky</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Romanov_Dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanov Dynasty">Romanov Dynasty</a> acceded to the throne in 1613 by the decision of Zemsky Sobor, and the country started its gradual recovery from the crisis.
</p><p>Russia continued its territorial growth through the 17th century, which was the age of <a href="/wiki/Cossacks" title="Cossacks">Cossacks</a>. Cossacks were warriors organized into military communities, resembling <a href="/wiki/Pirates" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirates">pirates</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pioneers_of_the_New_World" class="mw-redirect" title="Pioneers of the New World">pioneers of the New World</a>. In 1648, the peasants of Ukraine joined the <a href="/wiki/Zaporozhian_Cossacks" title="Zaporozhian Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a> in rebellion against Poland-Lithuania during the <a href="/wiki/Khmelnytsky_Uprising" title="Khmelnytsky Uprising">Khmelnytsky Uprising</a> in reaction to the social and religious oppression they had been suffering under Polish rule. In 1654, the Ukrainian leader, <a href="/wiki/Bohdan_Khmelnytsky" title="Bohdan Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a>, offered to place Ukraine under the protection of the Russian Tsar, <a href="/wiki/Aleksey_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksey I">Aleksey&#160;I</a>. Aleksey's acceptance of this offer led to another <a href="/wiki/Russo-Polish_War_(1654%E2%80%931667)" title="Russo-Polish War (1654–1667)">Russo-Polish War</a>. Finally, Ukraine was split along the <a href="/wiki/Dnieper_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnieper River">Dnieper River</a>, leaving the western part, <a href="/wiki/Right-bank_Ukraine" title="Right-bank Ukraine">right-bank Ukraine</a>, under Polish rule and the eastern part (<a href="/wiki/Left-bank_Ukraine" title="Left-bank Ukraine">Left-bank Ukraine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>) under Russian rule. Later, in 1670–71, the <a href="/wiki/Don_Cossacks" title="Don Cossacks">Don Cossacks</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Stenka_Razin" title="Stenka Razin">Stenka Razin</a> initiated a major uprising in the <a href="/wiki/Volga_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga Region">Volga Region</a>, but the Tsar's troops were successful in defeating the rebels.
</p><p>In the east, the rapid Russian exploration and colonisation of the huge territories of Siberia was led mostly by Cossacks hunting for valuable furs and ivory. <a href="/wiki/Russian_explorers" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian explorers">Russian explorers</a> pushed eastward primarily along the <a href="/wiki/Siberian_River_Routes" title="Siberian River Routes">Siberian River Routes</a>, and by the mid-17th century there were Russian settlements in Eastern Siberia, on the <a href="/wiki/Chukchi_Peninsula" title="Chukchi Peninsula">Chukchi Peninsula</a>, along the <a href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur River</a>, and on the Pacific coast. In 1648, the <a href="/wiki/Bering_Strait" title="Bering Strait">Bering Strait</a> between Asia and North America was passed for the first time by <a href="/wiki/Fedot_Popov" class="mw-redirect" title="Fedot Popov">Fedot Popov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Semyon_Dezhnyov" class="mw-redirect" title="Semyon Dezhnyov">Semyon Dezhnyov</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Imperial_Russia">Imperial Russia</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_de_Grote.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Peter_de_Grote.jpg/170px-Peter_de_Grote.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="239" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Peter_de_Grote.jpg/255px-Peter_de_Grote.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Peter_de_Grote.jpg/340px-Peter_de_Grote.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1687" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peter_de_Grote.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tsar_of_All_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Tsar of All Russia">Tsar of All Russia</a> in 1682–1721 and the first <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_All_Russia" title="Emperor of All Russia">Emperor of All Russia</a> in 1721–1725</div></div></div>
<p>Under <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a>, Russia was proclaimed an Empire in 1721 and became recognized as a world power. Ruling from 1682 to 1725, Peter defeated Sweden in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Northern_War" title="Great Northern War">Great Northern War</a>, forcing it to cede West <a href="/wiki/Karelia" title="Karelia">Karelia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ingria" title="Ingria">Ingria</a> (two regions lost by Russia in the <a href="/wiki/Time_of_Troubles" title="Time of Troubles">Time of Troubles</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">&#91;70&#93;</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Governorate_of_Estonia" title="Governorate of Estonia">Estland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Livland" class="mw-redirect" title="Livland">Livland</a>, securing Russia's access to the sea and sea trade.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">&#91;71&#93;</a></sup> On the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, Peter founded a new capital called <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, later known as Russia's "window to Europe". <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great%27s_reforms" class="mw-redirect" title="Peter the Great&#39;s reforms">Peter the Great's reforms</a> brought considerable Western European cultural influences to Russia.
</p><p>The reign of Peter&#160;I's daughter <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_of_Russia" title="Elizabeth of Russia">Elizabeth</a> in 1741–62 saw Russia's participation in the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years&#39; War">Seven Years' War</a> (1756–63). During this conflict Russia annexed <a href="/wiki/East_Prussia" title="East Prussia">East Prussia</a> for a while and even took Berlin. However, upon Elizabeth's death, all these conquests were returned to the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Prussia" title="Kingdom of Prussia">Kingdom of Prussia</a> by pro-Prussian <a href="/wiki/Peter_III_of_Russia" title="Peter III of Russia">Peter&#160;III of Russia</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine&#160;II</a> ("the Great"), who ruled in 1762–96, presided over the Age of <a href="/wiki/Russian_Enlightenment" title="Russian Enlightenment">Russian Enlightenment</a>. She extended Russian political control over the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth and incorporated most of its territories into Russia during the <a href="/wiki/Partitions_of_Poland" title="Partitions of Poland">Partitions of Poland</a>, pushing the Russian frontier westward into Central Europe. In the south, after successful <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Turkish Wars">Russo-Turkish Wars</a> against <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turkey" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Turkey">Ottoman Turkey</a>, Catherine advanced Russia's boundary to the Black Sea, defeating the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_Khanate" title="Crimean Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>. As a result of victories over <a href="/wiki/Qajar_dynasty" title="Qajar dynasty">Qajar Iran</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Persian_Wars" title="Russo-Persian Wars">Russo-Persian Wars</a>, by the first half of the 19th century Russia also made significant territorial gains in <a href="/wiki/Transcaucasia" title="Transcaucasia">Transcaucasia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>, forcing the former to irrevocably cede what is nowadays <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(country)" title="Georgia (country)">Georgia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dagestan" title="Dagestan">Dagestan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a> to Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">&#91;72&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">&#91;73&#93;</a></sup> This continued with <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia" title="Alexander I of Russia">Alexander&#160;I's</a> (1801–25) wresting of Finland from the weakened kingdom of Sweden in 1809 and of <a href="/wiki/Bessarabia" title="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> from the Ottomans in 1812. At the same time, Russians <a href="/wiki/Russian_America" title="Russian America">colonized Alaska</a> and even founded settlements in California, such as <a href="/wiki/Fort_Ross" class="mw-redirect" title="Fort Ross">Fort Ross</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_1533-1896.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Russia_1533-1896.gif/220px-Russia_1533-1896.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Russia_1533-1896.gif/330px-Russia_1533-1896.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Russia_1533-1896.gif/440px-Russia_1533-1896.gif 2x" data-file-width="603" data-file-height="428" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_1533-1896.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian expansion in Eurasia between 1533 and 1894</div></div></div>
<p>In 1803–1806, the <a href="/wiki/First_Russian_circumnavigation" title="First Russian circumnavigation">first Russian circumnavigation</a> was made, later followed by other notable Russian sea exploration voyages. In 1820, <a href="/wiki/Fabian_Gottlieb_von_Bellingshausen#First_Russian_Antarctic_expedition" title="Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen">a Russian expedition</a> discovered the continent of <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
</p><p>In alliances with various European countries, Russia fought against <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s France. The <a href="/wiki/French_invasion_of_Russia" title="French invasion of Russia">French invasion of Russia</a> at the height of Napoleon's power in 1812 reached Moscow, but eventually failed miserably as the obstinate resistance in combination with the bitterly cold <a href="/wiki/Russian_winter" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian winter">Russian winter</a> led to a disastrous defeat of invaders, in which more than 95% of the pan-European <a href="/wiki/Grande_Arm%C3%A9e" title="Grande Armée">Grande Armée</a> perished.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">&#91;74&#93;</a></sup> Led by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kutuzov" title="Mikhail Kutuzov">Mikhail Kutuzov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barclay_de_Tolly" class="mw-redirect" title="Barclay de Tolly">Barclay de Tolly</a>, the Russian army ousted Napoleon from the country and drove through Europe in the <a href="/wiki/War_of_the_Sixth_Coalition" title="War of the Sixth Coalition">war of the Sixth Coalition</a>, finally entering Paris. Alexander&#160;I headed Russia's delegation at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Vienna" title="Congress of Vienna">Congress of Vienna</a> that defined the map of post-Napoleonic Europe.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koetoezov_kazan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Koetoezov_kazan.jpg/180px-Koetoezov_kazan.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="270" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Koetoezov_kazan.jpg/270px-Koetoezov_kazan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Koetoezov_kazan.jpg/360px-Koetoezov_kazan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Koetoezov_kazan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Monument to <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kutuzov" title="Mikhail Kutuzov">Mikhail Kutuzov</a> in front of the <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Cathedral,_St._Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Kazan Cathedral, St. Petersburg">Kazan Cathedral</a> in Saint Petersburg. The Kazan Cathedral and the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour" title="Cathedral of Christ the Saviour">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a> in Moscow were built to commemorate <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon</a>'s defeat.</div></div></div>
<p>The officers of the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> brought ideas of liberalism back to Russia with them and attempted to curtail the tsar's powers during the abortive <a href="/wiki/Decembrist_revolt" title="Decembrist revolt">Decembrist revolt</a> of 1825. At the end of the conservative reign of <a href="/wiki/Nicolas_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicolas I">Nicolas&#160;I</a> (1825–55), a zenith period of Russia's power and influence in Europe was disrupted by defeat in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a>. Between 1847 and 1851, about one million people died of Asiatic <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">&#91;75&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Nicholas's successor <a href="/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia" title="Alexander II of Russia">Alexander&#160;II</a> (1855–81) enacted significant changes in the country, including the <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_reform_of_1861" title="Emancipation reform of 1861">emancipation reform of 1861</a>. These <i>Great Reforms</i> spurred industrialization and modernized the Russian army, which had successfully liberated Bulgaria from Ottoman rule in the <a href="/wiki/1877%E2%80%9378_Russo-Turkish_War" class="mw-redirect" title="1877–78 Russo-Turkish War">1877–78 Russo-Turkish War</a>.
</p><p>The late 19th century saw the rise of various socialist movements in Russia. Alexander&#160;II was killed in 1881 by revolutionary terrorists, and the reign of his son
<a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Russia" title="Alexander III of Russia">Alexander&#160;III</a> (1881–94) was less liberal but more peaceful. The last Russian Emperor, <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Nicholas II">Nicholas&#160;II</a> (1894–1917), was unable to prevent the events of the Russian <a href="/wiki/Revolution_of_1905" class="mw-redirect" title="Revolution of 1905">Revolution of 1905</a>, triggered by the unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Russo-Japanese_War" title="Russo-Japanese War">Russo-Japanese War</a> and the demonstration incident known as <a href="/wiki/Bloody_Sunday_(1905)" title="Bloody Sunday (1905)">Bloody Sunday</a>. The uprising was put down, but the government was forced to concede major reforms (<a href="/wiki/Russian_Constitution_of_1906" title="Russian Constitution of 1906">Russian Constitution of 1906</a>), including granting the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_speech" title="Freedom of speech">freedoms of speech</a> and <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_assembly" title="Freedom of assembly">assembly</a>, the legalization of political parties, and the creation of an elected legislative body, the <a href="/wiki/State_Duma_of_the_Russian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="State Duma of the Russian Empire">State Duma of the Russian Empire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Stolypin_reform" title="Stolypin reform">Stolypin agrarian reform</a> led to a massive peasant migration and settlement into <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>. More than four million settlers arrived in that region between 1906 and 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">&#91;76&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="February_Revolution_and_Russian_Republic">February Revolution and Russian Republic</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Russian Provisional Government</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Republic" title="Russian Republic">Russian Republic</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/1917_Russian_Constituent_Assembly_election" title="1917 Russian Constituent Assembly election">1917 Russian Constituent Assembly election</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Democratic_Federative_Republic" title="Russian Democratic Federative Republic">Russian Democratic Federative Republic</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/210px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg" decoding="async" width="210" height="186" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/315px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg/420px-Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3711" data-file-height="3281" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Russian_Imperial_Family_1913.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II of Russia</a> and his family <a href="/wiki/Execution_of_the_Romanov_family" title="Execution of the Romanov family">were murdered</a> by the Bolsheviks in 1918.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1914, Russia entered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War&#160;I</a> in response to <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>'s declaration of war on Russia's ally <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a>, and fought across multiple fronts while isolated from its <a href="/wiki/Triple_Entente" title="Triple Entente">Triple Entente</a> allies. In 1916, the <a href="/wiki/Brusilov_Offensive" title="Brusilov Offensive">Brusilov Offensive</a> of the Russian Army almost completely destroyed the military of Austria-Hungary. However, the already-existing public distrust of the regime was deepened by the rising costs of war, <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">high casualties</a>, and rumors of corruption and treason. All this formed the climate for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> of 1917, carried out in two major acts.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/February_Revolution" title="February Revolution">February Revolution</a> forced <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_II_of_Russia" title="Nicholas II of Russia">Nicholas II</a> to abdicate; he and his family were imprisoned and <a href="/wiki/Shooting_of_the_Romanov_family" class="mw-redirect" title="Shooting of the Romanov family">later executed in Yekaterinburg</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>. The monarchy was replaced by a shaky coalition of political parties that declared itself the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Provisional_Government" title="Russian Provisional Government">Provisional Government</a>. On 1 September (14), 1917, upon a decree of the Provisional Government, the Russian Republic was proclaimed.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">&#91;77&#93;</a></sup> On 6 January (19), 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Constituent_Assembly" title="Russian Constituent Assembly">Russian Constituent Assembly</a> declared Russia a democratic federal republic (thus ratifying the Provisional Government's decision). The next day the Constituent Assembly was dissolved by the <a href="/wiki/All-Russian_Central_Executive_Committee" title="All-Russian Central Executive Committee">All-Russian Central Executive Committee</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg/180px-Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="248" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg/270px-Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg/360px-Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg 2x" data-file-width="464" data-file-height="640" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Thecristisrizenoldrussiancivilwarposter.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>1932 <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White émigré">White émigré</a> propaganda poster</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_Russia_and_civil_war">Soviet Russia and civil war</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">Russian Civil War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">White movement</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Constitution_of_1918" title="Russian Constitution of 1918">Russian Constitution of 1918</a></div>
<p>An alternative socialist establishment co-existed, the <a href="/wiki/Petrograd_Soviet" title="Petrograd Soviet">Petrograd Soviet</a>, wielding power through the democratically elected councils of workers and peasants, called <i><a href="/wiki/Soviet_(council)" title="Soviet (council)">Soviets</a></i>. The rule of the new authorities only aggravated the crisis in the country, instead of resolving it. Eventually, the <a href="/wiki/October_Revolution" title="October Revolution">October Revolution</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, overthrew the Provisional Government and gave full governing power to the Soviets, leading to the creation of the world's first <a href="/wiki/Socialist_state" title="Socialist state">socialist state</a>.
</p><p>Following the October Revolution, a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Civil_War" title="Russian Civil War">civil war</a> broke out between the <a href="/wiki/Anti-Communist" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-Communist">anti-Communist</a> <a href="/wiki/White_movement" title="White movement">White movement</a> and the new <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_council" title="Workers&#39; council">Soviet</a> regime with its <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a>. Bolshevist Russia lost its Ukrainian, Polish, Baltic, and Finnish territories by signing the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Brest-Litovsk_(Russia%E2%80%93Central_Powers)" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (Russia–Central Powers)">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> that concluded hostilities with the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> of World War&#160;I. The <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied powers</a> launched an unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Allied_intervention_in_the_Russian_Civil_War" title="Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War">military intervention</a> in support of anti-Communist forces. In the meantime both the Bolsheviks and White movement carried out campaigns of deportations and executions against each other, known respectively as the <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror" title="Red Terror">Red Terror</a> and <a href="/wiki/White_Terror_(Russia)" title="White Terror (Russia)">White Terror</a>. By the end of the civil war, Russia's economy and infrastructure were heavily damaged. There were an estimated 7–12 million casualties during the war, mostly civilians.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">&#91;78&#93;</a></sup> Millions became <a href="/wiki/White_%C3%A9migr%C3%A9" title="White émigré">White émigrés</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">&#91;79&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_famine_of_1921%E2%80%9322" title="Russian famine of 1921–22">Russian famine of 1921–22</a> claimed up to five&#160;million victims.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">&#91;80&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Soviet_Union">Soviet Union</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="History of the Soviet Union">History of the Soviet Union</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Creation_of_the_USSR" title="Treaty on the Creation of the USSR">Treaty on the Creation of the USSR</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:272px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg/270px-Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg" decoding="async" width="270" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg/405px-Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg/540px-Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg 2x" data-file-width="880" data-file-height="456" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Stalin-Lenin-Kalinin-1919.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kalinin" title="Mikhail Kalinin">Mikhail Kalinin</a> meeting in 1919. All three of them were "<a href="/wiki/Old_Bolsheviks" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Bolsheviks">Old Bolsheviks</a>"—members of the <a href="/wiki/Bolshevik" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> party before the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution_of_1917" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Revolution of 1917">Russian Revolution of 1917</a>, the first successful socialist revolution in human history.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic">Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic</a> (called <i>Russian Socialist Federative Soviet Republic</i> at the time), together with the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Ukrainian SSR">Ukrainian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byelorussian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Byelorussian SSR">Byelorussian</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Transcaucasian_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Transcaucasian SSR">Transcaucasian Soviet Socialist Republics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Creation_of_the_USSR" title="Treaty on the Creation of the USSR">formed</a> the <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Soviet_Socialist_Republics" class="mw-redirect" title="Union of Soviet Socialist Republics">Union of Soviet Socialist Republics</a> (USSR), or Soviet Union, on 30 December 1922. Out of the 15 <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Republics of the USSR">republics that would make up the USSR</a>, the largest in size and over half of the total USSR population was the Russian SFSR, which came to dominate the union for its entire 69-year history.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1922).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg/180px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg/270px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg/360px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281922%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="592" data-file-height="376" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1922).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Russian SFSR at the moment of <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_the_Creation_of_the_USSR" title="Treaty on the Creation of the USSR">formation of the USSR</a> in 1922</div></div></div>
