<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1940).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg/180px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="180" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg/270px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg/360px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_%281940%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="592" data-file-height="376" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR_(1940).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Russian SFSR as a part of the USSR in 1940, after <a href="/wiki/National_delimitation_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="National delimitation in the Soviet Union">1924–1936 intra-Soviet territorial changes</a> and the separation of the <a href="/wiki/Karelo-Finnish_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Karelo-Finnish SSR">Karelo-Finnish SSR</a> in 1940</div></div></div>
<p>Following <a href="/wiki/Death_and_state_funeral_of_Vladimir_Lenin" title="Death and state funeral of Vladimir Lenin">Lenin's death</a> in 1924, a <a href="/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Soviet_Union#List_of_troikas" title="List of leaders of the Soviet Union">troika</a> was designated to govern the Soviet Union. However, <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Stalin" title="Joseph Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a>, an elected <a href="/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union">General Secretary of the Communist Party</a>, managed to suppress all opposition groups within the party and consolidate power in his hands. <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a>, the main proponent of <a href="/wiki/World_revolution" title="World revolution">world revolution</a>, was exiled from the Soviet Union in 1929, and Stalin's idea of <a href="/wiki/Socialism_in_One_Country" title="Socialism in One Country">Socialism in One Country</a> became the primary line. The continued internal struggle in the Bolshevik party culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Purge" title="Great Purge">Great Purge</a>, a period of mass repressions in 1937–38, during which hundreds of thousands of people were executed, including <a href="/wiki/Old_Bolshevik" title="Old Bolshevik">original party members</a> and military leaders accused of <a href="/wiki/Coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="Coup d&#39;état">coup d'état</a> plots.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">&#91;81&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Stalin's leadership, the government launched a <a href="/wiki/Command_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Command economy">command economy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Industrialization_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrialization in the USSR">industrialization of the largely rural country</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivization in the USSR">collectivization</a> of <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_the_USSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Agriculture in the USSR">its agriculture</a>. During this period of rapid economic and social change, millions of people were sent to <a href="/wiki/Gulag" title="Gulag">penal labor camps</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Getty_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Getty-86">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> including many political convicts for their opposition to Stalin's rule; millions were <a href="/wiki/Population_transfer_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Population transfer in the Soviet Union">deported and exiled</a> to remote areas of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-Getty_86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Getty-86">&#91;82&#93;</a></sup> The transitional disorganisation of the country's agriculture, combined with the harsh state policies and a drought, led to the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%931933" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet famine of 1932–1933">Soviet famine of 1932–1933</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">&#91;83&#93;</a></sup> which killed between 2 and 3 million people in the Russian SFSR.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">&#91;84&#93;</a></sup> The Soviet Union made the costly transformation from a largely agrarian economy to a major industrial powerhouse in a short span of time.
</p><p>Under the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/State_atheism" title="State atheism">state atheism</a> in the Soviet Union, there was a "government-sponsored program of forced conversion to <a href="/wiki/Marxist-Leninist_atheism" class="mw-redirect" title="Marxist-Leninist atheism">atheism</a>" conducted by Communists.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">&#91;85&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">&#91;86&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Adappur2000_91-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Adappur2000-91">&#91;87&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Communist_regime" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist regime">communist regime</a> targeted religions based on State interests, and while most organized religions were never outlawed, religious property was confiscated, believers were harassed, and religion was ridiculed while atheism was propagated in schools.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">&#91;88&#93;</a></sup> In 1925 the government founded the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Militant_Atheists" title="League of Militant Atheists">League of Militant Atheists</a> to intensify the persecution.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">&#91;89&#93;</a></sup> Accordingly, although personal expressions of religious faith were not explicitly banned, a strong sense of social stigma was imposed on them by the official structures and mass media and it was generally considered unacceptable for members of certain professions (teachers, state bureaucrats, soldiers) to be openly religious. As for the Russian Orthodox Church, Soviet authorities sought to control it and, in times of national crisis, to exploit it for the regime's own purposes; but their ultimate goal was to eliminate it. During the first five years of Soviet power, the Bolsheviks executed 28 Russian Orthodox bishops and over 1,200 Russian Orthodox priests. Many others were imprisoned or exiled. Believers were harassed and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Christians_in_the_Soviet_Union" title="Persecution of Christians in the Soviet Union">persecuted</a>. Most seminaries were closed, and the publication of most religious material was prohibited. By 1941 only 500 churches remained open out of about 54,000 in existence prior to World War I.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="World_War_II">World War II</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg/300px-RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="108" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg/450px-RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg/600px-RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2163" data-file-height="776" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_44732_Soviet_soldiers_attack_house.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a>, the largest and bloodiest battle in the history of warfare, ended in 1943 with a decisive Soviet victory.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Appeasement" title="Appeasement">Appeasement</a> policy of Great <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a> towards <a href="/wiki/Adolf_Hitler" title="Adolf Hitler">Adolf Hitler</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Anschluss" title="Anschluss">annexation of Austria</a> and <a href="/wiki/German_occupation_of_Czechoslovakia" title="German occupation of Czechoslovakia">Czechoslovakia</a> did not stem an increase in the power of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>. Around the same time, the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Third Reich</a> allied with the <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Japan" title="Empire of Japan">Empire of Japan</a>, a rival of the USSR in the Far East and an open enemy of the USSR in the <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_Border_Wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet–Japanese Border Wars">Soviet–Japanese Border Wars</a> in 1938–39.
</p><p>In August 1939, the Soviet government decided to improve relations with Germany by concluding the <a href="/wiki/Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop_Pact" title="Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>, pledging <a href="/wiki/Non-aggression_pact" title="Non-aggression pact">non-aggression</a> between the two countries and dividing Eastern Europe into their respective spheres of influence. While Hitler conquered Poland and France and other countries acted on a single front at the start of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War&#160;II</a>, the USSR was able to build up its military and occupy the Western Ukraine, <a href="/wiki/Hertza_region" title="Hertza region">Hertza region</a> and Northern <a href="/wiki/Bukovina" title="Bukovina">Bukovina</a> as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Poland" title="Soviet invasion of Poland">Soviet invasion of Poland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Winter_War" title="Winter War">Winter War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_the_Baltic_states_(1940)" title="Soviet occupation of the Baltic states (1940)">the occupation of the Baltic states</a> and <a href="/wiki/Soviet_occupation_of_Bessarabia_and_Northern_Bukovina" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina">Soviet occupation of Bessarabia and Northern Bukovina</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="366" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_2153_After_bombing.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad" title="Siege of Leningrad">Siege of Leningrad</a> was the deadliest siege of a city in history.</div></div></div>
<p>On 22 June 1941, Nazi Germany broke the non-aggression treaty and <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">invaded</a> the Soviet Union with the largest and most powerful invasion force in human history,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">&#91;90&#93;</a></sup> opening the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">largest theater of World War&#160;II</a>. The Nazi <a href="/wiki/Hunger_Plan" title="Hunger Plan">Hunger Plan</a> foresaw the "extinction of industry as well as a great part of the population".<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">&#91;91&#93;</a></sup> Nearly 3 million <a href="/wiki/German_mistreatment_of_Soviet_prisoners_of_war" title="German mistreatment of Soviet prisoners of war">Soviet POWs</a> in German captivity were murdered in just eight months of 1941–42.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">&#91;92&#93;</a></sup> Although the <a href="/wiki/Wehrmacht" title="Wehrmacht">German army</a> had considerable early success, their attack was halted in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Moscow" title="Battle of Moscow">Battle of Moscow</a>. Subsequently, the Germans were dealt major defeats first at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Stalingrad" title="Battle of Stalingrad">Battle of Stalingrad</a> in the winter of 1942–43,<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">&#91;93&#93;</a></sup> and then in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kursk" title="Battle of Kursk">Battle of Kursk</a> in the summer of 1943. Another German failure was the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Leningrad" title="Siege of Leningrad">Siege of Leningrad</a>, in which the city was fully blockaded on land between 1941 and 1944 by German and Finnish forces, and suffered starvation and more than a million deaths, but never surrendered.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">&#91;94&#93;</a></sup> Under Stalin's administration and the leadership of such commanders as <a href="/wiki/Georgy_Zhukov" title="Georgy Zhukov">Georgy Zhukov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Rokossovsky" title="Konstantin Rokossovsky">Konstantin Rokossovsky</a>, Soviet forces took Eastern Europe in 1944–45 and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Berlin" title="Battle of Berlin">captured Berlin</a> in May 1945. In August 1945 the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Army" title="Soviet Army">Soviet Army</a> <a href="/wiki/Soviet%E2%80%93Japanese_War" title="Soviet–Japanese War">ousted the Japanese</a> from China's <a href="/wiki/Manchukuo" title="Manchukuo">Manchukuo</a> and North Korea, contributing to the allied victory over Japan.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png/390px-World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png" decoding="async" width="390" height="206" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png/585px-World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png/780px-World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png 2x" data-file-width="1368" data-file-height="724" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:World_War_II_military_deaths_in_Europe_by_theater_and_by_year.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The German armed forces suffered 80% of its <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">military deaths</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Front_(World_War_II)" title="Eastern Front (World War II)">Eastern Front</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">&#91;95&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The 1941–45 period of World War&#160;II is known in Russia as the "<a href="/wiki/Great_Patriotic_War_(term)" title="Great Patriotic War (term)">Great Patriotic War</a>". The Soviet Union together with the United States, the United Kingdom and China were considered as the <a href="/wiki/Big_Four_in_World_War_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Four in World War II">Big Four</a> of Allied powers in World War II <sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">&#91;96&#93;</a></sup> and later became the <a href="/wiki/Four_Policemen" title="Four Policemen">Four Policemen</a> which was the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">&#91;97&#93;</a></sup> During this war, which included many of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_battles_by_casualties" title="List of battles by casualties">most lethal battle operations</a> in human history, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="World War II casualties of the Soviet Union">Soviet civilian and military death were about 27 million</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">&#91;98&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">&#91;99&#93;</a></sup> accounting for about a third of all <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">World War&#160;II casualties</a>. The full demographic loss to the Soviet peoples was even greater.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">&#91;100&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Soviet_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet economy">Soviet economy</a> and infrastructure suffered massive devastation which caused the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1946%E2%80%9347" title="Soviet famine of 1946–47">Soviet famine of 1946–47</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">&#91;101&#93;</a></sup> but the Soviet Union emerged as an acknowledged military superpower on the continent.
</p><p>The Soviet rear was also badly damaged by the <a href="/wiki/Operation_Barbarossa" title="Operation Barbarossa">German invasion</a>. <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> bombed the cities of the Soviet Union from the air. <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Gorky</a> suffered the most from the <a href="/wiki/Bombing_of_Gorky_in_World_War_II" title="Bombing of Gorky in World War II">bombing</a>. This city was the main industrial center of the USSR and was located near the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Defence_Zone" title="Moscow Defence Zone">Moscow Defence Zone</a>. The bombing of the <a href="/wiki/Volga_Military_District" title="Volga Military District">Volga</a> capital destroyed the largest automobile plant <a href="/wiki/GAZ" title="GAZ">GAZ</a>. This plant supplied tanks for the front. Whole residential areas and other large factories of the city were destroyed. From 1941 to 1943, German pilots bombed different areas of the city. This bombardment is comparable to the <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">London Blitz</a>. Some damage remained until this time.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cold_War">Cold War</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg/220px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="140" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg/330px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg/440px-Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="592" data-file-height="376" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Soviet_Union_-_Russian_SFSR.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The RSFSR in 1956–1991, mostly after territorial acquisitions according to WWII treaties, the accession of <a href="/wiki/Tuvan_People%27s_Republic" title="Tuvan People&#39;s Republic">Tuva</a> in 1944, the <a href="/wiki/1954_transfer_of_Crimea" title="1954 transfer of Crimea">transfer of the Crimean Oblast in 1954</a> and the incorporation of the <a href="/wiki/Karelo-Finnish_SSR" class="mw-redirect" title="Karelo-Finnish SSR">Karelo-Finnish SSR</a> in 1956. In 1991, the borders of the Russian SFSR became the Russian Federation's international borders with sovereign states</div></div></div>
<p>After the war, Eastern and Central Europe including <a href="/wiki/East_Germany" title="East Germany">East Germany</a> and part of <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> was occupied by <a href="/wiki/Red_Army" title="Red Army">Red Army</a> according to the <a href="/wiki/Potsdam_Conference" title="Potsdam Conference">Potsdam Conference</a>. Dependent socialist governments were installed in the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Bloc" title="Eastern Bloc">Eastern Bloc</a> satellite states. Becoming the world's second <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">nuclear weapons power</a>, the USSR established the <a href="/wiki/Warsaw_Pact" title="Warsaw Pact">Warsaw Pact</a> alliance and entered into a struggle for global dominance, known as the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, with the United States and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>. The Soviet Union supported revolutionary movements across the world, including the newly formed People's Republic of China, the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_People%27s_Republic_of_Korea" class="mw-redirect" title="Democratic People&#39;s Republic of Korea">Democratic People's Republic of Korea</a> and, later on, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Cuba" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Cuba">Republic of Cuba</a>. Significant amounts of Soviet resources were <a href="/wiki/International_relations_within_the_Comecon" title="International relations within the Comecon">allocated in aid</a> to the other socialist states.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">&#91;102&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/Stalin%27s_death" class="mw-redirect" title="Stalin&#39;s death">Stalin's death</a> and a short period of <a href="/wiki/Collective_leadership" title="Collective leadership">collective rule</a>, the new leader <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> denounced the <a href="/wiki/Stalin%27s_cult_of_personality" title="Stalin&#39;s cult of personality">cult of personality of Stalin</a> and launched the policy of <a href="/wiki/De-Stalinization" title="De-Stalinization">de-Stalinization</a>. The penal labor system was reformed and many prisoners were released and rehabilitated (many of them posthumously).<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">&#91;103&#93;</a></sup> The general easement of repressive policies became known later as the <a href="/wiki/Khrushchev_Thaw" title="Khrushchev Thaw">Khrushchev Thaw</a>. At the same time, tensions with the United States heightened when the two rivals clashed over the deployment of the United States <a href="/wiki/PGM-19_Jupiter" title="PGM-19 Jupiter">Jupiter missiles</a> in Turkey and Soviet <a href="/wiki/Cuban_Missile_Crisis" title="Cuban Missile Crisis">missiles in Cuba</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sputnik_asm.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Sputnik_asm.jpg/190px-Sputnik_asm.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="156" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Sputnik_asm.jpg/285px-Sputnik_asm.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Sputnik_asm.jpg/380px-Sputnik_asm.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1094" data-file-height="896" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sputnik_asm.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik&#160;1</a> was the world's first artificial satellite.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1957, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> launched the world's first artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik&#160;1</a></i>, thus starting the <a href="/wiki/Space_Age" title="Space Age">Space Age</a>. Russia's <a href="/wiki/Cosmonaut" class="mw-redirect" title="Cosmonaut">cosmonaut</a> <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a> became the first human to orbit the Earth, aboard the <i><a href="/wiki/Vostok_1" title="Vostok 1">Vostok&#160;1</a></i> manned spacecraft on <a href="/wiki/Cosmonautics_Day" title="Cosmonautics Day">12 April 1961</a>.
</p><p>Following the ousting of Khrushchev in 1964, another period of <a href="/wiki/Collectivity_of_leadership" class="mw-redirect" title="Collectivity of leadership">collective rule</a> ensued, until <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Brezhnev" title="Leonid Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> became the leader. The era of the 1970s and the early 1980s was later designated as the <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Stagnation" title="Era of Stagnation">Era of Stagnation</a>, a period when economic growth slowed and social policies became static. The 1965 <a href="/wiki/Kosygin_reform" class="mw-redirect" title="Kosygin reform">Kosygin reform</a> aimed for partial <a href="/wiki/Decentralization" title="Decentralization">decentralization</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet economy">Soviet economy</a> and shifted the emphasis from <a href="/wiki/Heavy_industry" title="Heavy industry">heavy industry</a> and weapons to <a href="/wiki/Light_industry" title="Light industry">light industry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consumer_goods" class="mw-redirect" title="Consumer goods">consumer goods</a> but was stifled by the conservative Communist leadership.
</p><p>In 1979, after a Communist-led revolution in Afghanistan, <a href="/wiki/Soviet_invasion_of_Afghanistan" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet invasion of Afghanistan">Soviet forces entered</a> that country. The occupation drained economic resources and dragged on without achieving meaningful political results. Ultimately, the Soviet Army was withdrawn from Afghanistan in 1989 due to international opposition, persistent anti-Soviet guerrilla warfare, and a lack of support by Soviet citizens.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg/220px-Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg/330px-Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg/440px-Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg 2x" data-file-width="750" data-file-height="505" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Reagan_and_Gorbachev_hold_discussions.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> in one-to-one discussions with US President <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan" title="Ronald Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a></div></div></div>
<p>From 1985 onwards, the last Soviet leader <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, who sought to enact liberal reforms in the Soviet system, introduced the policies of <i><a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a></i> (openness) and <i><a href="/wiki/Perestroika" title="Perestroika">perestroika</a></i> (restructuring) in an attempt to end the <a href="/wiki/Era_of_Stagnation" title="Era of Stagnation">period of economic stagnation</a> and to <a href="/wiki/Demokratizatsiya_(Soviet_Union)" title="Demokratizatsiya (Soviet Union)">democratize the government</a>. This, however, led to the rise of strong nationalist and separatist movements. Prior to 1991, the Soviet economy was the second largest in the world,<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">&#91;104&#93;</a></sup> but during its last years it was afflicted by shortages of goods in grocery stores, huge budget deficits, and explosive growth in the money supply leading to inflation.<sup id="cite_ref-photius.com_109-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-photius.com-109">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>By 1991, economic and political turmoil began to boil over, as the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_states" title="Baltic states">Baltic states</a> chose to secede from the Soviet Union. On 17 March, a <a href="/wiki/1991_Soviet_Union_referendum" title="1991 Soviet Union referendum">referendum</a> was held, in which the vast majority of participating citizens voted in favour of changing the Soviet Union into a <a href="/wiki/Union_of_Sovereign_States" title="Union of Sovereign States">renewed federation</a>. In August 1991, <a href="/wiki/1991_Soviet_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1991 Soviet coup d&#39;état attempt">a coup d'état attempt</a> by members of Gorbachev's government, directed against Gorbachev and aimed at preserving the Soviet Union, instead led to the end of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. On 25 December 1991, the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">USSR was dissolved</a> into 15 <a href="/wiki/Post-Soviet_states" title="Post-Soviet states">post-Soviet states</a>.
</p>
<h3><span id="Post-Soviet_Russia_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-Soviet_Russia_(1991–present)">Post-Soviet Russia (1991–present)</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Russia_(1991%E2%80%93present)" title="History of Russia (1991–present)">History of Russia (1991–present)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_the_United_Nations" title="Russia and the United Nations">Russia and the United Nations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1993_Constitution_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="1993 Constitution of Russia">1993 Constitution of Russia</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a>, <a href="/wiki/War_of_Laws" title="War of Laws">War of Laws</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1993_Russian_constitutional_crisis" title="1993 Russian constitutional crisis">1993 Russian constitutional crisis</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="334" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_with_Boris_Yeltsin-5.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>President <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> with <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Alexy_II_of_Moscow" title="Patriarch Alexy II of Moscow">Patriarch Alexy II of Moscow</a> and Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a></div></div></div>
<p>In June 1991, <a href="/wiki/Boris_Yeltsin" title="Boris Yeltsin">Boris Yeltsin</a> became the first directly elected President in Russian history when he was elected President of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, which became the independent Russian Federation in December of that year. During and after the disintegration of the Soviet Union, wide-ranging reforms including <a href="/wiki/Privatization_in_Russia" title="Privatization in Russia">privatization</a> and <a href="/wiki/Free_trade" title="Free trade">market and trade liberalization</a> were undertaken,<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-110">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup> including radical changes along the lines of "<a href="/wiki/Shock_therapy_(economics)" title="Shock therapy (economics)">shock therapy</a>" as recommended by the United States and the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Sciolino,_E_111-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sciolino,_E-111">&#91;107&#93;</a></sup> All this resulted in a major <a href="/wiki/Economic_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic crisis">economic crisis</a>, characterized by a 50% decline in both GDP and industrial output between 1990 and 1995.<sup id="cite_ref-OECD_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OECD-110">&#91;106&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">&#91;108&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The privatization largely shifted control of enterprises from state agencies to individuals with inside connections in the government. Many of the newly rich moved billions in cash and assets outside of the country in an enormous <a href="/wiki/Capital_flight" title="Capital flight">capital flight</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">&#91;109&#93;</a></sup> The depression of the economy led to the collapse of social services; the <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a> plummeted while the <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> skyrocketed.<sup id="cite_ref-TBTCTES106_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TBTCTES106-114">&#91;110&#93;</a></sup> Millions plunged into poverty, from a level of 1.5% in the late Soviet era to 39–49% by mid-1993.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-115">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> The 1990s saw extreme corruption and lawlessness, the rise of criminal gangs and violent crime.<sup id="cite_ref-Jason_Bush_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jason_Bush-116">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1990s were plagued by armed conflicts in the <a href="/wiki/North_Caucasus" title="North Caucasus">North Caucasus</a>, both local ethnic skirmishes and separatist <a href="/wiki/Islamist" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamist">Islamist</a> insurrections. From the time <a href="/wiki/Chechnya" title="Chechnya">Chechen</a> separatists declared independence in the early 1990s, an <a href="/wiki/First_Chechen_War" title="First Chechen War">intermittent guerrilla war</a> has been fought between the rebel groups and the Russian military. <a href="/wiki/Terrorism_in_Russia" title="Terrorism in Russia">Terrorist attacks against civilians</a> carried out by separatists, most notably the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_theater_hostage_crisis" title="Moscow theater hostage crisis">Moscow theater hostage crisis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Beslan_school_siege" title="Beslan school siege">Beslan school siege</a>, caused hundreds of deaths and drew worldwide attention.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg/220px-Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg/330px-Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg/440px-Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="434" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Obama_and_Medvedev_sign_Prague_Treaty_2010.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> after signing the <a href="/wiki/New_START" title="New START">New START</a> treaty</div></div></div>
<p>Russia took up the responsibility for settling the USSR's external debts, even though its population made up just half of the population of the USSR at the time of its dissolution.<sup id="cite_ref-Jason_Bush_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jason_Bush-116">&#91;112&#93;</a></sup> In 1992, most consumer price controls were eliminated, causing extreme inflation and significantly devaluing the Ruble.<sup id="cite_ref-Lipton_1992_213_117-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipton_1992_213-117">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> With a devalued Ruble, the Russian government struggled to pay back its debts to internal debtors, as well as international institutions like the International Monetary Fund.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">&#91;114&#93;</a></sup> Despite significant attempts at economic restructuring, Russia's debt outpaced GDP growth.  High budget deficits coupled with increasing capital flight and inability to pay back debts<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">&#91;115&#93;</a></sup> caused the 1998 Russian financial crisis<sup id="cite_ref-Lipton_1992_213_117-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lipton_1992_213-117">&#91;113&#93;</a></sup> and resulted in a further GDP decline.<sup id="cite_ref-photius.com_109-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-photius.com-109">&#91;105&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 31 December 1999, President Yeltsin unexpectedly resigned, handing the post to the recently appointed Prime Minister, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a>, who then won <a href="/wiki/2000_Russian_presidential_election" title="2000 Russian presidential election">the 2000 presidential election</a>. Putin <a href="/wiki/Second_Chechen_War" title="Second Chechen War">suppressed the Chechen insurgency</a> although sporadic violence still occurs throughout the Northern Caucasus. <a href="/wiki/World_oil_market_chronology_from_2003" title="World oil market chronology from 2003">High oil prices</a> and the initially weak currency followed by increasing domestic demand, consumption, and investments helped the economy grow at an average of 7% per year from 1998 to 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-CIA2019_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2019-120">&#91;116&#93;</a></sup> improving the standard of living and increasing Russia's influence on the world stage.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> Following the world economic crisis of 2008 and a subsequent drop in oil prices, Russia's economy stagnated and poverty again started to rise<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">&#91;118&#93;</a></sup> until 2017 when, after the prolonged recession, Russia's economy began to grow again, supported by stronger global growth, higher oil prices, and solid macro fundamentals.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">&#91;119&#93;</a></sup> While many reforms made during the Putin presidency have been generally criticized by Western nations as undemocratic,<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">&#91;120&#93;</a></sup> Putin's leadership over the return of order, stability, and progress has won him widespread admiration in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">&#91;121&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov,_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/220px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/330px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg/440px-Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov%2C_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="4091" data-file-height="2722" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Putin_with_Vladimir_Konstantinov,_Sergey_Aksyonov_and_Alexey_Chaly_4.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> (third, left), <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Aksyonov" title="Sergey Aksyonov">Sergey Aksyonov</a> (first, left), <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Konstantinov_(politician)" title="Vladimir Konstantinov (politician)">Vladimir Konstantinov</a> (second, left) and <a href="/wiki/Aleksei_Chalyi" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksei Chalyi">Aleksei Chalyi</a> (right) sign the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_on_Accession_of_the_Republic_of_Crimea_to_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty on Accession of the Republic of Crimea to Russia">Treaty on Accession of the Republic of Crimea to Russia</a> in 2014</div></div></div>
<p>On 2 March 2008, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> was elected President of Russia while Putin became <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="Prime Minister of Russia">Prime Minister</a>. Putin returned to the presidency following the <a href="/wiki/2012_Russian_presidential_election" title="2012 Russian presidential election">2012 presidential elections</a>, and Medvedev was appointed Prime Minister. This quick succession in leadership change was coined "<a href="/wiki/Tandemocracy" title="Tandemocracy">tandemocracy</a>" by outside media. Some critics claimed that the leadership change was superficial, and that Putin remained as the decision making force in the Russian government. Within the context of the ongoing <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine_gas_disputes#Cutting_off_supply_(January_2009)" title="Russia–Ukraine gas disputes">Russia–Ukraine gas dispute</a> in early January 2009, Nikolai Petrov, an analyst with the <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Moscow_Center" title="Carnegie Moscow Center">Carnegie Moscow Center</a> said: "What we see right now is the dominant role of Putin. We see him as a real head of state. ... This is not surprising. We are still living in Putin's Russia."<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">&#91;122&#93;</a></sup> Some Russian political analysts and commentators viewed the political power as truly tandem between Medvedev and Putin. Prior to the 2008 election, political scientists <a href="/wiki/Gleb_Pavlovsky" title="Gleb Pavlovsky">Gleb Pavlovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stanislav_Belkovsky" title="Stanislav Belkovsky">Stanislav Belkovsky</a> discussed the future configuration of power. According to Mr. Pavlovsky, people would be very suited with the option of the union of Putin and Medvedev "similar to the two Consuls of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Rome</a>". Belkovsky called Medvedev "President of a dream", referring to the early 1990s when people ostensibly dreamed of the time they "would live without the stranglehold of ubiquitous ideology, and a common person would become the head of the state".<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">&#91;123&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014, after President <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Yanukovych" title="Viktor Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> fled as a result of a <a href="/wiki/2014_Ukrainian_revolution" title="2014 Ukrainian revolution">revolution</a>, Putin requested and received authorization from the Russian Parliament to <a href="/wiki/2014_Russian_military_intervention_in_Ukraine" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Russian military intervention in Ukraine">deploy Russian troops to Ukraine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">&#91;124&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BBCPutinDeploys_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCPutinDeploys-129">&#91;125&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Radyuhin_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Radyuhin-130">&#91;126&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-walker-the-guardian-2014-descend_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-walker-the-guardian-2014-descend-131">&#91;127&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bloomberg-news-2014-request_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bloomberg-news-2014-request-132">&#91;128&#93;</a></sup> Following a <a href="/wiki/2014_Crimean_status_referendum" title="2014 Crimean status referendum">Crimean referendum</a> in which separation was favored by a large majority of voters,<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">&#91;129&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">&#91;130&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">&#91;131&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">&#91;132&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">&#91;133&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">&#91;134&#93;</a></sup> the Russian leadership announced the accession of Crimea into the Russian Federation, though this and the referendum that preceded it were not accepted internationally. On 27 March the United Nations General Assembly voted in favor of a non-binding resolution opposing the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Russian annexation of Crimea</a> by a vote of 100 member states in favor, 11 against and 58 abstentions.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">&#91;135&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In September 2015, Russia started <a href="/wiki/Russian_military_intervention_in_the_Syrian_Civil_War" title="Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War">military intervention</a> in the Syrian Civil War, consisting of air strikes against militant groups of the <a href="/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant" title="Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant">Islamic State</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al-Nusra_Front" title="Al-Nusra Front">al-Nusra Front</a> (al-Qaeda in the Levant), and the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_Conquest" title="Army of Conquest">Army of Conquest</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Russia" title="Politics of Russia">Politics of Russia</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:left;background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:268px;max-width:268px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_(2017-07-08).jpg" class="image"><img alt="Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg/130px-Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="166" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg/195px-Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg/260px-Vladimir_Putin_%282017-07-08%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="903" data-file-height="1155" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/15px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png" decoding="async" width="15" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/23px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/30px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1200" /></span> <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">President</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a></small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="Dmitry Anatolyevich Medvedev" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg/130px-Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="174" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg/195px-Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg/260px-Dmitry_Medvedev_govru_official_photo_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1795" data-file-height="2398" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/File:Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg" class="image"><img alt="Coat of Arms of the Russian Federation 2.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg/15px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg.png" decoding="async" width="15" height="16" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg/23px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg/30px-Coat_of_Arms_of_the_Russian_Federation_2.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="367" data-file-height="402" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="Prime Minister of Russia">Prime Minister</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a></small></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia" title="Constitution of Russia">Constitution of Russia</a>, the country is an <a href="/wiki/Asymmetric_federalism" title="Asymmetric federalism">asymmetric federation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential">semi-presidential</a> republic, wherein the President is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">&#91;136&#93;</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="Prime Minister of Russia">Prime Minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The Russian Federation is fundamentally structured as a <a href="/wiki/Multi-party_system" title="Multi-party system">multi-party</a> <a href="/wiki/Representative_democracy" title="Representative democracy">representative democracy</a>, with the federal government composed of three branches:
</p>
<ul><li>Legislative: The <a href="/wiki/Bicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Bicameral">bicameral</a> <a href="/wiki/Federal_Assembly_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Assembly of Russia">Federal Assembly of Russia</a>, made up of the 450-member <a href="/wiki/State_Duma" title="State Duma">State Duma</a> and the 170-member <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="Federation Council">Federation Council</a>, adopts <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_war" title="Declaration of war">declares war</a>, approves treaties, has the <a href="/wiki/Power_of_the_purse" title="Power of the purse">power of the purse</a> and the power of <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeachment</a> of the President.</li>
<li>Executive: The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">President</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Commander-in-Chief_of_the_Armed_Forces_of_the_Russian_Federation" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation">Commander-in-Chief</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Armed Forces</a>, can veto <a href="/wiki/Legislative_bill" class="mw-redirect" title="Legislative bill">legislative bills</a> before they become law, and appoints the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" title="Government of Russia">Government of Russia</a> (Cabinet) and other officers, who administer and enforce federal laws and policies.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Russia" title="Judiciary of Russia">Judiciary</a>: The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Russia" title="Constitutional Court of Russia">Constitutional Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Russia" title="Supreme Court of Russia">Supreme Court</a> and lower federal courts, whose judges are appointed by the Federation Council on the recommendation of the President, interpret laws and can overturn laws they deem <a href="/wiki/Unconstitutional" class="mw-redirect" title="Unconstitutional">unconstitutional</a>.</li></ul>
<p>The president is elected by popular vote for a six-year term (eligible for a second term, but not for a third consecutive term).<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">&#91;137&#93;</a></sup> Ministries of the government are composed of the Premier and his deputies, ministers, and selected other individuals; all are appointed by the President on the recommendation of the Prime Minister (whereas the appointment of the latter requires the consent of the State Duma). Leading political parties in Russia include <a href="/wiki/United_Russia" title="United Russia">United Russia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Communist Party of the Russian Federation">Communist Party</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Political_party_LDPR" class="mw-redirect" title="Political party LDPR">Liberal Democratic Party</a>, and <a href="/wiki/A_Just_Russia" title="A Just Russia">A Just Russia</a>. In 2017, Russia was ranked as 135th of 167 countries in the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>, compiled by <a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a> Intelligence Unit,<sup id="cite_ref-wjp_142-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wjp-142">&#91;138&#93;</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">World Justice Project</a>, as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, ranked Russia 80th of 99 countries surveyed in terms of rule of law.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">&#91;139&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Russia" title="Foreign relations of Russia">Foreign relations of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Continental_Orgs_Map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Continental_Orgs_Map.png/220px-Continental_Orgs_Map.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="102" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Continental_Orgs_Map.png/330px-Continental_Orgs_Map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Continental_Orgs_Map.png/440px-Continental_Orgs_Map.png 2x" data-file-width="1357" data-file-height="628" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Continental_Orgs_Map.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>As a <a href="/wiki/Transcontinental_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Transcontinental country">transcontinental country</a>, Russia is a member of both the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> (COE) and the <a href="/wiki/Asia_Cooperation_Dialogue" title="Asia Cooperation Dialogue">Asia Cooperation Dialogue</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Council_of_Europe_(blue).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg/220px-Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="185" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg/330px-Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg/440px-Council_of_Europe_%28blue%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2045" data-file-height="1720" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Council_of_Europe_(blue).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Russian Federation became the 39th member state of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> on 28 February 1996.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SCO_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/220px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/330px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/440px-SCO_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="553" data-file-height="553" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:SCO_(orthographic_projection).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Member states, observers and partners of the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation</a> (SCO)</div></div></div>
<p>The Russian Federation is recognized in international law as a <a href="/wiki/Successor_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Successor state">successor state</a> of the former <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-uk_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uk-33">&#91;29&#93;</a></sup> Russia continues to implement the international commitments of the USSR, and has assumed the USSR's permanent seat in the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">UN Security Council</a>, membership in other international organisations, the rights and obligations under international treaties, and property and debts. Russia has a multifaceted foreign policy. As of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, it maintains diplomatic relations with 191 countries and has <a href="/wiki/Russian_embassies" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian embassies">144 embassies</a>. The foreign policy is determined by the President and implemented by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia">Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">&#91;140&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Although it is the successor state to a former superpower, Russia is commonly accepted to be a <a href="/wiki/Great_power" title="Great power">great power</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">&#91;141&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">&#91;142&#93;</a></sup> Russia is one of five permanent members of the UN Security Council.  The country participates in the <a href="/wiki/Quartet_on_the_Middle_East" title="Quartet on the Middle East">Quartet on the Middle East</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Six-party_talks" title="Six-party talks">Six-party talks</a> with North Korea. Russia is a member of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation" title="Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation">APEC</a>. Russia usually takes a leading role in regional organisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Independent_States" title="Commonwealth of Independent States">CIS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Community" title="Eurasian Economic Community">EurAsEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Collective_Security_Treaty_Organisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Collective Security Treaty Organisation">CSTO</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">&#91;143&#93;</a></sup> Russia became the 39th member state of the Council of Europe in 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">&#91;144&#93;</a></sup> In 1998, Russia ratified the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>. The legal basis for EU relations with Russia is the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement, which came into force in 1997. The Agreement recalls the parties' shared respect for democracy and human rights, political and economic freedom and commitment to international peace and security.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">&#91;145&#93;</a></sup> In May 2003, the EU and Russia agreed to reinforce their cooperation on the basis of common values and shared interests.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">&#91;146&#93;</a></sup> Former President Vladimir Putin had advocated a strategic partnership with close integration in various dimensions including establishment of <a href="/wiki/EU-Russia_Common_Spaces" class="mw-redirect" title="EU-Russia Common Spaces">EU-Russia Common Spaces</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">&#91;147&#93;</a></sup> From the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Russia has initially developed a friendlier relationship with the <a href="/wiki/Russia-United_States_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia-United States relations">United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO-Russia_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="NATO-Russia relations">NATO</a>, however today, the trilateral relationship has significantly deteriorated due to several issues and conflicts between Russia and the Western countries.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">&#91;148&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">&#91;149&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/NATO-Russia_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="NATO-Russia Council">NATO-Russia Council</a> was established in 2002 to allow the United States, Russia and the 27 allies in NATO to work together as equal partners to pursue opportunities for joint collaboration.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">&#91;150&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg/220px-BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="120" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg/330px-BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg/440px-BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1568" data-file-height="858" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:BRICS_leaders_meet_on_the_sidelines_of_2016_G20_Summit_in_China.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Leaders of the <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> nations in 2016: (l-r) <a href="/wiki/Michel_Temer" title="Michel Temer">Michel Temer</a> of Brazil, <a href="/wiki/Narendra_Modi" title="Narendra Modi">Narendra Modi</a> of India, <a href="/wiki/Xi_Jinping" title="Xi Jinping">Xi Jinping</a> of China, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> of Russia and <a href="/wiki/Jacob_Zuma" title="Jacob Zuma">Jacob Zuma</a> of South Africa</div></div></div>
<p>Russia maintains strong and positive relations with other <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">SCO</a> and <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">&#91;151&#93;</a></sup> In recent years, the country has significantly strengthened bilateral ties with the <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">People's Republic of China</a> by signing the <a href="/wiki/2001_Sino-Russian_Treaty_of_Friendship" title="2001 Sino-Russian Treaty of Friendship">Treaty of Friendship</a> as well as building the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_oil_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Trans-Siberian oil pipeline">Trans-Siberian oil pipeline</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yakutia%E2%80%93Khabarovsk%E2%80%93Vladivostok_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Yakutia–Khabarovsk–Vladivostok pipeline">gas pipeline from Siberia to China</a>, and has since formed a <a href="/wiki/Sino-Russian_relations_since_1991" title="Sino-Russian relations since 1991">special relationship with China</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">&#91;152&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">&#91;153&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> is the largest customer of Russian military equipment and the two countries share <a href="/wiki/India%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="India–Russia relations">extensive defense and strategic relations</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">&#91;154&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>An important aspect of Russia's relations with the West is the criticism of Russia's political system and <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Russia" title="Human rights in Russia">human rights</a> management (including <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Russia" title="LGBT rights in Russia">LGBT rights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Russia" title="Media freedom in Russia">media freedom</a>, and reports about <a href="/wiki/List_of_journalists_killed_in_Russia" title="List of journalists killed in Russia">killed journalists</a>) by Western governments, the mass media and the leading democracy and human rights <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/watchdog" class="extiw" title="wikt:watchdog">watchdogs</a>. In particular, such organisations as <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> and <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> consider Russia to have not enough democratic attributes and to allow few political rights and civil liberties to its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">&#91;155&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">&#91;156&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>, an international organisation funded by the United States, ranks Russia as "not free", citing "carefully engineered elections" and "absence" of debate.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">&#91;157&#93;</a></sup> Russian authorities dismiss these claims and especially criticise Freedom House. The Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has called the 2006 <i><a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a></i> report "prefabricated", stating that the human rights issues have been turned into a political weapon in particular by the United States. The ministry also claims that such organisations as Freedom House and Human Rights Watch use the same scheme of voluntary extrapolation of "isolated facts that of course can be found in any country" into "dominant tendencies".<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">&#91;158&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_Armed_Forces" title="Russian Armed Forces">Russian Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Army-2015_2.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Army-2015_2.png/220px-Army-2015_2.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Army-2015_2.png/330px-Army-2015_2.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Army-2015_2.png/440px-Army-2015_2.png 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="540" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Army-2015_2.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Patriot_Park" title="Patriot Park">Military-patriotic recreation park of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg/220px-%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg/330px-%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg/440px-%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1880" data-file-height="1160" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A8%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B8%D0%B5_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%B8%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%89%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B2%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B9_%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%B8_%C2%AB%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA%C2%BB_-_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Members of the <a href="https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D0%91%D0%B5%D1%81%D1%81%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%80%D1%82%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%BF%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BA" class="extiw" title="ru:Бессмертный полк">Immortal regiment</a> carrying portraits of their ancestors who fought in <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Moscow_Victory_Day_Parade" title="2015 Moscow Victory Day Parade">2015 Moscow Victory Day Parade</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Russian military is divided into the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Ground_Forces" title="Russian Ground Forces">Ground Forces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Navy" title="Russian Navy">Navy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Air_Force" title="Russian Air Force">Air Force</a>. There are also three independent arms of service: <a href="/wiki/Strategic_Missile_Troops" class="mw-redirect" title="Strategic Missile Troops">Strategic Missile Troops</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Aerospace_Defence_Forces" title="Russian Aerospace Defence Forces">Aerospace Defence Forces</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Airborne_Troops" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Airborne Troops">Airborne Troops</a>. As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the military comprised over one million active duty personnel, the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_power" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by military power">fifth largest</a> in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-Global_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global-163">&#91;159&#93;</a></sup> Additionally, there are over 2.5 million reservists, with the total number of reserve troops possibly being as high as 20 million.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">&#91;160&#93;</a></sup> It is mandatory for all male citizens aged 18–27 to be <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">drafted</a> for a year of service in Armed Forces.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia has <a href="/wiki/Russia_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction" title="Russia and weapons of mass destruction">the largest stockpile of nuclear weapons</a> in the world, the second largest fleet of <a href="/wiki/Ballistic_missile_submarine" title="Ballistic missile submarine">ballistic missile submarines</a>, and the only modern <a href="/wiki/Strategic_bomber" title="Strategic bomber">strategic bomber</a> force outside the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-fas_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fas-38">&#91;34&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">&#91;161&#93;</a></sup> More than 90% of world's 14,000 <a href="/wiki/List_of_states_with_nuclear_weapons" title="List of states with nuclear weapons">nuclear weapons</a> are owned by Russia and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">&#91;162&#93;</a></sup> Russia's <a href="/wiki/Tank" title="Tank">tank</a> force is the largest in the world, while its surface navy and air force are among the largest.
