</p><p>The country has a large and fully indigenous <a href="/wiki/Defense_industry_of_Russia" title="Defense industry of Russia">arms industry</a>, producing most of its own military equipment with only a few types of weapons imported. It has been one of the world's top supplier of arms since 2001, accounting for around 30% of worldwide weapons sales<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">&#91;163&#93;</a></sup> and exporting weapons to about 80 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">&#91;164&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a>, SIPRI, found that Russia was the second biggest exporter of arms in 2010–14, increasing their exports by 37 per cent from the period 2005–2009. In 2010–14, Russia delivered weapons to 56 states and to rebel forces in eastern Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-sipri1_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sipri1-169">&#91;165&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Russian government's official 2014 military budget is about 2.49 trillion <a href="/wiki/Rubles" class="mw-redirect" title="Rubles">rubles</a> (approximately US$69.3 billion), the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">third largest</a> in the world behind the US and China. The official budget is set to rise to 3.03 trillion rubles (approximately US$83.7 billion) in 2015, and 3.36 trillion rubles (approximately US$93.9 billion) in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">&#91;166&#93;</a></sup> However, unofficial estimates put the budget significantly higher, for example the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> (SIPRI) 2013 Military Expenditure Database estimated Russia's military expenditure in 2012 at US$90.749 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">&#91;167&#93;</a></sup> This estimate is an increase of more than US$18 billion on SIPRI's estimate of the Russian military budget for 2011 (US$71.9 billion).<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">&#91;168&#93;</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, Russia's military budget is higher than any other <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> nation.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Political_divisions">Political divisions</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Russia" title="Subdivisions of Russia">Subdivisions of Russia</a></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:592px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_(2014).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg/590px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="590" height="325" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg/885px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg/1180px-Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_%282014%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="282" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_federal_subjects_of_Russia_(2014).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Federal subjects of Russia. Yellow: oblast, green: republic, orange: krai, blue: autonomous okrug, red: federal city, purple: autonomous oblast.</div></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg/220px-Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg/330px-Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg/440px-Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Gorodskaya_Meria_Rostov.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Rostov_City_Hall" title="Rostov City Hall">City Duma building</a> of <a href="/wiki/Rostov-on-Don" title="Rostov-on-Don">Rostov-on-Don</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg/220px-Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg/330px-Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg/440px-Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="449" data-file-height="334" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vladimir_Putin_8_November_2000-1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Akhmad_Kadyrov" title="Akhmad Kadyrov">Akhmad Kadyrov</a>, former rebel and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_the_Chechen_Republic" title="Head of the Chechen Republic">head of the Chechen Republic</a>, 2000</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg/220px-RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg/330px-RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg/440px-RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="622" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RIAN_archive_172139_Dmitry_Medvedev_visits_Kazan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russian President <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Medvedev" title="Dmitry Medvedev">Dmitry Medvedev</a> and President of Tatarstan <a href="/wiki/Mintimer_Shaimiyev" class="mw-redirect" title="Mintimer Shaimiyev">Mintimer Shaimiyev</a> in <a href="/wiki/Kazan" title="Kazan">Kazan</a>, the capital of <a href="/wiki/Tatarstan" title="Tatarstan">Tatarstan</a>, 2011</div></div></div>
<dl><dt>Federal subjects</dt></dl>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia" title="Constitution of Russia">Constitution</a>, the country comprises eighty-five <a href="/wiki/Federal_subjects_of_Russia" title="Federal subjects of Russia">federal subjects</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">&#91;169&#93;</a></sup> including the disputed <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Federal_cities_of_Russia" title="Federal cities of Russia">federal city</a> of <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">&#91;170&#93;</a></sup> In 1993, when the Constitution was adopted, there were eighty-nine federal subjects listed, but later some of them were merged. These subjects have equal representation—two delegates each—in the <a href="/wiki/Federation_Council_(Russia)" title="Federation Council (Russia)">Federation Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">&#91;171&#93;</a></sup> However, they differ in the degree of autonomy they enjoy.
</p>
<ul><li>46 <a href="/wiki/Oblasts_of_Russia" title="Oblasts of Russia">oblasts</a> (provinces): most common type of federal subjects, with locally elected governor and legislature.<sup id="cite_ref-FZ_gub_elect_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FZ_gub_elect-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup></li>
<li>22 <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia" title="Republics of Russia">republics</a>: nominally autonomous; each is tasked with drafting its own constitution, direct-elected<sup id="cite_ref-FZ_gub_elect_176-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FZ_gub_elect-176">&#91;172&#93;</a></sup> head of republic<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">&#91;173&#93;</a></sup> or a similar post, and parliament. Republics are allowed to establish their own official language alongside Russian but are represented by the federal government in international affairs. Republics are meant to be home to specific ethnic minorities.</li>
<li>9 <a href="/wiki/Krais_of_Russia" title="Krais of Russia">krais</a> (territories): essentially the same as oblasts. The "territory" designation is historic, originally given to frontier regions and later also to the administrative divisions that comprised autonomous okrugs or autonomous oblasts.</li>
<li>4 <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_okrugs_of_Russia" title="Autonomous okrugs of Russia">autonomous okrugs</a> (autonomous districts): originally autonomous entities within oblasts and krais created for ethnic minorities, their status was elevated to that of federal subjects in the 1990s. With the exception of <a href="/wiki/Chukotka_Autonomous_Okrug" title="Chukotka Autonomous Okrug">Chukotka Autonomous Okrug</a>, all autonomous okrugs are still administratively subordinated to a krai or an oblast of which they are a part.</li>
<li>1 <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_oblasts_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Autonomous oblasts of Russia">autonomous oblast</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Jewish_Autonomous_Oblast" title="Jewish Autonomous Oblast">Jewish Autonomous Oblast</a>): historically, autonomous oblasts were administrative units subordinated to krais. In 1990, all of them except for the Jewish AO were elevated in status to that of a republic.</li>
<li>3 <a href="/wiki/Federal_cities" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal cities">federal cities</a> (Moscow, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>): major cities that function as separate regions.</li></ul>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Crimea_and_Sevastopol" class="mw-redirect" title="Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol">Political status of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation</a></div>
<dl><dt>Federal districts</dt></dl>
<p>Federal subjects are grouped into eight <a href="/wiki/Federal_districts_of_Russia" title="Federal districts of Russia">federal districts</a>, each administered by an envoy appointed by the President of Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">&#91;174&#93;</a></sup> Unlike the federal subjects, the federal districts are not a subnational level of government, but are a level of administration of the federal government. Federal districts' envoys serve as liaisons between the federal subjects and the federal government and are primarily responsible for overseeing the compliance of the federal subjects with the federal laws.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Russia" title="Geography of Russia">Geography of Russia</a></div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_explorers" title="List of Russian explorers">List of Russian explorers</a></div>

cities</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:442px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg/440px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg.png" decoding="async" width="440" height="206" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg/660px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg/880px-Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1816" data-file-height="850" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Koppen-Geiger_Map_RUS_present.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate types</a> of Russia</div></div></div>
<p>Russia is the <a href="/wiki/Largest_country_in_the_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Largest country in the world">largest country in the world</a>; its total area is 17,075,200 square kilometres (6,592,800&#160;sq&#160;mi).<sup id="cite_ref-General_Information_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-General_Information-179">&#91;175&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-area_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-area-180">&#91;176&#93;</a></sup> This makes it larger than the continents of <a href="/wiki/Oceania" title="Oceania">Oceania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antarctica" title="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>. It lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/41st_parallel_north" title="41st parallel north">41°</a> and <a href="/wiki/82nd_parallel_north" title="82nd parallel north">82° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/19th_meridian_east" title="19th meridian east">19° E</a> and <a href="/wiki/169th_meridian_west" title="169th meridian west">169° W</a>.
</p><p>Russia's territorial expansion was achieved largely in the late 16th century under the Cossack <a href="/wiki/Yermak_Timofeyevich" title="Yermak Timofeyevich">Yermak Timofeyevich</a> during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ivan_the_Terrible" title="Ivan the Terrible">Ivan the Terrible</a>, at a time when competing city-states in the western regions of Russia had banded together to form one country. Yermak mustered an army and pushed eastward where he conquered nearly all the lands once belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Mongol_Empire" title="Mongol Empire">Mongols</a>, defeating their ruler, <a href="/wiki/Kuchum" title="Kuchum">Khan Kuchum</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">&#91;177&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia has a wide natural resource base, including major deposits of timber, petroleum, natural gas, coal, ores and other mineral resources.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Topography">Topography</span></h3>
<p>The two most widely separated points in Russia are about 8,000&#160;km (4,971&#160;mi) apart along a <a href="/wiki/Geodesic" title="Geodesic">geodesic</a> line. These points are: a 60&#160;km (37&#160;mi) long <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Spit" title="Vistula Spit">Vistula Spit</a> the boundary with Poland separating the <a href="/wiki/Gda%C5%84sk_Bay" title="Gdańsk Bay">Gdańsk Bay</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Vistula_Lagoon" title="Vistula Lagoon">Vistula Lagoon</a> and the most southeastern point of the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a>. The points which are farthest separated in <a href="/wiki/Longitude" title="Longitude">longitude</a> are 6,600&#160;km (4,101&#160;mi) apart along a geodesic line. These points are: in the west, the same spit on the boundary with Poland, and in the east, the <a href="/wiki/Big_Diomede_Island" class="mw-redirect" title="Big Diomede Island">Big Diomede Island</a>. The Russian Federation spans 11 <a href="/wiki/Time_zone" title="Time zone">time zones</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG/220px-%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG/330px-%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG/440px-%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%AD%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B1%D1%80%D1%83%D1%81_%D1%81_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B0_%D0%93%D1%83%D0%BC%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%88%D0%B8.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mount_Elbrus" title="Mount Elbrus">Mount Elbrus</a>, a dormant volcano, is the highest point of the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> and Russia and the tenth most prominent peak in the world</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg/220px-Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="145" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg/330px-Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg/440px-Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3332" data-file-height="2200" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Volga_River_P8132394_2200.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Volga_River" title="Volga River">Volga River</a> at <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod_Oblast" title="Nizhny Novgorod Oblast">Nizhny Novgorod</a>. The Volga is the longest river in Europe</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg/220px-Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg/330px-Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg/440px-Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1272" data-file-height="954" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Koryaksky_volcano_Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky_oct-2005.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Koryaksky" title="Koryaksky">Koryaksky</a> volcano towering over <a href="/wiki/Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky" title="Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky">Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula" title="Kamchatka Peninsula">Kamchatka Peninsula</a></div></div></div>
<p>Most of Russia consists of vast stretches of plains that are predominantly <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a> to the south and heavily forested to the north, with <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a> along the northern coast. Russia possesses 10% of the world's <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">&#91;178&#93;</a></sup> Mountain ranges are found along the southern borders, such as the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus_Mountains" title="Caucasus Mountains">Caucasus</a> (containing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Elbrus" title="Mount Elbrus">Mount Elbrus</a>, which at 5,642&#160;m (18,510&#160;ft) is the highest point in both Russia and Europe) and the <a href="/wiki/Altai_Mountains" title="Altai Mountains">Altai</a> (containing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Belukha" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Belukha">Mount Belukha</a>, which at the 4,506&#160;m (14,783&#160;ft) is the highest point of Siberia outside of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Far_East" title="Russian Far East">Russian Far East</a>); and in the eastern parts, such as the <a href="/wiki/Verkhoyansk_Range" title="Verkhoyansk Range">Verkhoyansk Range</a> or the volcanoes of <a href="/wiki/Kamchatka_Peninsula" title="Kamchatka Peninsula">Kamchatka Peninsula</a> (containing <a href="/wiki/Klyuchevskaya_Sopka" title="Klyuchevskaya Sopka">Klyuchevskaya Sopka</a>, which at the 4,750&#160;m (15,584&#160;ft) is the highest <a href="/wiki/Active_volcano" class="mw-redirect" title="Active volcano">active volcano</a> in Eurasia as well as the highest point of <a href="/wiki/Asian_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Asian Russia">Asian Russia</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>, rich in mineral resources, form a north-south range that divides Europe and Asia.
</p><p>Russia has an extensive coastline of over 37,000&#160;km (22,991&#160;mi) along the Arctic and Pacific Oceans, as well as along the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Azov" title="Sea of Azov">Sea of Azov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Caspian_Sea" title="Caspian Sea">Caspian Sea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Barents_Sea" title="Barents Sea">Barents Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_Sea" title="White Sea">White Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kara_Sea" title="Kara Sea">Kara Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laptev_Sea" title="Laptev Sea">Laptev Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Siberian_Sea" title="East Siberian Sea">East Siberian Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chukchi_Sea" title="Chukchi Sea">Chukchi Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bering_Sea" title="Bering Sea">Bering Sea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Okhotsk" title="Sea of Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Sea_of_Japan" title="Sea of Japan">Sea of Japan</a> are linked to Russia via the Arctic and Pacific. Russia's major islands and archipelagos include <a href="/wiki/Novaya_Zemlya" title="Novaya Zemlya">Novaya Zemlya</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Franz_Josef_Land" title="Franz Josef Land">Franz Josef Land</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Severnaya_Zemlya" title="Severnaya Zemlya">Severnaya Zemlya</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_Siberian_Islands" title="New Siberian Islands">New Siberian Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wrangel_Island" title="Wrangel Island">Wrangel Island</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Kuril_Islands" title="Kuril Islands">Kuril Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Diomede_Islands" title="Diomede Islands">Diomede Islands</a> (one controlled by Russia, the other by the United States) are just 3&#160;km (1.9&#160;mi) apart, and <a href="/wiki/Kunashir_Island" title="Kunashir Island">Kunashir Island</a> is about 20&#160;km (12.4&#160;mi) from <a href="/wiki/Hokkaido" title="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>, Japan.
</p><p>Russia has thousands of <a href="/wiki/Rivers_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Rivers in Russia">rivers</a> and inland bodies of water, providing it with one of the world's largest surface water resources. Its lakes contain approximately one-quarter of the world's liquid <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-loc_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loc-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> The largest and most prominent of Russia's bodies of fresh water is <a href="/wiki/Lake_Baikal" title="Lake Baikal">Lake Baikal</a>, the world's deepest, purest, oldest and most capacious fresh water lake.<sup id="cite_ref-baikal_184-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baikal-184">&#91;180&#93;</a></sup> Baikal alone contains over one-fifth of the world's fresh surface water.<sup id="cite_ref-loc_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-loc-183">&#91;179&#93;</a></sup> Other major lakes include <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ladoga" title="Lake Ladoga">Ladoga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Onega" title="Lake Onega">Onega</a>, two of the <a href="/wiki/Largest_lakes_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Largest lakes in Europe">largest lakes in Europe</a>. Russia is second only to Brazil in volume of the <a href="/wiki/Total_renewable_water_resources" class="mw-redirect" title="Total renewable water resources">total renewable water resources</a>. Of the country's 100,000 rivers,<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">&#91;181&#93;</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Volga" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga">Volga</a> is the most famous, not only because it is the <a href="/wiki/Longest_river_in_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Longest river in Europe">longest river in Europe</a>, but also because of its major role in Russian history.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The Siberian rivers <a href="/wiki/Ob_River" title="Ob River">Ob</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yenisey" class="mw-redirect" title="Yenisey">Yenisey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lena_River" title="Lena River">Lena</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amur_River" title="Amur River">Amur</a> are among the <a href="/wiki/Longest_rivers_in_the_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Longest rivers in the world">longest rivers in the world</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Russia" title="Climate of Russia">Climate of Russia</a></div>
<p>The enormous size of Russia and the remoteness of many areas from the sea result in the dominance of the <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a>, which is prevalent in all parts of the country except for the tundra and the extreme southwest. Mountains in the south obstruct the flow of warm air masses from the Indian Ocean, while the plain of the west and north makes the country open to Arctic and Atlantic influences.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-186">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of Northern European Russia and Siberia has a <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">subarctic climate</a>, with extremely severe winters in the inner regions of Northeast Siberia (mostly the <a href="/wiki/Sakha_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Sakha Republic">Sakha Republic</a>, where the Northern <a href="/wiki/Pole_of_Cold" title="Pole of Cold">Pole of Cold</a> is located with the record low temperature of −71.2&#160;°C or −96.2&#160;°F), and more moderate winters elsewhere. Both the strip of land along the shore of the Arctic Ocean and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Arctic_islands" title="Russian Arctic islands">Russian Arctic islands</a> have a <a href="/wiki/Polar_climate" title="Polar climate">polar climate</a>.
</p><p>The coastal part of <a href="/wiki/Krasnodar_Krai" title="Krasnodar Krai">Krasnodar Krai</a> on the Black Sea, most notably in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, possesses a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> with mild and wet winters. In many regions of East Siberia and the Far East, winter is dry compared to summer; other parts of the country experience more even precipitation across seasons. Winter precipitation in most parts of the country usually falls as snow. The region along the Lower Volga and Caspian Sea coast, as well as some areas of southernmost Siberia, possesses a <a href="/wiki/Semi-arid_climate" title="Semi-arid climate">semi-arid climate</a>.
</p>
<div>

<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/330px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg/440px-%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1549" data-file-height="1037" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%B1%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BD%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9_%D1%85%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B1%D0%B5%D1%82.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">Taiga</a> forest, <a href="/wiki/Yugyd_Va_National_Park" title="Yugyd Va National Park">Yugyd Va National Park</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Komi_Republic" title="Komi Republic">Komi Republic</a></div></div></div>
<p>Throughout much of the territory there are only two distinct seasons—winter and summer—as spring and autumn are usually brief periods of change between extremely low and extremely high temperatures.<sup id="cite_ref-congress_186-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-congress-186">&#91;182&#93;</a></sup> The coldest month is January (February on the coastline); the warmest is usually July. Great ranges of temperature are typical. In winter, temperatures get colder both from south to north and from west to east. Summers can be quite hot, even in Siberia.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">&#91;185&#93;</a></sup> The continental interiors are the driest areas.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/List_of_ecoregions_in_Russia" title="List of ecoregions in Russia">List of ecoregions in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_mammals_of_Russia" title="List of mammals of Russia">List of mammals of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Russia" title="List of birds of Russia">List of birds of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_freshwater_fish_of_Russia" title="List of freshwater fish of Russia">List of freshwater fish of Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Russia" title="Wildlife of Russia">Wildlife of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Medved_mzoo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Medved_mzoo.jpg/170px-Medved_mzoo.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Medved_mzoo.jpg/255px-Medved_mzoo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Medved_mzoo.jpg/340px-Medved_mzoo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="480" data-file-height="640" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Medved_mzoo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Brown_bear" title="Brown bear">brown bear</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Russian_Bear" title="Russian Bear">popular symbol of Russia</a>, particularly in the West.</div></div></div>
<p>From north to south the <a href="/wiki/East_European_Plain" title="East European Plain">East European Plain</a>, also known as Russian Plain, is clad sequentially in Arctic <a href="/wiki/Tundra" title="Tundra">tundra</a>, coniferous forest (<a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a>), <a href="/wiki/Mixed_and_broad-leaf_forests" class="mw-redirect" title="Mixed and broad-leaf forests">mixed and broad-leaf forests</a>, grassland (<a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppe</a>), and semi-desert (fringing the Caspian Sea), as the changes in vegetation reflect the changes in climate. Siberia supports a similar sequence but is largely taiga. Russia has the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Forest_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Forest reserves">forest reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-fao.org_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao.org-190">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup> known as "the lungs of Europe",<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> second only to the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazon Rainforest</a> in the amount of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> it absorbs.
</p><p>There are 266 mammal species and 780 bird species in Russia. A total of 415 animal species have been included in the <a href="/wiki/Red_Data_Book_of_the_Russian_Federation" title="Red Data Book of the Russian Federation">Red Data Book of the Russian Federation</a> as of 1997 and are now protected.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> There are 28 UNESCO <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Sites_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="World Heritage Sites in Russia">World Heritage Sites in Russia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup> 40 UNESCO <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosphere reserve">biosphere reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> 41 <a href="/wiki/National_parks_of_Russia" title="National parks of Russia">national parks</a> and 101 <a href="/wiki/Zapovednik" title="Zapovednik">nature reserves</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Russia" title="Economy of Russia">Economy of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow-City_(36211143494).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg/220px-Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg/330px-Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg/440px-Moscow-City_%2836211143494%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3753" data-file-height="2813" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow-City_(36211143494).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">Moscow International Business Center</a></div></div></div>
<p>Russia has an upper-middle income <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a><sup id="cite_ref-https&#58;//datahelpdesk.worldbank.org_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-https://datahelpdesk.worldbank.org-195">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> with enormous natural resources, particularly <a href="/wiki/Russian_oil_industry" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian oil industry">oil</a> and natural gas. It has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">12th largest</a> economy in the world by nominal GDP and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(PPP)" title="List of countries by GDP (PPP)">6th largest</a> by <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> (PPP). Since the turn of the 21st century, higher domestic consumption and greater political stability have bolstered economic growth in Russia. The country ended 2008 with its ninth straight year of growth, but growth has slowed with the decline in the price of oil and gas. Real GDP per capita, PPP (current international) was 19,840 in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-wdi_196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wdi-196">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> Growth was primarily driven by non-traded services and goods for the domestic market, as opposed to oil or mineral extraction and exports.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> The average nominal salary in Russia was $967 per month in early 2013, up from $80 in 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> In May 2016 the average nominal monthly wages fell below $450 per month,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> and tax on the income of individuals is payable at the rate of 13% on most incomes.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> Approximately 19.2 million of Russians lived <a href="/wiki/Poverty_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Poverty by country">below the national poverty line</a> in 2016,<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;197&#93;</a></sup> significantly up from 16.1 million in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-worldbank_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-worldbank-115">&#91;111&#93;</a></sup> Unemployment in Russia was 5.4% in 2014, down from about 12.4% in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> Officially, about 20–25% of the Russian population is categorized as middle class; however some economists and sociologists think this figure is inflated and the real fraction is about 7%.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> After the United States, the European Union and other countries imposed <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Ukrainian_crisis" title="International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis">economic sanctions</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">annexation of Crimea</a> and a collapse in oil prices, the proportion of middle-class could decrease drastically.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/220px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/330px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg/440px-HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="961" data-file-height="624" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:HDP_PPP_per_capita_Russia.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russia's GDP by purchasing power parity (PPP) in 1991-2019 (in <a href="/wiki/International_dollars" class="mw-redirect" title="International dollars">international dollars</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Oil, natural gas, metals, and timber account for more than 80% of Russian exports abroad.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup> Since 2003, the exports of natural resources started decreasing in economic importance as the internal market strengthened considerably. As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> the oil-and-gas sector accounted for 16% of <a href="/wiki/GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="GDP">GDP</a>, 52% of federal budget revenues and over 80% of total exports.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EIA_207-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EIA-207">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> Oil export earnings allowed Russia to increase its foreign reserves from $12&#160;billion in 1999 to $597.3&#160;billion on 1 August 2008. As of April&#160;2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, foreign reserves in Russia fell to US$332 Billion.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup> The macroeconomic policy under Finance Minister <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Kudrin" title="Alexei Kudrin">Alexei Kudrin</a> was prudent and sound, with excess income being stored in the <a href="/wiki/Stabilization_Fund_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Stabilization Fund of Russia">Stabilization Fund of Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-euromoney_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euromoney-210">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> In 2006, Russia repaid most of its formerly massive debts,<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> leaving it with <a href="/wiki/Foreign_debt_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign debt by country">one of the lowest foreign debts among major economies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> The Stabilization Fund helped Russia to come out of the <a href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Late-2000s recession">global financial crisis</a> in a much better state than many experts had expected.<sup id="cite_ref-euromoney_210-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-euromoney-210">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>A simpler, more streamlined tax code adopted in 2001 reduced the tax burden on people and dramatically increased state revenue.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> Russia has a <a href="/wiki/Flat_tax" title="Flat tax">flat tax</a> rate of 13%. This ranks it as the country with the second most attractive personal tax system for single managers in the world after the United Arab Emirates.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P." title="Bloomberg L.P.">Bloomberg</a>, Russia is considered well ahead of most other resource-rich countries in its economic development, with a long tradition of education, science, and industry.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> The country has a higher proportion of higher education graduates than any other country in Eurasia.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/220px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/330px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg/440px-Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="434" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_and_China_sign_major_gas_deal.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>On 21 May 2014, Russia and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a> signed a $400 billion gas deal. Starting 2019 Russia plans to provide <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">natural gas</a> to China for the next 30 years.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg/200px-Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="134" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg/300px-Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg/400px-Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1199" data-file-height="806" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_Superjet_100_prototype.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Superjet_100" title="Sukhoi Superjet 100">Sukhoi Superjet 100</a> is Russia's most recent civilian aviation product.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1,_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_(00).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG/200px-%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG/300px-%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG/400px-%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1%2C_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_%2800%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9E%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%B2%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%B9_%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BB%D1%8C_%D0%9C%D0%A7%D0%A1,_%D0%A1%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%BA%D1%82-%D0%9F%D0%B5%D1%82%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B1%D1%83%D1%80%D0%B3_(00).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/GAZ_Volga" title="GAZ Volga">GAZ Volga</a> used by the <a href="/wiki/Police_of_Russia" title="Police of Russia">Police of Russia</a></div></div></div>
<p>The economic development of the country has been uneven geographically with the Moscow region contributing a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_federal_subjects_by_GRP" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Russian federal subjects by GRP">very large share</a> of the country's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Inequality of household income and wealth has also been noted, with <a href="/wiki/Credit_Suisse" title="Credit Suisse">Credit Suisse</a> finding Russian wealth distribution so much more extreme than other countries studied it "deserves to be placed in a separate category."<sup id="cite_ref-pbs_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pbs-218">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CSRIGWR_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSRIGWR-219">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup>
Another problem is modernisation of infrastructure, ageing and inadequate after years of being neglected in the 1990s; the government has said $1&#160;trillion will be invested in development of infrastructure by 2020.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> In December 2011, Russia was approved as a member of the World Trade Organisation after 18 years of dialogue, allowing it a greater access to overseas markets.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> Some analysts estimate that WTO membership could bring the Russian economy a bounce of up to 3% annually.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> Russia ranks as the second-most corrupt country in Europe (after Ukraine), according to the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>. The Norwegian-Russian Chamber of Commerce also states that "[c]orruption is one of the biggest problems both Russian and international companies have to deal with."<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">Corruption in Russia</a> is perceived as a significant problem<sup id="cite_ref-CPI2015_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CPI2015-224">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> impacting all aspects of life, including <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Russia" title="Government of Russia">public administration</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Suhara_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Suhara-225">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Russia" title="Law enforcement in Russia">law enforcement</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">healthcare</a><sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">education</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> The phenomenon of corruption is strongly established in the historical model of public governance in Russia and attributed to general weakness of <a href="/wiki/Rule_of_law" title="Rule of law">rule of law</a> in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-Suhara_225-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Suhara-225">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a>, Russia ranked 138th with a score of 28 out of 100 in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The Russian central bank announced plans in 2013 to free float the Russian ruble in 2015. According to a stress test conducted by the central bank Russian financial system would be able to handle a currency decline of 25%–30% without major central bank interference. However, the Russian economy began stagnating in late 2013 and in combination with the <a href="/wiki/War_in_Donbass" title="War in Donbass">War in Donbass</a> is in danger of entering stagflation, slow growth and high inflation. The recent decline in the Russian ruble has increased the costs for Russian companies to make interest payments on debt issued in U.S. dollar or other foreign currencies that have strengthened against the ruble; thus it costs Russian companies more of their ruble-denominated revenue to repay their debt holders in dollars or other foreign currencies.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> As of March&#160;2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the ruble was devalued more than 50 percent since July 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-Nasdaq_Mar2016_232-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nasdaq_Mar2016-232">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup> Moreover, after bringing inflation down to 3.6% in 2012, the lowest rate since gaining independence from the Soviet Union, inflation in Russia jumped to nearly 7.5% in 2014, causing the central bank to increase its lending rate to 8% from 5.5% in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> In an October 2014 article in <i>Bloomberg Business Week</i>, it was reported that Russia had significantly started shifting its economy towards China in response to increasing financial tensions following its annexation of Crimea and subsequent Western economic sanctions.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Russia" title="Energy in Russia">Energy in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Russia" title="Nuclear power in Russia">Nuclear power in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russia_in_the_European_energy_sector" title="Russia in the European energy sector">Russia in the European energy sector</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/220px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" decoding="async" width="220" height="282" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/330px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif/440px-RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif 2x" data-file-width="590" data-file-height="757" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:RF_NG_pipestoEU.gif" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Russia is a key <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">oil</a> and <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">gas</a> supplier to much of Europe.</div></div></div>
<p>In recent years, Russia has frequently been described in the media as an <a href="/wiki/Energy_superpower" title="Energy superpower">energy superpower</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup> The country has the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas reserves">natural gas reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> the 8th largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> and the second largest <a href="/wiki/Coal_reserves" class="mw-redirect" title="Coal reserves">coal reserves</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> Russia is the world's leading <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_exporter" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas exporter">natural gas exporter</a><sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> and second largest <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural gas producer">natural gas producer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-cia-gas_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-gas-37">&#91;33&#93;</a></sup> while also the largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_exporter" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil exporter">oil exporter</a> and the largest <a href="/wiki/Oil_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil producer">oil producer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-IEA-Oil_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IEA-Oil-36">&#91;32&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia is the third largest <a href="/wiki/Electricity_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Electricity producer">electricity producer</a> in the world<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> and the 5th largest <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_producer" class="mw-redirect" title="Renewable energy producer">renewable energy producer</a>, the latter because of the well-developed <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectricity</a> production in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup> Large cascades of <a href="/wiki/Hydropower_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Hydropower plant">hydropower plants</a> are built in European Russia along big rivers like the Volga. The Asian part of Russia also features a number of major hydropower stations; however, the gigantic hydroelectric potential of Siberia and the Russian Far East largely remains unexploited.
</p><p>Russia was the first country to develop civilian nuclear power and to construct the world's <a href="/wiki/First_nuclear_power_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="First nuclear power plant">first nuclear power plant</a>. Currently the country is the 4th largest <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_by_country" title="Nuclear power by country">nuclear energy producer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> with all <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_Russia" title="Nuclear power in Russia">nuclear power in Russia</a> being managed by <a href="/wiki/Rosatom" title="Rosatom">Rosatom</a> State Corporation. The sector is rapidly developing, with an aim of increasing the total share of nuclear energy from current 16.9% to 23% by 2020. The Russian government plans to allocate 127&#160;billion rubles ($5.42&#160;billion) to a federal program dedicated to the next generation of nuclear energy technology. About 1&#160;trillion rubles ($42.7&#160;billion) is to be allocated from the federal budget to nuclear power and industry development before 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2014 on a two-day trip to <a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, President Putin signed a deal on behalf of Gazprom for the Russian energy giant to <a href="/wiki/Yakutia%E2%80%93Khabarovsk%E2%80%93Vladivostok_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Yakutia–Khabarovsk–Vladivostok pipeline">supply China</a> with 38 billion cubic meters of natural gas per year. Construction of a pipeline to facilitate the deal was agreed whereby Russia would contribute $55bn to the cost, and China $22bn, in what Putin described as "the world's biggest construction project for the next four years." The natural gas would begin to flow sometime between 2018 and 2020 and would continue for 30 years at an ultimate cost to China of $400bn.<sup id="cite_ref-CNPCdeal_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CNPCdeal-247">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="External_trade_and_investment">External trade and investment</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_(14795521387).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg/220px-McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg/330px-McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg/440px-McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_%2814795521387%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3146" data-file-height="1887" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:McDonalds_Moscow_Pushkinskaya_2013_(14795521387).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/McDonald%27s" title="McDonald&#39;s">McDonald's</a> restaurant in Moscow</div></div></div>
<table class="box-Expand_section plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><a href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg" class="image"><img alt="[icon]" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="14" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="44" data-file-height="31" /></a></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs expansion</b>. <small>You can help by <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">adding to it</a>.</small>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">January 2019</span>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_largest_trading_partners_of_Russia" title="List of the largest trading partners of Russia">List of the largest trading partners of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_oil_exports" title="List of countries by oil exports">List of countries by oil exports</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_natural_gas_exports" title="List of countries by natural gas exports">List of countries by natural gas exports</a></div>
<p>Russia recorded a trade surplus of US$130.1 billion in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> Russia's Trade Balance recorded a surplus of US$19.7 billion in October 2018, compared with a surplus of US$10.1 billion in October 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> is Russia's largest trading partner and Russia is the EU's fourth largest trading partner. 75% of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI) stocks in Russia come from the EU.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Reuters reported that <a href="/wiki/List_of_companies_of_the_United_States_by_state" title="List of companies of the United States by state">U.S. companies</a> "generated more than $90 billion in revenue from Russia in 2017."<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> According to the AALEP, "there are almost 3,000 American companies in Russia, and the U.S. is also the leader in terms of foreign companies in <a href="/wiki/Special_Economic_Zones_in_Russia" title="Special Economic Zones in Russia">Special Economic Zones</a>, with 11 projects."<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Russia" title="Agriculture in Russia">Agriculture in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_in_Russia" title="Fishing industry in Russia">Fishing industry in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="2254" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Shishkin_-_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D0%B6%D1%8C_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Rye Fields</i>, by <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Shishkin" title="Ivan Shishkin">Ivan Shishkin</a>. Russia is the world's top producer of <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buckwheat" title="Buckwheat">buckwheat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Oats" class="mw-redirect" title="Oats">oats</a>, and one of the largest producers and exporters of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed" title="Sunflower seed">sunflower seed</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Russia's <a href="/wiki/Total_area_of_cultivated_land" class="mw-redirect" title="Total area of cultivated land">total area of cultivated land</a> is estimated at 1,237,294 square kilometres (477,722&#160;sq&#160;mi), the fourth largest in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> From 1999 to 2009, Russia's agriculture grew steadily,<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> and the country turned from a grain importer to the third largest grain exporter after the EU and the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> The production of meat has grown from 6,813,000 tonnes in 1999 to 9,331,000 tonnes in 2008, and continues to grow.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>This restoration of agriculture was supported by a credit policy of the government, helping both individual farmers and large privatized corporate farms that once were Soviet <a href="/wiki/Kolkhoz" title="Kolkhoz">kolkhozes</a> and which still own the significant share of agricultural land.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup> While large farms concentrate mainly on grain production and <a href="/wiki/Husbandry" class="mw-redirect" title="Husbandry">husbandry</a> products, small private <a href="/wiki/Household_plot" title="Household plot">household plots</a> produce most of the country's potatoes, vegetables and fruits.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since Russia borders three oceans (the Atlantic, Arctic, and Pacific), Russian fishing fleets are a major <a href="/wiki/Fishing_industry_by_country" title="Fishing industry by country">world fish supplier</a>. Russia captured 3,191,068 tons of fish in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> Both exports and imports of fish and sea products grew significantly in recent years, reaching $2,415 and $2,036 million, respectively, in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Sprawling from the Baltic Sea to the Pacific Ocean, Russia has more than a fifth of the world's forests, which makes it the largest forest country in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-fao.org_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fao.org-190">&#91;186&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FAO_2010_261-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FAO_2010-261">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> However, according to a 2012 study by the <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization_of_the_United_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations">Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations</a> and the Government of the Russian Federation,<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup> the considerable potential of Russian forests is underutilized and Russia's share of the global trade in forest products is less than four percent.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Russia" title="Transport in Russia">Transport in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_rail_transport_in_Russia" title="History of rail transport in Russia">History of rail transport in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Russia" title="Rail transport in Russia">Rail transport in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg/170px-TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="232" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg/255px-TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg/340px-TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1464" data-file-height="1995" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:TransSiberianRailwayAtKm9288.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The marker for kilometre 9288 at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> in <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a></div></div></div>
<p>Railway transport in Russia is mostly under the control of the state-run <a href="/wiki/Russian_Railways" title="Russian Railways">Russian Railways</a> monopoly. The company accounts for over 3.6% of Russia's GDP and handles 39% of the total freight traffic (including pipelines) and more than 42% of passenger traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-rzd_264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rzd-264">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> The total length of common-used railway tracks exceeds 85,500&#160;km (53,127&#160;mi),<sup id="cite_ref-rzd_264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rzd-264">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> second only to the United States. Over 44,000&#160;km (27,340&#160;mi) of tracks are <a href="/wiki/Railway_electrification_system" title="Railway electrification system">electrified</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> which is the largest number in the world, and additionally there are more than 30,000&#160;km (18,641&#160;mi) of industrial non-common carrier lines. Railways in Russia, unlike in the most of the world, use <a href="/wiki/Broad_gauge" class="mw-redirect" title="Broad gauge">broad gauge</a> of <span class="nowrap">1,520&#160;mm</span> (<span class="nowrap">4&#160;ft&#160;<span class="frac">11<span class="visualhide">&#160;</span><sup>27</sup>&#8260;<sub>32</sub></span>&#160;in</span>), with the exception of 957&#160;km (595&#160;mi) on <a href="/wiki/Sakhalin" title="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a> island using narrow gauge of <span class="nowrap">1,067&#160;mm</span> (<span class="nowrap">3&#160;ft&#160;6&#160;in</span>). The most renowned railway in Russia is <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian</a> (<i>Transsib</i>), spanning a record seven time zones and serving the longest single continuous services in the world, Moscow-<a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a> (9,259&#160;km (5,753&#160;mi)), Moscow–<a href="/wiki/Pyongyang" title="Pyongyang">Pyongyang</a> (10,267&#160;km (6,380&#160;mi))<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>–Vladivostok (11,085&#160;km (6,888&#160;mi)).<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2006<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> Russia had <a href="/wiki/Roads_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Roads by country">933,000&#160;km of roads</a>, of which 755,000 were paved.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup> Some of these make up the <a href="/wiki/Russian_federal_motorway_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian federal motorway system">Russian federal motorway system</a>. With a large land area the road density is the lowest of all the <a href="/wiki/G8" class="mw-redirect" title="G8">G8</a> and <a href="/wiki/BRIC" title="BRIC">BRIC</a> countries.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Much of Russia's inland waterways, which <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_waterways_length" title="List of countries by waterways length">total 102,000&#160;km (63,380&#160;mi)</a>, are made up of natural rivers or lakes. In the European part of the country the network of channels connects the basins of major rivers. Russia's capital, Moscow, is sometimes called "the port of the five seas", because of its waterway connections to the Baltic, <a href="/wiki/White_Sea" title="White Sea">White</a>, Caspian, <a href="/wiki/Azov_Sea" class="mw-redirect" title="Azov Sea">Azov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Seas</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yamal_2009.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Yamal_2009.JPG/220px-Yamal_2009.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Yamal_2009.JPG/330px-Yamal_2009.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Yamal_2009.JPG/440px-Yamal_2009.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3008" data-file-height="2000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Yamal_2009.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Yamal_(icebreaker)" title="Yamal (icebreaker)">Yamal</a></i>, one of Russia's <a href="/wiki/Nuclear-powered_icebreaker" title="Nuclear-powered icebreaker">nuclear-powered icebreakers</a><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Major sea ports of Russia include <a href="/wiki/Rostov-on-Don" title="Rostov-on-Don">Rostov-on-Don</a> on the Azov Sea, <a href="/wiki/Novorossiysk" title="Novorossiysk">Novorossiysk</a> on the Black Sea, <a href="/wiki/Astrakhan" title="Astrakhan">Astrakhan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Makhachkala" title="Makhachkala">Makhachkala</a> on the Caspian, <a href="/wiki/Kaliningrad" title="Kaliningrad">Kaliningrad</a> and St Petersburg on the Baltic, <a href="/wiki/Arkhangelsk" title="Arkhangelsk">Arkhangelsk</a> on the White Sea, <a href="/wiki/Murmansk" title="Murmansk">Murmansk</a> on the Barents Sea, <a href="/wiki/Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky" title="Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky">Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladivostok" title="Vladivostok">Vladivostok</a> on the Pacific Ocean. In 2008 the country owned 1,448 <a href="/wiki/Merchant_marine_by_country" class="mw-redirect" title="Merchant marine by country">merchant marine</a> ships. The world's only fleet of <a href="/wiki/Nuclear-powered_icebreaker" title="Nuclear-powered icebreaker">nuclear-powered icebreakers</a> advances the economic exploitation of the Arctic <a href="/wiki/Continental_shelf_of_Russia" title="Continental shelf of Russia">continental shelf of Russia</a> and the development of sea trade through the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Sea_Route" title="Northern Sea Route">Northern Sea Route</a> between Europe and East Asia.
</p><p>By <a href="/wiki/Total_length_of_pipelines" class="mw-redirect" title="Total length of pipelines">total length of pipelines</a> Russia is second only to the United States.
