Currently many new pipeline projects are being realized, including <a href="/wiki/Nord_Stream" title="Nord Stream">Nord Stream</a> and <a href="/wiki/South_Stream" title="South Stream">South Stream</a> natural gas pipelines to Europe, and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Siberia_%E2%80%93_Pacific_Ocean_oil_pipeline" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Siberia – Pacific Ocean oil pipeline">Eastern Siberia – Pacific Ocean oil pipeline</a> (ESPO) to the Russian Far East and China.
</p><p>Russia has 1,216 airports,<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> the busiest being <a href="/wiki/Sheremetyevo" class="mw-redirect" title="Sheremetyevo">Sheremetyevo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Domodedovo_International_Airport" class="mw-redirect" title="Domodedovo International Airport">Domodedovo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vnukovo" class="mw-redirect" title="Vnukovo">Vnukovo</a> in Moscow, and <a href="/wiki/Pulkovo_Airport" title="Pulkovo Airport">Pulkovo</a> in St. Petersburg.
</p><p>Typically, major Russian cities have well-developed systems of public transport, with the most common varieties of exploited vehicles being bus, <a href="/wiki/Trolleybus" title="Trolleybus">trolleybus</a> and tram. Seven Russian cities, namely <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Metro" title="Moscow Metro">Moscow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_Metro" title="Saint Petersburg Metro">Saint Petersburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod_Metro" title="Nizhny Novgorod Metro">Nizhny Novgorod</a>, <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk_Metro" title="Novosibirsk Metro">Novosibirsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samara_Metro" title="Samara Metro">Samara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg_Metro" title="Yekaterinburg Metro">Yekaterinburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Metro" title="Kazan Metro">Kazan</a>, have underground metros, while <a href="/wiki/Volgograd" title="Volgograd">Volgograd</a> features a <a href="/wiki/Volgograd_Metrotram" title="Volgograd Metrotram">metrotram</a>. The total length of metros in Russia is 465.4 kilometres (289.2&#160;mi). <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Metro" title="Moscow Metro">Moscow Metro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_Metro" title="Saint Petersburg Metro">Saint Petersburg Metro</a> are the oldest in Russia, opened in 1935 and 1955 respectively. These two are among the fastest and <a href="/wiki/Busiest_metro_systems" class="mw-redirect" title="Busiest metro systems">busiest metro systems</a> in the world, and some of them are famous for rich decorations and unique designs of their stations, which is a common tradition in Russian metros and railways.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div style="width:52px"><a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399" /></a></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1" title="Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.<br /><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Russia%22">"Russia"</a>&#160;–&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Russia%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Russia%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Russia%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Russia%22">scholar</a>&#160;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Russia%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span>  <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Russian_inventions_and_technology_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records">Timeline of Russian inventions and technology records</a>, <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Russia" title="Science and technology in Russia">Science and technology in Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_scientists" title="List of Russian scientists">List of Russian scientists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_inventors" title="List of Russian inventors">List of Russian inventors</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/170px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="228" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/255px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg/340px-M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_%281787%2C_RAN%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="597" data-file-height="800" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:M.V._Lomonosov_by_L.Miropolskiy_after_G.C.Prenner_(1787,_RAN).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> (1711-1765), <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymath</a> scientist, inventor, poet and artist</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg/170px-Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="239" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg/255px-Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg/340px-Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1135" data-file-height="1599" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ivan_Pavlov_NLM3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ivan_Pavlov" title="Ivan Pavlov">Ivan Pavlov</a> (1849–1936), physiologist, Nobel Prize laureate in 1904</div></div></div>
<p>Science and technology in Russia blossomed since the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, when <a href="/wiki/Peter_the_Great" title="Peter the Great">Peter the Great</a> founded the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Sciences" title="Russian Academy of Sciences">Russian Academy of Sciences</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_State_University" title="Saint Petersburg State University">Saint Petersburg State University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Polymath" title="Polymath">polymath</a> <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a>, paving the way for a strong native tradition in learning and innovation. In the 19th and 20th centuries the country produced a large number of notable scientists and inventors.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_physics_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian physics school">Russian physics school</a> began with Lomonosov who proposed the law of conservation of matter preceding the <a href="/wiki/Energy_conservation_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Energy conservation law">energy conservation law</a>. Russian discoveries and inventions in physics include the <a href="/wiki/Electric_arc" title="Electric arc">electric arc</a>, electrodynamical <a href="/wiki/Lenz%27s_law" title="Lenz&#39;s law">Lenz's law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Space_groups" class="mw-redirect" title="Space groups">space groups</a> of <a href="/wiki/Crystal" title="Crystal">crystals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Photoelectric_cell" class="mw-redirect" title="Photoelectric cell">photoelectric cell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Superfluidity" title="Superfluidity">superfluidity</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cherenkov_radiation" title="Cherenkov radiation">Cherenkov radiation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electron_paramagnetic_resonance" title="Electron paramagnetic resonance">electron paramagnetic resonance</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heterotransistor" class="mw-redirect" title="Heterotransistor">heterotransistors</a> and <a href="/wiki/3D_holography" class="mw-redirect" title="3D holography">3D holography</a>. <a href="/wiki/Laser" title="Laser">Lasers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maser" title="Maser">masers</a> were co-invented by <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Basov" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolai Basov">Nikolai Basov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Prokhorov" title="Alexander Prokhorov">Alexander Prokhorov</a>, while the idea of <a href="/wiki/Tokamak" title="Tokamak">tokamak</a> for controlled <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_fusion" title="Nuclear fusion">nuclear fusion</a> was introduced by <a href="/wiki/Igor_Tamm" title="Igor Tamm">Igor Tamm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Sakharov" title="Andrei Sakharov">Andrei Sakharov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lev_Artsimovich" title="Lev Artsimovich">Lev Artsimovich</a>, leading eventually the modern international <a href="/wiki/ITER" title="ITER">ITER</a> project, where Russia is a party.
</p><p>Since the time of <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Lobachevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Lobachevsky">Nikolay Lobachevsky</a> (the "<a href="/wiki/Copernicus" class="mw-redirect" title="Copernicus">Copernicus</a> of <a href="/wiki/Geometry" title="Geometry">Geometry</a>" who pioneered the <a href="/wiki/Non-Euclidean_geometry" title="Non-Euclidean geometry">non-Euclidean geometry</a>) and a prominent tutor <a href="/wiki/Pafnuty_Chebyshev" title="Pafnuty Chebyshev">Pafnuty Chebyshev</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_mathematical_school" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian mathematical school">Russian mathematical school</a> became one of the most influential in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> Chebyshev's students included <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov" title="Aleksandr Lyapunov">Aleksandr Lyapunov</a>, who founded the modern <a href="/wiki/Stability_theory" title="Stability theory">stability theory</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Markov" title="Andrey Markov">Andrey Markov</a> who invented the <a href="/wiki/Markov_chain" title="Markov chain">Markov chains</a>. In the 20th century Soviet mathematicians, such as <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Kolmogorov" title="Andrey Kolmogorov">Andrey Kolmogorov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Israel_Gelfand" title="Israel Gelfand">Israel Gelfand</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Sobolev" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Sobolev">Sergey Sobolev</a>, made major contributions to various areas of mathematics. Nine Soviet/Russian mathematicians were awarded with the <a href="/wiki/Fields_Medal" title="Fields Medal">Fields Medal</a>, a most prestigious award in mathematics. Recently <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Perelman" title="Grigori Perelman">Grigori Perelman</a> was offered the first ever Clay <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Prize_Problems" title="Millennium Prize Problems">Millennium Prize Problems</a> Award for his final proof of the <a href="/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture" title="Poincaré conjecture">Poincaré conjecture</a> in 2002.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_chemist" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian chemist">Russian chemist</a> <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Mendeleev" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Mendeleev">Dmitry Mendeleev</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">Periodic table</a>, the main framework of modern <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>. <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Butlerov" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Butlerov">Aleksandr Butlerov</a> was one of the creators of the theory of <a href="/wiki/Chemical_structure" title="Chemical structure">chemical structure</a>, playing a central role in <a href="/wiki/Organic_chemistry" title="Organic chemistry">organic chemistry</a>. <a href="/wiki/Russian_biologists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian biologists">Russian biologists</a> include <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Ivanovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Ivanovsky">Dmitry Ivanovsky</a> who discovered viruses, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Pavlov" title="Ivan Pavlov">Ivan Pavlov</a> who was the first to experiment with the <a href="/wiki/Classical_conditioning" title="Classical conditioning">classical conditioning</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Mechnikov" class="mw-redirect" title="Ilya Mechnikov">Ilya Mechnikov</a> who was a pioneer researcher of the <a href="/wiki/Immune_system" title="Immune system">immune system</a> and <a href="/wiki/Probiotics" class="mw-redirect" title="Probiotics">probiotics</a>.
</p><p>Many Russian scientists and inventors were <a href="/wiki/%C3%89migr%C3%A9s" class="mw-redirect" title="Émigrés">émigrés</a>, like <a href="/wiki/Igor_Sikorsky" title="Igor Sikorsky">Igor Sikorsky</a>, who built the first <a href="/wiki/Airliner" title="Airliner">airliners</a> and modern-type helicopters; <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Zworykin" class="mw-redirect" title="Vladimir Zworykin">Vladimir Zworykin</a>, often called the father of television; chemist <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Prigogine" title="Ilya Prigogine">Ilya Prigogine</a>, noted for his work on <a href="/wiki/Dissipative_structures" class="mw-redirect" title="Dissipative structures">dissipative structures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Complex_systems" class="mw-redirect" title="Complex systems">complex systems</a>; Nobel Prize-winning economists <a href="/wiki/Simon_Kuznets" title="Simon Kuznets">Simon Kuznets</a> and <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Leontief" title="Wassily Leontief">Wassily Leontief</a>; physicist <a href="/wiki/Georgiy_Gamov" class="mw-redirect" title="Georgiy Gamov">Georgiy Gamov</a> (an author of the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang" title="Big Bang">Big Bang</a> theory) and social scientist <a href="/wiki/Pitirim_Sorokin" title="Pitirim Sorokin">Pitirim Sorokin</a>. Many foreigners worked in Russia for a long time, like <a href="/wiki/Leonard_Euler" class="mw-redirect" title="Leonard Euler">Leonard Euler</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Nobel" title="Alfred Nobel">Alfred Nobel</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_inventions" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian inventions">Russian inventions</a> include <a href="/wiki/Arc_welding" title="Arc welding">arc welding</a> by <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Benardos" title="Nikolay Benardos">Nikolay Benardos</a>, further developed by <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Slavyanov" title="Nikolay Slavyanov">Nikolay Slavyanov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Khrenov" title="Konstantin Khrenov">Konstantin Khrenov</a> and other Russian engineers. <a href="/wiki/Gleb_Kotelnikov" title="Gleb Kotelnikov">Gleb Kotelnikov</a> invented the <a href="/wiki/Knapsack_parachute" class="mw-redirect" title="Knapsack parachute">knapsack parachute</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Evgeniy_Chertovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Evgeniy Chertovsky">Evgeniy Chertovsky</a> introduced the <a href="/wiki/Pressure_suit" title="Pressure suit">pressure suit</a>. <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Lodygin" title="Alexander Lodygin">Alexander Lodygin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pavel_Yablochkov" title="Pavel Yablochkov">Pavel Yablochkov</a> were pioneers of <a href="/wiki/Electric_lighting" class="mw-redirect" title="Electric lighting">electric lighting</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Dolivo-Dobrovolsky" title="Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky">Mikhail Dolivo-Dobrovolsky</a> introduced the first <a href="/wiki/Three-phase_electric_power" title="Three-phase electric power">three-phase electric power</a> systems, widely used today. <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Vasiljevich_Lebedev" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergei Vasiljevich Lebedev">Sergei Lebedev</a> invented the first commercially viable and mass-produced type of <a href="/wiki/Synthetic_rubber" title="Synthetic rubber">synthetic rubber</a>. The first <a href="/wiki/Ternary_computer" title="Ternary computer">ternary computer</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Setun" title="Setun">Setun</a></i>, was developed by <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Brusentsov" title="Nikolay Brusentsov">Nikolay Brusentsov</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg/220px-Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg/330px-Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg/440px-Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1023" data-file-height="683" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Sukhoi_T-50_Maksimov.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-57" title="Sukhoi Su-57">Sukhoi Su-57</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Fifth-generation_jet_fighter" title="Fifth-generation jet fighter">fifth-generation jet fighter</a> being developed for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Air_Force" title="Russian Air Force">Russian Air Force</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/220px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/330px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg/440px-Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="2010" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mir_on_12_June_1998edit1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> <a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg/170px-Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="265" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg/255px-Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg/340px-Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1927" data-file-height="3000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Soyuz_TMA-2_launch.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Soyuz_TMA-2" title="Soyuz TMA-2">Soyuz TMA-2</a> is launched from <a href="/wiki/Baikonur" title="Baikonur">Baikonur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, carrying one of the first resident crews to the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the 20th century a number of prominent <a href="/wiki/Soviet_aerospace_engineers" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet aerospace engineers">Soviet aerospace engineers</a>, inspired by the fundamental works of <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Yegorovich_Zhukovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Yegorovich Zhukovsky">Nikolai Zhukovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Chaplygin" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergei Chaplygin">Sergei Chaplygin</a> and others, designed many hundreds of models of military and civilian aircraft and founded a number of <i>KBs</i> (<i>Construction Bureaus</i>) that now constitute the bulk of Russian <a href="/wiki/United_Aircraft_Corporation" title="United Aircraft Corporation">United Aircraft Corporation</a>. Famous Russian aircraft include the civilian <a href="/wiki/Tupolev" title="Tupolev">Tu</a>-series, <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi" title="Sukhoi">Su</a> and <a href="/wiki/MiG" class="mw-redirect" title="MiG">MiG</a> fighter aircraft, <a href="/wiki/Kamov" title="Kamov">Ka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mil_Moscow_Helicopter_Plant" title="Mil Moscow Helicopter Plant">Mi</a>-series helicopters; many Russian aircraft models are on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_produced_aircraft" class="mw-redirect" title="List of most produced aircraft">list of most produced aircraft</a> in history.
</p><p>Famous Russian battle tanks include <a href="/wiki/T-34" title="T-34">T34</a>, the most heavily produced tank design of World War&#160;II,<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> and further tanks of T-series, including the most produced tank in history, <a href="/wiki/T-54/55" class="mw-redirect" title="T-54/55">T54/55</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/AK47" class="mw-redirect" title="AK47">AK47</a> and <a href="/wiki/AK-74" title="AK-74">AK74</a> by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Kalashnikov" title="Mikhail Kalashnikov">Mikhail Kalashnikov</a> constitute the most widely used type of <a href="/wiki/Assault_rifle" title="Assault rifle">assault rifle</a> throughout the world—so much so that more AK-type rifles have been manufactured than all other assault rifles combined.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>With all these achievements, however, since the late Soviet era Russia was lagging behind the West in a number of technologies, mostly those related to <a href="/wiki/Energy_conservation" title="Energy conservation">energy conservation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Consumer_goods" class="mw-redirect" title="Consumer goods">consumer goods</a> production. The crisis of the 1990s led to the drastic reduction of the state support for science and a <a href="/wiki/Brain_drain" class="mw-redirect" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a> migration from Russia.
</p><p>In the 2000s, on the wave of a new economic boom, the situation in the Russian science and technology has improved, and the government <a href="/wiki/Medvedev_modernisation_programme" title="Medvedev modernisation programme">launched a campaign</a> aimed into modernisation and <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovation</a>. Russian President Dmitry Medvedev formulated top priorities for the country's technological development:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Efficient_energy_use" title="Efficient energy use">Efficient energy use</a></li>
<li>Information technology, including both common products and the products combined with <a href="/wiki/Space_technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Space technology">space technology</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">Nuclear energy</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pharmaceuticals">Pharmaceuticals</a><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup></li></ul>
<p>Currently Russia has completed the <a href="/wiki/GLONASS" title="GLONASS">GLONASS</a> <a href="/wiki/Satellite_navigation_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Satellite navigation system">satellite navigation system</a>. The country is developing its own <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_PAK_FA" class="mw-redirect" title="Sukhoi PAK FA">fifth-generation jet fighter</a> and constructing the first serial <a href="/wiki/Mobile_nuclear_plant" class="mw-redirect" title="Mobile nuclear plant">mobile nuclear plant</a> in the world.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Space_exploration">Space exploration</span></h3>
<p>Russian achievements in the field of <a href="/wiki/Space_technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Space technology">space technology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration" title="Space exploration">space exploration</a> are traced back to <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Tsiolkovsky" title="Konstantin Tsiolkovsky">Konstantin Tsiolkovsky</a>, the father of theoretical <a href="/wiki/Astronautics" title="Astronautics">astronautics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> His works had inspired leading Soviet rocket engineers, such as <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Korolyov" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Korolyov">Sergey Korolyov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valentin_Glushko" title="Valentin Glushko">Valentin Glushko</a>, and many others who contributed to the success of the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_space_program" title="Soviet space program">Soviet space program</a> in the early stages of the <a href="/wiki/Space_Race" title="Space Race">Space Race</a> and beyond.
</p><p>In 1957 the first Earth-orbiting artificial <a href="/wiki/Satellite" title="Satellite">satellite</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sputnik_1" title="Sputnik 1">Sputnik&#160;1</a></i>, was launched; in 1961 the first human trip into space was successfully made by <a href="/wiki/Yuri_Gagarin" title="Yuri Gagarin">Yuri Gagarin</a>. Many other Soviet and Russian <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_records" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration records">space exploration records</a> ensued, including the first <a href="/wiki/Spacewalk" class="mw-redirect" title="Spacewalk">spacewalk</a> performed by <a href="/wiki/Alexei_Leonov" title="Alexei Leonov">Alexei Leonov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luna_9" title="Luna 9">Luna&#160;9</a> was the first spacecraft to land on the <a href="/wiki/Moon" title="Moon">Moon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zond_5" title="Zond 5">Zond 5</a> brought the first Earthlings (two tortoises and other life forms) to circumnavigate the Moon, <a href="/wiki/Venera_7" title="Venera 7">Venera&#160;7</a> was the first to land on another planet (<a href="/wiki/Venus" title="Venus">Venus</a>), <a href="/wiki/Mars_3" title="Mars 3">Mars&#160;3</a> then the first to land on <a href="/wiki/Mars" title="Mars">Mars</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Space_exploration_rover" class="mw-redirect" title="Space exploration rover">space exploration rover</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Lunokhod-1" class="mw-redirect" title="Lunokhod-1">Lunokhod 1</a></i>, and the first <a href="/wiki/Space_station" title="Space station">space station</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Salyut_1" title="Salyut 1">Salyut&#160;1</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Mir" title="Mir">Mir</a></i>.
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Collapse_of_the_Soviet_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Collapse of the Soviet Union">collapse of the Soviet Union</a>, some government-funded space exploration programs, including the <a href="/wiki/Buran_programme" title="Buran programme">Buran</a> space shuttle program, were cancelled or delayed, while participation of the Russian space industry in commercial activities and international cooperation intensified.
Nowadays Russia is the largest satellite launcher.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> After the United States <a href="/wiki/Space_Shuttle" title="Space Shuttle">Space Shuttle</a> program ended in 2011, <a href="/wiki/Soyuz_(rocket_family)" title="Soyuz (rocket family)">Soyuz rockets</a> became the only provider of transport for astronauts at the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Luna-Glob" title="Luna-Glob">Luna-Glob</a> is a Russian Moon exploration programme, with first planned mission launch in 2021. Roscosmos is also developing the <i><a href="/wiki/Federation_(spacecraft)" class="mw-redirect" title="Federation (spacecraft)">Federation</a></i> spacecraft, to replace the aging Soyuz, it could also conduct mission to lunar orbit as early as 2026.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> In February 2019, it was announced that Russia is intending to conduct its first crewed mission to land on the Moon in 2031.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Russia" title="Water supply and sanitation in Russia">Water supply and sanitation in Russia</a></div>
<p>In Russia, approximately 70 per cent of drinking water comes from surface water and 30 per cent from groundwater. In 2004, water supply systems had a total capacity of 90 million cubic metres a day. The average residential water use was 248 litres per capita per day.<sup id="cite_ref-UN_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN-283">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup> One fourth of the world's fresh surface and <a href="/wiki/Groundwater" title="Groundwater">groundwater</a> is located in Russia. The water utilities sector is one of the largest industries in Russia serving the entire Russian population.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corruption">Corruption</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Russia" title="Corruption in Russia">Corruption in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_(2017-06-12)_54.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg/220px-Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg/330px-Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg/440px-Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_%282017-06-12%29_54.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Anti-Corruption_Rally_in_Saint_Petersburg_(2017-06-12)_54.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests" title="2017–2018 Russian protests">2017–2018 Russian protests</a>, organized by Russia's opposition</div></div></div>
<p>There are many different estimates of the actual cost of corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-ararat.osipian_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ararat.osipian-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> According to official government statistics from Rosstat, the "shadow economy" occupied only 15% of Russia's GDP in 2011, and this included unreported salaries (to avoid taxes and social payments) and other types of tax evasion.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> According to Rosstat's estimates, corruption in 2011 amounted to only 3.5 to 7% of GDP. In comparison, some independent experts maintain that corruption consumes as much of 25% of Russia's GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> A World Bank report puts this figure at 48%.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> There is also an interesting shift in the main focus of bribery: whereas previously officials took bribes to shut their eyes to legal infractions, they now take them simply to perform their duties.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup> Many experts admit that in recent years corruption in Russia has become a business. In the 1990s, businessmen had to pay different criminal groups to provide a "<i>krysha</i>" (literally, a "roof", i.e., protection). Nowadays, this "protective" function is performed by officials. Corrupt hierarchies characterize different sectors of the economy,<sup id="cite_ref-ararat.osipian_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ararat.osipian-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2018)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> including education.<sup id="cite_ref-ararat.osipian_284-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ararat.osipian-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2018)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>In the end, the Russian population pays for this corruption.<sup id="cite_ref-ararat.osipian_284-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ararat.osipian-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2018)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> For example, some experts believe that the rapid increases in tariffs for housing, water, gas and electricity, which significantly outpace the rate of inflation, are a direct result of high volumes of corruption at the highest levels.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> In the recent years the reaction to corruption has changed: starting from Putin's second term, very few corruption cases have been the subject of outrage. Putin's system is remarkable for its ubiquitous and open merging of the civil service and business, as well as its use of relatives, friends, and acquaintances to benefit from budgetary expenditures and take over state property. Corporate, property, and land raiding is commonplace.<sup id="cite_ref-ararat.osipian_284-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ararat.osipian-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (October 2018)">better&#160;source&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup>
</p><p>On 26 March 2017, <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%932018_Russian_protests" title="2017–2018 Russian protests">protests</a> against alleged corruption in the federal Russian government took place simultaneously in many cities across the country.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> They were triggered by the lack of proper response from the Russian authorities to the published investigative film <i><a href="/wiki/He_Is_Not_Dimon_To_You" class="mw-redirect" title="He Is Not Dimon To You">He Is Not Dimon To You</a></i>, which has garnered more than 20 million views on YouTube.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2018 results of the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> by <a href="/wiki/Transparency_International" title="Transparency International">Transparency International</a>, Russia ranked 138th out of 180 countries with a score of 28 out of 100, tying with <a href="/wiki/Guinea" title="Guinea">Guinea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea" title="Papua New Guinea">Papua New Guinea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Russia" title="Demographics of Russia">Demographics of Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rossiyane" class="mw-redirect" title="Rossiyane">Rossiyane</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png/310px-%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="159" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png/465px-%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png/620px-%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png 2x" data-file-width="7200" data-file-height="3684" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9F%D0%BB%D0%BE%D1%82%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D1%8C_%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F_%D0%A0%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%81%D0%B8%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%BE_%D0%BC%D1%83%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BF%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D1%8B%D0%BC_%D0%BE%D0%B1%D1%80%D0%B0%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F%D0%BC.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Federal districts by population density. The population is most dense in the European part of the country, with milder climate, centering on Moscow, St Petersburg and other cities.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup></div></div></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r889293853/mw-parser-output/.tmulti"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:304px;max-width:304px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:302px;max-width:302px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/300px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="173" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/450px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg/600px-Percentage_of_Russians_by_region.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1092" data-file-height="630" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Percentage of ethnic Russians by region in 2010<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ff0000; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;&gt;80%</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ff9955; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;70—79%</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffccaa; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;50—69%</div><div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6d5; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;20—49%</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;">&#160;</span>&#160;&lt;20%</div></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:302px;max-width:302px"><div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG/300px-Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG" decoding="async" width="300" height="185" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG/450px-Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG/600px-Russia_natural_population_growth_rates_2015.PNG 2x" data-file-width="2263" data-file-height="1398" /></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Natural population growth rate in Russia, 2015</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> comprise 81% of the country's population.<sup id="cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> The Russian Federation is also home to several sizable minorities. In all, 160 different other ethnic groups and indigenous peoples live within its borders.<sup id="cite_ref-ethnicgroups_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicgroups-294">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> Although Russia's population is comparatively large, <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by population density">its density is low</a> because of the country's enormous size. Population is densest in <a href="/wiki/European_Russia" title="European Russia">European Russia</a>, near the <a href="/wiki/Ural_Mountains" title="Ural Mountains">Ural Mountains</a>, and in southwest Siberia. 73% of the population lives in urban areas while 27% in rural ones.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> The results of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" title="Russian Census (2010)">2010 Census</a> show a total population of 142,856,536.<sup id="cite_ref-2010Census_296-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2010Census-296">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's population peaked at 148,689,000 in 1991, just before the <a href="/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Dissolution of the Soviet Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>. It began to experience a rapid decline starting in the mid-1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup> The decline has slowed to near stagnation in recent years because of reduced <a href="/wiki/Death_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rates">death rates</a>, increased <a href="/wiki/Birth_rates" class="mw-redirect" title="Birth rates">birth rates</a> and increased <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, Russia recorded annual population growth for the first time in fifteen years, with total growth of 10,500.<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> The number of Russian emigrants steadily declined from 359,000 in 2000 to 32,000 in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a>, Russia's <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Russia" title="Immigration to Russia">immigrant population</a> is the third largest in the world, numbering 11.6 million.<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Azerbaijan, Moldova and Kazakhstan were the leading countries of origin for immigrants to Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> There are about 3 million <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Russia" title="Ukrainians in Russia">Ukrainians</a> living in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> 196,000 migrants arrived to the Russian Federation in 2016, mostly from the ex-Soviet states.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> Russia is home to approximately 116&#160;million ethnic Russians<sup id="cite_ref-ethnicgroups_294-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicgroups-294">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> and about 20&#160;million <a href="/wiki/Russian_diaspora" title="Russian diaspora">ethnic Russians</a> live outside Russia in the former republics of the Soviet Union,<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup> mostly in Ukraine and Kazakhstan.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Census_(2010)" title="Russian Census (2010)">2010 census</a> recorded 81% of the population as <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">ethnically Russian</a>, and 19% as other ethnicities:<sup id="cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup> 3.7% <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a>; 1.4% <a href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_Russia" title="Ukrainians in Russia">Ukrainians</a>; 1.1% <a href="/wiki/Bashkirs" title="Bashkirs">Bashkirs</a>; 1% <a href="/wiki/Chuvash_people" title="Chuvash people">Chuvashes</a>; 11.8% others and unspecified. According to the Census, 84.93% of the Russian population belongs to European ethnic groups (Slavic, Germanic, Finnic other than <a href="/wiki/Ugric_peoples" class="mw-redirect" title="Ugric peoples">Ugric</a>, Greek, and others). This is a decline from the 2002, when they constituted for more than 86% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-perepis-2010.ru_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-perepis-2010.ru-3">&#91;2&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russia's birth rate is higher than that of most European countries (13.3 births per 1000 people in 2014<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> compared to the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> average of 10.1 per 1000),<sup id="cite_ref-EU_crude_rates_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_crude_rates-305">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> but its death rate is also substantially higher (in 2014, Russia's death rate was 13.1 per 1000 people<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> compared to the EU average of 9.7 per 1000).<sup id="cite_ref-EU_crude_rates_305-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EU_crude_rates-305">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup> The Russian Ministry of Health and Social Affairs predicted that by 2011 the death rate would equal the birth rate because of increase in fertility and decline in mortality.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> The government is implementing a number of programs designed to increase the birth rate and attract more migrants. Monthly government child-assistance payments were doubled to US$55, and a one-time payment of US$9,200 was offered to women who had a second child since 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2018 the average <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across Russia was 1.61 children per woman.,<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> below the replacement rate of 2.1, it remains considerably below the high of 7.44 children born per woman in 1908.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup> In 2018 the <a href="/wiki/Median_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Median age">median age</a> of the Russian population was 39.8 years.
</p><p>In 2006, in a bid to compensate for the country's demographic decline, the Russian government started simplifying immigration laws and launched a state program "for providing assistance to voluntary immigration of ethnic Russians from former Soviet republics".<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup> In 2009 Russia experienced its highest birth rate since the dissolution of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup> In 2012, the birth rate increased again. Russia recorded 1,896,263 births, the highest number since 1990, and even exceeding annual births during the period 1967–1969, with a TFR of about 1.7, the highest since 1991. (Source: Vital statistics table below)
</p><p>In August 2012, as the country saw its first demographic growth since the 1990s, President Putin declared that Russia's population could reach 146 million by 2025, mainly as a result of immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup>
</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="Ethnic groups in Russia">Ethnic groups in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/290px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" decoding="async" width="290" height="169" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/435px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png/580px-Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png 2x" data-file-width="4836" data-file-height="2820" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ethnic_groups_in_Russia_of_more_than_1_million_people_2010_Census_English.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethnic groups in Russia of more than 1 million people, 2010 Census</div></div></div>
<p>Russia is a multi-national state with <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Russia" title="List of ethnic groups in Russia">over 170 ethnic groups</a> designated as nationalities; the populations of these groups vary enormously, from millions (e.g., Russians and Tatars) to under 10,000 (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Sami_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Sami people">Samis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eskimo" title="Eskimo">Eskimo</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Russia" title="Languages of Russia">Languages of Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_endangered_languages_in_Russia" title="List of endangered languages in Russia">List of endangered languages in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic,_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_(en).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/220px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="138" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/330px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png/440px-Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic%2C_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_%28en%29.png 2x" data-file-width="3245" data-file-height="2036" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Linguistic_map_of_the_Altaic,_Turkic_and_Uralic_languages_(en).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Distribution of <a href="/wiki/Uralic_languages" title="Uralic languages">Uralic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Altaic_languages" title="Altaic languages">Altaic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yukaghir_languages" title="Yukaghir languages">Yukaghir languages</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/220px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/330px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png/440px-Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png 2x" data-file-width="1025" data-file-height="808" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Fenno-Ugrian_languages.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Geographical distribution of <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">Finno-Ugric</a> and <a href="/wiki/Samoyedic_peoples" title="Samoyedic peoples">Samoyedic peoples</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/220px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="250" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/330px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg/440px-Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="977" data-file-height="1111" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Caucasus-ethnic_en.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_Caucasus" title="Languages of the Caucasus">Ethnolinguistic groups</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caucasus" title="Caucasus">Caucasus</a> region</div></div></div>
<p>Russia's 160 ethnic groups speak some 100 languages.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-17">&#91;13&#93;</a></sup> According to the 2002 Census, 142.6&#160;million people speak Russian, followed by <a href="/wiki/Tatar_language" title="Tatar language">Tatar</a> with 5.3&#160;million and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> with 1.8&#160;million speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup> Russian is the only official state language, but the Constitution gives the individual <a href="/wiki/Republics_of_Russia" title="Republics of Russia">republics</a> the right to establish their own state languages in addition to Russian.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Despite its wide distribution, the Russian language is homogeneous throughout the country. Russian is the most geographically widespread language of Eurasia, as well as the most widely spoken <a href="/wiki/Slavic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic language">Slavic language</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup> It belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European language">Indo-European language</a> family and is one of the living members of the <a href="/wiki/East_Slavic_languages" title="East Slavic languages">East Slavic languages</a>, the others being <a href="/wiki/Belarusian_language" title="Belarusian language">Belarusian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a> (and possibly <a href="/wiki/Rusyn_language" title="Rusyn language">Rusyn</a>). Written examples of <a href="/wiki/Old_East_Slavic" title="Old East Slavic">Old East Slavic</a> (<i>Old Russian</i>) are attested from the 10th century onwards.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Russian is the second-most used language on the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a> after English,<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> one of two official languages aboard the <a href="/wiki/International_Space_Station" title="International Space Station">International Space Station</a><sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup> and is one of the six <a href="/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_UN" class="mw-redirect" title="Official languages of the UN">official languages of the UN</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>35 languages are officially recognized in Russia in various regions by local governments.
</p>
