<th>Total population</th>
<th colspan="2">142,800,000
</th></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Russians have practised <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Christianity" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Christianity">Orthodox Christianity</a> since the 10th century. According to the historical traditions of the Orthodox Church, <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> was first brought to the territory of modern <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, Russia and <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> by <a href="/wiki/Saint_Andrew" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Andrew">Saint Andrew</a>, the first <a href="/wiki/Apostle_(Christian)" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostle (Christian)">Apostle</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jesus_Christ" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesus Christ">Jesus Christ</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-encarta_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encarta-360">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> Following the <i>Primary Chronicle</i>, the definitive <a href="/wiki/Christianization" title="Christianization">Christianization</a> of <a href="/wiki/Kievan_Rus%27" title="Kievan Rus&#39;">Kievan Rus'</a> dates from the year 988 (the year is disputed<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup>), when <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_the_Great" title="Vladimir the Great">Vladimir the Great</a> was baptized in <a href="/wiki/Chersonesus" title="Chersonesus">Chersonesus</a> and proceeded to baptize his family and people in <a href="/wiki/Kiev" title="Kiev">Kiev</a>. The latter events are traditionally referred to as the "baptism of Rus'" (<a href="/wiki/Russian_language" title="Russian language">Russian</a>: <span lang="ru">Крещение Руси</span>, <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_language" title="Ukrainian language">Ukrainian</a>: <span lang="uk">Хрещення Русі</span>) in Russian and Ukrainian literature. Much of the Russian population, like other Slavic peoples, preserved for centuries a double belief (<i>dvoeverie</i>) in both indigenous religion and Orthodox Christianity.
</p><p>At the time of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian revolution">1917 Revolution</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> was deeply integrated into the <a href="/wiki/Autocracy" title="Autocracy">autocratic state</a>, enjoying official status. This was a significant factor that contributed to the Bolshevik attitude to religion and the steps they took to control it. Moreover, the Bolsheviks including many people with non-Russian and/or non-Christian background, such as <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Lenin" title="Vladimir Lenin">Vladimir Lenin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leon_Trotsky" title="Leon Trotsky">Leon Trotsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grigory_Zinoviev" title="Grigory Zinoviev">Grigory Zinoviev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kamenev" title="Lev Kamenev">Lev Kamenev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grigori_Sokolnikov" title="Grigori Sokolnikov">and Grigori Sokolnikov</a>, who were, at best, indifferent towards Christianity, and at worst hostile to it. The ideas of German philosopher <a href="/wiki/Karl_Marx" title="Karl Marx">Karl Marx</a> were <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">synthesised with Lenin's own political thought</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Communist_party" title="Communist party">Communist Party</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PoU_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PoU-362">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/170px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="210" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/255px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg/340px-Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg 2x" data-file-width="945" data-file-height="1170" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasnetsov_Bapt_Vladimir.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>"The Baptism of Vladimir", a fresco by <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Vasnetsov" title="Viktor Vasnetsov">Viktor Vasnetsov</a></div></div></div>
<p>Thus the USSR became one of the first <a href="/wiki/Communist" class="mw-redirect" title="Communist">communist</a> states to proclaim, as an ideological objective, the <a href="/wiki/State_atheism" title="State atheism">elimination of religion</a><sup id="cite_ref-Kowalewski_363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kowalewski-363">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> and its replacement with universal <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup> The communist government ridiculed religions and their believers, and propagated atheism in schools.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> The confiscation of religious assets was often based on accusations of illegal accumulation of wealth. State atheism in the Soviet Union was known in Russian as <i>gosateizm</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-Kowalewski_363-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kowalewski-363">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> and was based on the ideology of <a href="/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism" title="Marxism–Leninism">Marxism–Leninism</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Marxist%E2%80%93Leninist_atheism" title="Marxist–Leninist atheism">consistently advocated</a> has consistently advocated the control, suppression, and elimination of religion. Within about a year of the revolution, the state <a href="/wiki/Expropriated" class="mw-redirect" title="Expropriated">expropriated</a> all church property, including the churches themselves, and in the period from 1922 to 1926, 28 Russian Orthodox <a href="/wiki/Bishop" title="Bishop">bishops</a> and more than 1,200 <a href="/wiki/Priest" title="Priest">priests</a> were killed. Many more were persecuted.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-367">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After the collapse of the Soviet Union there has been a renewal of religions in Russia, and among Slavs various movements have emerged besides Christianity, including <a href="/wiki/Rodnovery" class="mw-redirect" title="Rodnovery">Rodnovery</a> (Slavic Native Faith), <a href="/wiki/Assianism" title="Assianism">Assianism</a>, and other ethnic Paganisms, <a href="/wiki/Roerichism" title="Roerichism">Roerichism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ringing_Cedars%27_Anastasianism" title="Ringing Cedars&#39; Anastasianism">Ringing Cedars' Anastasianism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Siberian_shamanism" class="mw-redirect" title="Siberian shamanism">Siberian shamanism</a><sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> or <a href="/wiki/Tengrism" title="Tengrism">Tengrism</a>, and other religions.
</p><p>In 2012 the research organization Sreda, in cooperation with the 2010 census and the Ministry of Justice, published the Arena Atlas, a detailed enumeration of religious populations and nationalities in Russia, based on a large-sample country-wide survey. The results showed that 46.8% of Russians declared themselves Christians—including 41% Russian Orthodox, 1.5% simply Orthodox or members of non-Russian Orthodox churches, 4.1% unaffiliated Christians, and less than 1% for both <a href="/wiki/Old_Believers" title="Old Believers">Old Believers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholics</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestants</a>—while 25% were <a href="/wiki/Spiritual_but_not_religious" title="Spiritual but not religious">spiritual but not religious</a>, 13% were atheists, 6.5% were <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Muslims</a>, 1.2% were followers of "traditional religions honoring gods and ancestors" (including Rodnovery, Tengrism and other <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_religions" class="mw-redirect" title="Ethnic religions">ethnic religions</a>), and 0.5% were <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhists</a>, 0.1% were <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">religious Jews</a> and 0.1% were <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hindus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_356-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-356">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg/220px-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="163" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg/330px-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg/440px-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="594" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%B4._%D0%A2%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B8%D1%86%D0%B5-%D0%A1%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B0_%D0%BB%D0%B0%D0%B2%D1%80%D0%B0._1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Trinity_Lavra_of_St._Sergius" title="Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius">Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius</a>, spiritual centre of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> and UNESCO <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Russia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Russia">World Heritage site</a></div></div></div>
<p>According to various reports, the proportion of not religious people in Russia is between 16% and 48% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-370" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-370">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> According to recent studies, the proportion of atheists has significantly decreased over the decades after the dissolution of the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-2013_Belivers_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2013_Belivers-371">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-GallupInt_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GallupInt-372">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Orthodox Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, and Paganism (either preserved or revived) are recognised by law as Russia's traditional religions, marking the country's "historical heritage".<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kizhi_church_1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Kizhi_church_1.jpg/170px-Kizhi_church_1.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Kizhi_church_1.jpg/255px-Kizhi_church_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Kizhi_church_1.jpg/340px-Kizhi_church_1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1988" data-file-height="2532" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kizhi_church_1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kizhi_Pogost" title="Kizhi Pogost">Church of the Transfiguration</a> on <a href="/wiki/Kizhi_Island" title="Kizhi Island">Kizhi</a> island in the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Karelia" title="Republic of Karelia">Republic of Karelia</a></div></div></div>
<p>An estimated 95% of the registered Orthodox parishes belong to the Russian Orthodox Church while there are a number of smaller Orthodox churches.<sup id="cite_ref-religare.ru_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-religare.ru-375">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup> However, the vast majority of Orthodox believers do not attend church on a regular basis. Easter is the most popular religious holiday in Russia, celebrated by a large segment of the Russian population, including large numbers of those who are non-religious. More than three-quarters of the Russian population celebrate Easter by making traditional Easter cakes, coloured eggs and <a href="/wiki/Paskha_(dish)" class="mw-redirect" title="Paskha (dish)">paskha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Russia" title="Islam in Russia">Islam</a> is the second largest religion in Russia after Russian Orthodoxy.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> It is the traditional or predominant religion amongst some <a href="/wiki/Peoples_of_the_Caucasus" title="Peoples of the Caucasus">Caucasian ethnicities</a> (notably the <a href="/wiki/Chechens" title="Chechens">Chechens</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ingush_people" title="Ingush people">Ingush</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassians</a>), and amongst some <a href="/wiki/Turkic_peoples" title="Turkic peoples">Turkic peoples</a> (notably the <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Bashkirs" title="Bashkirs">Bashkirs</a>).
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Buddhism_in_Russia" title="Buddhism in Russia">Buddhism</a> is traditional in three republics of Russia: <a href="/wiki/Buryatia" title="Buryatia">Buryatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kalmykia" title="Kalmykia">Kalmykia</a>, the latter being the only region in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> where Buddhism is the most practiced religion.
</p><p>In cultural and social affairs, Vladimir Putin has collaborated closely with the Russian Orthodox Church. <a href="/wiki/Patriarch_Kirill_of_Moscow" title="Patriarch Kirill of Moscow">Patriarch Kirill of Moscow</a>, head of the Church, endorsed his election in 2012. Steven Myers reports, "The church, once heavily repressed, had emerged from the Soviet collapse as one of the most respected institutions... Now Kiril led the faithful directly into an alliance with the state."<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> Baptist minister Mark Woods provides specific examples of how the Church under Patriarch Kirill of Moscow has backed the expansion of Russian power into Crimea and eastern Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> 
</p><p>The Holy Synod of the Russian Orthodox Church, at its session on 15 October 2018, <a href="/wiki/Moscow%E2%80%93Constantinople_schism_(2018)" class="mw-redirect" title="Moscow–Constantinople schism (2018)">severed ties</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Ecumenical_Patriarchate_of_Constantinople" title="Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople</a>. The decision was taken in response to the move made by the Patriarchate of Constantinople a few days prior that effectively ended the Moscow Patriarchate's <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Orthodox_Church_(Moscow_Patriarchate)" title="Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate)">jurisdiction over Ukraine</a> and promised <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Church_of_Ukraine" title="Orthodox Church of Ukraine">autocephaly</a> to Ukraine.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 26 April 2017, for the first time, the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Commission_on_International_Religious_Freedom" class="mw-redirect" title="U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom">U.S. Commission on International Religious Freedom</a> classified Russia as one of the world's worst violators of religious liberty, recommending in its 2017 annual report that the U.S. government deem Russia a "country of particular concern" under the International Religious Freedom Act and negotiate for religious liberty. The report states, "—it is the sole state to have not only continually intensified its repression of religious freedom since USCIRF commenced monitoring it, but also to have expanded its repressive policies....ranging from administrative harassment to arbitrary imprisonment to extrajudicial killing, are implemented in a fashion that is systematic, ongoing, and egregious."<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup> On 4 April 2017 <a href="/wiki/UN_Special_Rapporteur" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Special Rapporteur">UN Special Rapporteur</a> on Freedom of Opinion and Expression <a href="/wiki/David_Kaye_(law_professor)" title="David Kaye (law professor)">David Kaye</a>, UN Special Rapporteur on Freedoms of Peaceful Assembly and Association <a href="/wiki/Maina_Kiai" title="Maina Kiai">Maina Kiai</a>, and UN Special Rapporteur on Freedom of Religion and Belief <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Shaheed" title="Ahmed Shaheed">Ahmed Shaheed</a> condemned Russia's treatment of <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witnesses" title="Jehovah&#39;s Witnesses">Jehovah's Witnesses</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> Many other countries and international organizations have spoken out on Russia's religious abuses.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 120.66666666667px"><div style="width: 120.66666666667px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 118.66666666667px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/178px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg" decoding="async" width="119" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/267px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg/356px-Moscow_StBasilCathedral_d18.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2105" data-file-height="2128" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 215.33333333333px"><div style="width: 215.33333333333px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 213.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg/320px-%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg" decoding="async" width="214" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg/480px-%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg/640px-%D0%9C%D0%BE%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%81%D0%BE%D0%B1%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D0%BC%D0%B5%D1%87%D0%B5%D1%82%D1%8C.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5791" data-file-height="3257" /></a></div></div>
			<div class="gallerytext">
<p><a href="/wiki/Moscow_Cathedral_Mosque" title="Moscow Cathedral Mosque">Moscow Cathedral Mosque</a>
</p>
			</div>
		</div></li>
		<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 167.33333333333px"><div style="width: 167.33333333333px">
			<div class="thumb" style="width: 165.33333333333px;"><div style="margin:0px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg/248px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg" decoding="async" width="166" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg/372px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg/496px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%90%D1%80%D1%87%D1%8B.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="930" /></a></div></div>

</p>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Russia" title="Healthcare in Russia">Healthcare in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG/220px-Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG/330px-Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG/440px-Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Terapevt_Mudrov_train.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A mobile clinic used to provide health care at remote railway stations</div></div></div>
<p>The Russian Constitution guarantees free, <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> for all its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup> In practice, however, free health care is partially restricted because of <a href="/wiki/Registration_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Registration in Russia">mandatory registration</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">&#91;380&#93;</a></sup> While Russia has more physicians, hospitals, and health care workers than almost any other country in the world on a per capita basis,<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">&#91;381&#93;</a></sup> since the dissolution of the Soviet Union the health of the Russian population has declined considerably as a result of social, economic, and lifestyle changes;<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">&#91;382&#93;</a></sup> the trend has been reversed only in the recent years, with average life expectancy having increased 5.2 years for males and 3.1 years for females between 2006 and 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-demo26data_390-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demo26data-390">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Due to the ongoing <a href="/wiki/Russian_financial_crisis_(2014%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian financial crisis (2014–present)">Russian financial crisis</a> since 2014, major cuts in health spending have resulted in a decline in the quality of service of the state healthcare system. About 40% of basic medical facilities have fewer staff than they are supposed to have, with others being closed down. Waiting times for treatment have increased, and patients have been forced to pay for more services that were previously free.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">&#91;384&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">&#91;385&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, the average life expectancy in Russia was 65.29 years for males and 76.49 years for females.<sup id="cite_ref-demo26data_390-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-demo26data-390">&#91;383&#93;</a></sup> The biggest factor contributing to the relatively low life expectancy for males is a high mortality rate among working-age males. Deaths mostly occur from preventable causes, including alcohol poisoning, smoking, traffic accidents and violent crime.<sup id="cite_ref-gks_298-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gks-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup> As a result, Russia has one of the world's most female-biased <a href="/wiki/Human_sex_ratio" title="Human sex ratio">sex ratios</a>, with 0.859 males to every female.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_121-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-121">&#91;117&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Russia" title="Education in Russia">Education in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow_State_University.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Moscow_State_University.jpg/220px-Moscow_State_University.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Moscow_State_University.jpg/330px-Moscow_State_University.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Moscow_State_University.jpg/440px-Moscow_State_University.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4450" data-file-height="2455" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Moscow_State_University.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Lomonosov Moscow State University</a></div></div></div>
<p>Russia has the most college-level or higher graduates in terms of percentage of population in the world, at 54%.<sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">&#91;386&#93;</a></sup> Russia has a <a href="/wiki/Free_education" title="Free education">free education</a> system, which is guaranteed for all citizens by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Russia" title="Constitution of Russia">Constitution</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">&#91;387&#93;</a></sup> however entry to subsidized higher education is highly competitive.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">&#91;388&#93;</a></sup> As a result of great emphasis on science and technology in education, Russian medical, mathematical, scientific, and aerospace research is generally of a high order.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">&#91;389&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1990, the 11-year school education has been introduced. Education in state-owned secondary schools is free. University level education is free, with exceptions. A substantial share of students is enrolled for full pay (many state institutions started to open commercial positions in the last years).<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">&#91;390&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The oldest and largest <a href="/wiki/Russian_universities" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian universities">Russian universities</a> are <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg_State_University" title="Saint Petersburg State University">Saint Petersburg State University</a>. In the 2000s, in order to create higher education and research institutions of comparable scale in Russian regions, the government launched a program of establishing "federal universities", mostly by merging existing large regional universities and research institutes and providing them with a special funding. These new institutions include the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Federal_University" title="Southern Federal University">Southern Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siberian_Federal_University" title="Siberian Federal University">Siberian Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazan_Volga_Federal_University" class="mw-redirect" title="Kazan Volga Federal University">Kazan Volga Federal University</a>, <a href="/wiki/North-Eastern_Federal_University" title="North-Eastern Federal University">North-Eastern Federal University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Far_Eastern_Federal_University" title="Far Eastern Federal University">Far Eastern Federal University</a>.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<p>According to the 2018 QS World University Rankings, the highest-ranking Russian educational institution is <a href="/wiki/Moscow_State_University" title="Moscow State University">Moscow State University</a>, rated 95th in the world.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_culture" title="Russian culture">Russian culture</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Folk_culture_and_cuisine">Folk culture and cuisine</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Russian_traditions" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian traditions">Russian traditions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_jokes" title="Russian jokes">Russian jokes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Fairy_Tales_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Russian Fairy Tales (disambiguation)">Russian fairy tales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gopnik" title="Gopnik">Gopnik</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg/220px-Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg/330px-Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg/440px-Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1250" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Kustodiev_Merchants_Wife.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>The Merchant's Wife</i> by <a href="/wiki/Boris_Kustodiev" title="Boris Kustodiev">Boris Kustodiev</a>, showcasing the <a href="/wiki/Russian_tea_culture" title="Russian tea culture">Russian tea culture</a></div></div></div>
<p>There are over 160 different ethnic groups and indigenous peoples in Russia.<sup id="cite_ref-ethnicgroups_294-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicgroups-294">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> The country's vast cultural diversity spans ethnic <a href="/wiki/Russians" title="Russians">Russians</a> with their <a href="/wiki/Slavs" title="Slavs">Slavic</a> <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> traditions, <a href="/wiki/Tatars" title="Tatars">Tatars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bashkirs" title="Bashkirs">Bashkirs</a> with their Turkic Muslim culture, <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> <a href="/wiki/Nomad" title="Nomad">nomadic</a> <a href="/wiki/Buryats" title="Buryats">Buryats</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kalmyks" title="Kalmyks">Kalmyks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shamanistic" class="mw-redirect" title="Shamanistic">Shamanistic</a> peoples of the <a href="/wiki/Extreme_North" class="mw-redirect" title="Extreme North">Extreme North</a> and Siberia, highlanders of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Caucasus" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Caucasus">Northern Caucasus</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Finno-Ugric_peoples" title="Finno-Ugric peoples">Finno-Ugric peoples</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_North_West" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian North West">Russian North West</a> and <a href="/wiki/Volga_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga Region">Volga Region</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Handicraft" title="Handicraft">Handicraft</a>, like <a href="/wiki/Dymkovo_toy" class="mw-redirect" title="Dymkovo toy">Dymkovo toy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Khokhloma" title="Khokhloma">khokhloma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gzhel" title="Gzhel">gzhel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Palekh_miniature" title="Palekh miniature">palekh miniature</a> represent an important aspect of Russian <a href="/wiki/Folk_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk culture">folk culture</a>. Ethnic Russian clothes include <a href="/wiki/Kaftan" title="Kaftan">kaftan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovorotka" title="Kosovorotka">kosovorotka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ushanka" title="Ushanka">ushanka</a> for men, <a href="/wiki/Sarafan" title="Sarafan">sarafan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kokoshnik" title="Kokoshnik">kokoshnik</a> for women, with <a href="/wiki/Lapti" class="mw-redirect" title="Lapti">lapti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valenki" title="Valenki">valenki</a> as common shoes. The clothes of <a href="/wiki/Cossack" class="mw-redirect" title="Cossack">Cossacks</a> from Southern Russia include <a href="/wiki/Burka_(Caucasus)" title="Burka (Caucasus)">burka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papaha" class="mw-redirect" title="Papaha">papaha</a>, which they share with the peoples of the Northern Caucasus.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_cuisine" title="Russian cuisine">Russian cuisine</a> widely uses fish, caviar, poultry, mushrooms, berries, and honey. Crops of <a href="/wiki/Rye" title="Rye">rye</a>, wheat, <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Millet" title="Millet">millet</a> provide the ingredients for various breads, <a href="/wiki/Pancake" title="Pancake">pancakes</a> and cereals, as well as for <a href="/wiki/Kvass" title="Kvass">kvass</a>, beer and vodka drinks. <a href="/wiki/Black_bread" class="mw-redirect" title="Black bread">Black bread</a> is rather popular in Russia, compared to the rest of the world. Flavourful soups and stews include <a href="/wiki/Shchi" title="Shchi">shchi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Borsch" class="mw-redirect" title="Borsch">borsch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ukha" title="Ukha">ukha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Solyanka" title="Solyanka">solyanka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Okroshka" title="Okroshka">okroshka</a>. <a href="/wiki/Smetana_(dairy_product)" title="Smetana (dairy product)">Smetana</a> (a heavy <a href="/wiki/Sour_cream" title="Sour cream">sour cream</a>) is often added to soups and salads. <a href="/wiki/Pirozhki" title="Pirozhki">Pirozhki</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blini" title="Blini">blini</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syrniki" title="Syrniki">syrniki</a> are native types of pancakes. <a href="/wiki/Chicken_Kiev" title="Chicken Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pelmeni" title="Pelmeni">pelmeni</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shashlyk" class="mw-redirect" title="Shashlyk">shashlyk</a> are popular meat dishes, the last two being of Tatar and Caucasus origin respectively. Other meat dishes include stuffed cabbage rolls <i>(<a href="/wiki/Golubtsy" class="mw-redirect" title="Golubtsy">golubtsy</a>)</i> usually filled with meat.<sup id="cite_ref-mrig-golubtsy_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mrig-golubtsy-398">&#91;391&#93;</a></sup> Salads include <a href="/wiki/Olivier_salad" title="Olivier salad">Olivier salad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vinegret" title="Vinegret">vinegret</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dressed_herring" title="Dressed herring">dressed herring</a>.
</p><p>Russia's large number of ethnic groups have distinctive traditions regarding <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Russia#Ethnic_roots_music" title="Music of Russia">folk music</a>. Typical ethnic Russian musical instruments are <a href="/wiki/Gusli" title="Gusli">gusli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balalaika" title="Balalaika">balalaika</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zhaleika" title="Zhaleika">zhaleika</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Garmoshka" class="mw-redirect" title="Garmoshka">garmoshka</a>. Folk music had a significant influence on Russian classical composers, and in modern times it is a source of inspiration for a number of popular <a href="/wiki/Folk_band" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk band">folk bands</a>, like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Melnitsa&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Melnitsa (page does not exist)">Melnitsa</a>. <a href="/wiki/Russian_folk_songs" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian folk songs">Russian folk songs</a>, as well as patriotic <a href="/wiki/Soviet_songs" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet songs">Soviet songs</a>, constitute the bulk of the repertoire of the world-renowned <a href="/wiki/Alexandrov_Ensemble" title="Alexandrov Ensemble">Red Army choir</a> and other popular ensembles.
</p><p>Russians have <a href="/wiki/Russian_traditions" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian traditions">many traditions</a>, including the washing in <a href="/wiki/Banya_(sauna)" title="Banya (sauna)">banya</a>, a hot steam bath somewhat similar to <a href="/wiki/Sauna" title="Sauna">sauna</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-banya_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-banya-63">&#91;59&#93;</a></sup> Old <a href="/wiki/Russian_folklore" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian folklore">Russian folklore</a> takes its roots in the pagan <a href="/wiki/Slavic_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic mythology">Slavic religion</a>. Many <a href="/wiki/Russian_fairy_tale" title="Russian fairy tale">Russian fairy tales</a> and epic <a href="/wiki/Bylina" title="Bylina">bylinas</a> were adapted for animation films, or for feature movies by the prominent directors like <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Ptushko" title="Aleksandr Ptushko">Aleksandr Ptushko</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Ilya_Muromets_(film)" title="Ilya Muromets (film)">Ilya Muromets</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Sadko_(film)" title="Sadko (film)">Sadko</a></i>) and <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Rou" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Rou">Aleksandr Rou</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Morozko" class="mw-redirect" title="Morozko">Morozko</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Vasilisa_the_Beautiful_(1939_film)" title="Vasilisa the Beautiful (1939 film)">Vasilisa the Beautiful</a></i>). Russian poets, including <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Pavlovich_Yershov" title="Pyotr Pavlovich Yershov">Pyotr Yershov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Filatov" title="Leonid Filatov">Leonid Filatov</a>, made a number of well-known poetical interpretations of the classical fairy tales, and in some cases, like that of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a>, also created fully original fairy tale poems of great popularity.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_architecture" title="Russian architecture">Russian architecture</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_architects" title="List of Russian architects">List of Russian architects</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Basil_Cathedral,_Moscow.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg/170px-Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="227" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg/255px-Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg/340px-Saint_Basil_Cathedral%2C_Moscow.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3864" data-file-height="5152" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Basil_Cathedral,_Moscow.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, one of the most popular symbols of the country</div></div></div>
<p>Since the <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_Kievan_Rus%27" title="Christianization of Kievan Rus&#39;">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a> for several ages Russian architecture was influenced predominantly by the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_architecture" title="Byzantine architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. Apart from fortifications (<a href="/wiki/Kremlin" class="mw-redirect" title="Kremlin">kremlins</a>), the main stone buildings of ancient Rus' were <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_church_(building)" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox church (building)">Orthodox churches</a> with their many <a href="/wiki/Dome" title="Dome">domes</a>, often gilded or brightly painted.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Aristotle_Fioravanti" class="mw-redirect" title="Aristotle Fioravanti">Aristotle Fioravanti</a> and other Italian architects brought <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> trends into Russia since the late 15th century, while the 16th century saw the development of unique <a href="/wiki/Tent-like_church" class="mw-redirect" title="Tent-like church">tent-like churches</a> culminating in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">&#91;392&#93;</a></sup> By that time the <a href="/wiki/Onion_dome" title="Onion dome">onion dome</a> design was also fully developed.<sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">&#91;393&#93;</a></sup> In the 17th century, the "fiery style" of ornamentation flourished in Moscow and <a href="/wiki/Yaroslavl" title="Yaroslavl">Yaroslavl</a>, gradually paving the way for the <a href="/wiki/Naryshkin_baroque" class="mw-redirect" title="Naryshkin baroque">Naryshkin baroque</a> of the 1690s. After the <a href="/wiki/Reforms_of_Peter_the_Great" class="mw-redirect" title="Reforms of Peter the Great">reforms of Peter the Great</a> the change of architectural styles in Russia generally followed that in the Western Europe.
</p><p>The 18th-century taste for <a href="/wiki/Rococo" title="Rococo">rococo</a> architecture led to the ornate works of <a href="/wiki/Bartolomeo_Rastrelli" class="mw-redirect" title="Bartolomeo Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a> and his followers. The reigns of <a href="/wiki/Catherine_the_Great" title="Catherine the Great">Catherine the Great</a> and her grandson <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Russia" title="Alexander I of Russia">Alexander&#160;I</a> saw the flourishing of <a href="/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture" title="Neoclassical architecture">Neoclassical architecture</a>, most notably in the capital city of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a>. The second half of the 19th century was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Neo-Byzantine_architecture_in_the_Russian_Empire" title="Neo-Byzantine architecture in the Russian Empire">Neo-Byzantine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revival" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian Revival">Russian Revival</a> styles. Prevalent styles of the 20th century were the <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a>, <a href="/wiki/Constructivist_architecture" title="Constructivist architecture">Constructivism</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Stalin_Empire_style" class="mw-redirect" title="Stalin Empire style">Stalin Empire style</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg/220px-Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg/330px-Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg/440px-Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="3600" data-file-height="2384" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral_in_SPB.jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The neoclassical <a href="/wiki/Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Isaac&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Isaac's Cathedral</a> in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_cultural_heritage_register#Denial_of_heritage_(1917–1941)" title="Russian cultural heritage register">With the change in values imposed by communist ideology</a>, the tradition of preservation was broken. Independent preservation societies, even those that defended only secular landmarks such as Moscow-based OIRU were disbanded by the end of the 1920s. A new anti-religious campaign, launched in 1929, coincided with collectivization of peasants; destruction of churches in the cities peaked around 1932. A number of churches were demolished, including the <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour" title="Cathedral of Christ the Saviour">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a> in Moscow. <a href="/wiki/Russian_cultural_heritage_register#Post-Soviet_Russia_(1991–present)" title="Russian cultural heritage register">In Moscow alone losses of 1917–2006</a> are estimated at over 640 notable buildings (including 150 to 200 listed buildings, out of a total inventory of 3,500) – some disappeared completely, others were replaced with concrete replicas.
</p><p>In 1955, a new Soviet leader, <a href="/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev" title="Nikita Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a>, condemned the "excesses" of the former academic architecture,<sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">&#91;394&#93;</a></sup> and the late Soviet era was dominated by plain <a href="/wiki/Functionalism_in_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Functionalism in architecture">functionalism in architecture</a>. This helped somewhat to resolve the housing problem, but created a large quantity of buildings of low architectural quality, much in contrast with the previous bright styles. <a href="/wiki/Russian_cultural_heritage_register#Khrushchev&#39;s_offensive_(1959–1964)" title="Russian cultural heritage register">In 1959 Nikita Khrushchev launched his anti-religious campaign</a>. By 1964 over 10 thousand churches out of 20 thousand were shut down (mostly in rural areas) and many were demolished. Of 58 monasteries and convents operating in 1959, only sixteen remained by 1964; of Moscow's fifty churches operating in 1959, thirty were closed and six demolished.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Russian_artists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian artists">Russian artists</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg/170px-Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="257" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg/255px-Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg/340px-Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="1963" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Rublev_Arhangel_Mikhail.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Archangel Michael</i> fresco (1408) by <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a>, which represents the typical <a href="/wiki/Russo-Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Russo-Byzantine">Russo-Byzantine</a> style of art</div></div></div>
<p>Early Russian painting is represented in <a href="/wiki/Russian_icons" title="Russian icons">icons</a> and vibrant <a href="/wiki/Fresco" title="Fresco">frescos</a>, the two genres inherited from <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a>. As Moscow rose to power, <a href="/wiki/Theophanes_the_Greek" title="Theophanes the Greek">Theophanes the Greek</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dionisius" title="Dionisius">Dionisius</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrei_Rublev" title="Andrei Rublev">Andrei Rublev</a> became vital names associated with a distinctly Russian art.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_Academy_of_Arts" title="Russian Academy of Arts">Russian Academy of Arts</a> was created in 1757<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">&#91;395&#93;</a></sup> and gave Russian artists an international role and status. <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Argunov" title="Ivan Argunov">Ivan Argunov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Levitzky" title="Dmitry Levitzky">Dmitry Levitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Borovikovsky" title="Vladimir Borovikovsky">Vladimir Borovikovsky</a> and other 18th-century academicians mostly focused on <a href="/wiki/Portrait_painting" title="Portrait painting">portrait painting</a>. In the early 19th century, when <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">neoclassicism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romantism" class="mw-redirect" title="Romantism">romantism</a> flourished, mythological and Biblical themes inspired many prominent paintings, notably by <a href="/wiki/Karl_Briullov" class="mw-redirect" title="Karl Briullov">Karl Briullov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Andreyevich_Ivanov" title="Alexander Andreyevich Ivanov">Alexander Ivanov</a>.
</p><p>In the mid-19th century the <i><a href="/wiki/Peredvizhniki" title="Peredvizhniki">Peredvizhniki</a></i> (<i>Wanderers</i>) group of artists broke with the Academy and initiated a school of art liberated from academic restrictions.<sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">&#91;396&#93;</a></sup> These were mostly <a href="/wiki/Realism_(visual_arts)" class="mw-redirect" title="Realism (visual arts)">realist</a> painters who captured Russian identity in landscapes of wide rivers, forests, and birch clearings, as well as vigorous genre scenes and robust portraits of their contemporaries. Some artists focused on depicting dramatic moments in Russian history, while others turned to <a href="/wiki/Social_criticism" title="Social criticism">social criticism</a>, showing the conditions of the poor and caricaturing authority; <a href="/wiki/Critical_realism_(philosophy_of_the_social_sciences)" title="Critical realism (philosophy of the social sciences)">critical realism</a> flourished under the reign of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_II_of_Russia" title="Alexander II of Russia">Alexander II</a>. Leading realists include <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Shishkin" title="Ivan Shishkin">Ivan Shishkin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arkhip_Kuindzhi" title="Arkhip Kuindzhi">Arkhip Kuindzhi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kramskoi" title="Ivan Kramskoi">Ivan Kramskoi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Polenov" title="Vasily Polenov">Vasily Polenov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Levitan" title="Isaac Levitan">Isaac Levitan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Surikov" title="Vasily Surikov">Vasily Surikov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viktor_Vasnetsov" title="Viktor Vasnetsov">Viktor Vasnetsov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ilya_Repin" title="Ilya Repin">Ilya Repin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Boris_Kustodiev" title="Boris Kustodiev">Boris Kustodiev</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/330px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/440px-Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="30000" data-file-height="21059" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Karl_Brullov_-_The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Last_Day_of_Pompeii" title="The Last Day of Pompeii">The Last Day of Pompeii</a></i> (1833, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Museum" title="Russian Museum">Russian Museum</a>) by <a href="/wiki/Karl_Bryullov" title="Karl Bryullov">Karl Bryullov</a>, a key figure in transition from the Russian neoclassicism to romanticism</div></div></div>
<p>The turn of the 20th century saw the rise of <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(art)" class="mw-redirect" title="Symbolism (art)">symbolist</a> painting, represented by <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Vrubel" title="Mikhail Vrubel">Mikhail Vrubel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kuzma_Petrov-Vodkin" title="Kuzma Petrov-Vodkin">Kuzma Petrov-Vodkin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nicholas_Roerich" title="Nicholas Roerich">Nicholas Roerich</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Russian_avant-garde" title="Russian avant-garde">Russian avant-garde</a> was a large, influential wave of <a href="/wiki/Modernist_art" class="mw-redirect" title="Modernist art">modernist art</a> that flourished in Russia from approximately 1890 to 1930. The term covers many separate, but inextricably related art movements that occurred at the time, namely <a href="/wiki/Neo-primitivism" title="Neo-primitivism">neo-primitivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suprematism" title="Suprematism">suprematism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Constructivism_(art)" title="Constructivism (art)">constructivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rayonism" title="Rayonism">rayonism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_Futurism" title="Russian Futurism">Russian Futurism</a>. Notable artists from this era include <a href="/wiki/El_Lissitzky" title="El Lissitzky">El Lissitzky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazimir_Malevich" title="Kazimir Malevich">Kazimir Malevich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky" title="Wassily Kandinsky">Wassily Kandinsky</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marc_Chagall" title="Marc Chagall">Marc Chagall</a>. Since the 1930s the revolutionary ideas of the <a href="/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde">avant-garde</a> clashed with the newly emerged conservative direction of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a>.
</p><p>Soviet art produced works that were furiously patriotic and <a href="/wiki/Anti-fascist" class="mw-redirect" title="Anti-fascist">anti-fascist</a> during and after the <a href="/wiki/Great_Patriotic_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Patriotic War">Great Patriotic War</a>. Multiple war memorials, marked by a great restrained solemnity, were built throughout the country. Soviet artists often combined innovation with socialist realism, notably the sculptors <a href="/wiki/Vera_Mukhina" title="Vera Mukhina">Vera Mukhina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Vuchetich" title="Yevgeny Vuchetich">Yevgeny Vuchetich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Neizvestny" title="Ernst Neizvestny">Ernst Neizvestny</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music_and_dance">Music and dance</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Russia" title="Music of Russia">Music of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_traditional_music" title="Russian traditional music">Russian traditional music</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_ballet" title="Russian ballet">Russian ballet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_opera" title="Russian opera">Russian opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian rock">Russian rock</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_pop" title="Russian pop">Russian pop</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_composers" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian composers">Russian composers</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Snowdance.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Snowdance.jpg/170px-Snowdance.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="245" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Snowdance.jpg/255px-Snowdance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Snowdance.jpg/340px-Snowdance.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="2948" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Snowdance.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i>Snowdance</i> scene from <i><a href="/wiki/The_Nutcracker" title="The Nutcracker">The Nutcracker</a></i> ballet, composed by <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a></div></div></div>
<p>Music in 19th-century Russia was defined by the tension between classical composer <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Glinka" title="Mikhail Glinka">Mikhail Glinka</a> along with other members of <a href="/wiki/The_Mighty_Handful" class="mw-redirect" title="The Mighty Handful">The Mighty Handful</a>, who embraced Russian national identity and added religious and folk elements to their compositions, and the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Musical_Society" title="Russian Musical Society">Russian Musical Society</a> led by composers <a href="/wiki/Anton_Rubinstein" title="Anton Rubinstein">Anton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Rubinstein" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Rubinstein">Nikolay Rubinsteins</a>, which was musically conservative. The later tradition of <a href="/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky" title="Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky">Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky</a>, one of the greatest composers of the <a href="/wiki/Romantic_music" title="Romantic music">Romantic era</a>, was continued into the 20th century by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Rachmaninoff" title="Sergei Rachmaninoff">Sergei Rachmaninoff</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">&#91;397&#93;</a></sup> World-renowned composers of the 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Scriabin" title="Alexander Scriabin">Alexander Scriabin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky" title="Igor Stravinsky">Igor Stravinsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev" title="Sergei Prokofiev">Sergei Prokofiev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dmitri_Shostakovich" title="Dmitri Shostakovich">Dmitri Shostakovich</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Schnittke" title="Alfred Schnittke">Alfred Schnittke</a>.
</p><p>Russian conservatories have turned out generations of famous soloists. Among the best known are violinists <a href="/wiki/Jascha_Heifetz" title="Jascha Heifetz">Jascha Heifetz</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Oistrakh" title="David Oistrakh">David Oistrakh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Kogan" title="Leonid Kogan">Leonid Kogan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gidon_Kremer" title="Gidon Kremer">Gidon Kremer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Vengerov" title="Maxim Vengerov">Maxim Vengerov</a>; cellists <a href="/wiki/Mstislav_Rostropovich" title="Mstislav Rostropovich">Mstislav Rostropovich</a>, <a href="/wiki/Natalia_Gutman" title="Natalia Gutman">Natalia Gutman</a>; pianists <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Horowitz" title="Vladimir Horowitz">Vladimir Horowitz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sviatoslav_Richter" title="Sviatoslav Richter">Sviatoslav Richter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Emil_Gilels" title="Emil Gilels">Emil Gilels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Sofronitsky" title="Vladimir Sofronitsky">Vladimir Sofronitsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evgeny_Kissin" title="Evgeny Kissin">Evgeny Kissin</a>; and vocalists <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Shalyapin" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Shalyapin">Fyodor Shalyapin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Reizen" title="Mark Reizen">Mark Reizen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elena_Obraztsova" title="Elena Obraztsova">Elena Obraztsova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamara_Sinyavskaya" title="Tamara Sinyavskaya">Tamara Sinyavskaya</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nina_Dorliak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nina Dorliak (page does not exist)">Nina Dorliak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Galina_Vishnevskaya" title="Galina Vishnevskaya">Galina Vishnevskaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Netrebko" title="Anna Netrebko">Anna Netrebko</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dmitry_Hvorostovsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Dmitry Hvorostovsky">Dmitry Hvorostovsky</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">&#91;398&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>During the early 20th century, Russian ballet dancers <a href="/wiki/Anna_Pavlova" title="Anna Pavlova">Anna Pavlova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vaslav_Nijinsky" title="Vaslav Nijinsky">Vaslav Nijinsky</a> rose to fame, and impresario <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Diaghilev" title="Sergei Diaghilev">Sergei Diaghilev</a> and his <a href="/wiki/Ballets_Russes" title="Ballets Russes">Ballets Russes</a>' travels abroad profoundly influenced the development of dance worldwide.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">&#91;399&#93;</a></sup> Soviet ballet preserved the perfected 19th-century traditions,<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">&#91;400&#93;</a></sup> and the Soviet Union's choreography schools produced many internationally famous stars, including <a href="/wiki/Galina_Ulanova" title="Galina Ulanova">Galina Ulanova</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maya_Plisetskaya" title="Maya Plisetskaya">Maya Plisetskaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rudolf_Nureyev" title="Rudolf Nureyev">Rudolf Nureyev</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Baryshnikov" title="Mikhail Baryshnikov">Mikhail Baryshnikov</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Ballet" title="Bolshoi Ballet">Bolshoi Ballet</a> in Moscow and the <a href="/wiki/Mariinsky_Ballet" title="Mariinsky Ballet">Mariinsky Ballet</a> in St Petersburg remain famous throughout the world.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">&#91;401&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern <a href="/wiki/Russian_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian rock">Russian rock</a> music takes its roots both in the Western <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock and roll</a> and <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>, and in traditions of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_bards" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian bards">Russian bards</a> of the Soviet era, such as <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vysotsky" title="Vladimir Vysotsky">Vladimir Vysotsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulat_Okudzhava" title="Bulat Okudzhava">Bulat Okudzhava</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">&#91;402&#93;</a></sup> Popular Russian rock groups include <a href="/wiki/Mashina_Vremeni" title="Mashina Vremeni">Mashina Vremeni</a>, <a href="/wiki/DDT_(band)" title="DDT (band)">DDT</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aquarium_(group)" class="mw-redirect" title="Aquarium (group)">Aquarium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alisa_(Russian_band)" title="Alisa (Russian band)">Alisa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kino_(band)" title="Kino (band)">Kino</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kipelov" title="Kipelov">Kipelov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nautilus_Pompilius_(band)" title="Nautilus Pompilius (band)">Nautilus Pompilius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aria_(band)" title="Aria (band)">Aria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grazhdanskaya_Oborona" title="Grazhdanskaya Oborona">Grazhdanskaya Oborona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Splean" title="Splean">Splean</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Korol_i_Shut" title="Korol i Shut">Korol i Shut</a>. <a href="/wiki/Russian_pop" title="Russian pop">Russian pop</a> music developed from what was known in the Soviet times as <i>estrada</i> into full-fledged industry, with some performers gaining wide international recognition, such as <a href="/wiki/T.A.T.u." title="T.A.T.u.">t.A.T.u.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nu_Virgos" title="Nu Virgos">Nu Virgos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vitas" title="Vitas">Vitas</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature_and_philosophy">Literature and philosophy</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_poets" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian poets">Russian poets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_playwrights" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian playwrights">Russian playwrights</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_novelists" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian novelists">Russian novelists</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Russian_science_fiction_and_fantasy" title="Russian science fiction and fantasy">Russian science fiction and fantasy</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Tolstoy,_05.1908.ws.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg/170px-Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="215" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg/255px-Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg/340px-Leo_Tolstoy%2C_05.1908.ws.jpg 2x" data-file-width="732" data-file-height="926" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Leo_Tolstoy,_05.1908.ws.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> is regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time.</div></div></div>
<p>In the 18th century, during the era of <a href="/wiki/Russian_Enlightenment" title="Russian Enlightenment">Russian Enlightenment</a>, the development of <a href="/wiki/Russian_literature" title="Russian literature">Russian literature</a> was boosted by the works of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lomonosov" title="Mikhail Lomonosov">Mikhail Lomonosov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Denis_Fonvizin" title="Denis Fonvizin">Denis Fonvizin</a>. By the early 19th century a modern national tradition had emerged, producing some of the greatest writers in Russian history. This period, known also as the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Golden Age of Russian Poetry">Golden Age of Russian Poetry</a>, began with <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a>, who is considered the founder of the modern Russian literary language and often described as the "Russian Shakespeare".<sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">&#91;403&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (August 2019)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> It continued with the poetry of <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Lermontov" title="Mikhail Lermontov">Mikhail Lermontov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Nekrasov" title="Nikolay Nekrasov">Nikolay Nekrasov</a>, dramas of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Ostrovsky" title="Alexander Ostrovsky">Alexander Ostrovsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anton_Chekhov" title="Anton Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a>, and the prose of <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Gogol" title="Nikolai Gogol">Nikolai Gogol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Turgenev" title="Ivan Turgenev">Ivan Turgenev</a>. <a href="/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy">Leo Tolstoy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoyevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Fyodor Dostoyevsky">Fyodor Dostoyevsky</a> have been described by literary critics as the greatest novelists of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">&#91;404&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">&#91;405&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/170px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/255px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/340px-Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="4000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vasily_Perov_-_%D0%9F%D0%BE%D1%80%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%82_%D0%A4.%D0%9C.%D0%94%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BE_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Dostoevsky" title="Fyodor Dostoevsky">Fyodor Dostoevsky</a></div></div></div>
<p>By the 1880s, the age of the great novelists was over, and short fiction and poetry became the dominant genres. The next several decades became known as the <a href="/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Russian_Poetry" title="Silver Age of Russian Poetry">Silver Age of Russian Poetry</a>, when the previously dominant <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">literary realism</a> was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Symbolism_(arts)" title="Symbolism (arts)">symbolism</a>. Leading authors of this era include such poets as <a href="/wiki/Valery_Bryusov" title="Valery Bryusov">Valery Bryusov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Ivanov_(poet)" title="Vyacheslav Ivanov (poet)">Vyacheslav Ivanov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Blok" title="Alexander Blok">Alexander Blok</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Gumilev" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Gumilev">Nikolay Gumilev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anna_Akhmatova" title="Anna Akhmatova">Anna Akhmatova</a>, and novelists <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Andreyev" title="Leonid Andreyev">Leonid Andreyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Bunin" title="Ivan Bunin">Ivan Bunin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maxim_Gorky" title="Maxim Gorky">Maxim Gorky</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Russian_philosophy" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian philosophy">Russian philosophy</a> blossomed in the 19th century, when it was defined initially by the opposition of <a href="/wiki/Westernizers" class="mw-redirect" title="Westernizers">Westernizers</a>, who advocated Western political and economical models, and <a href="/wiki/Slavophiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavophiles">Slavophiles</a>, who insisted on developing Russia as a unique civilization. The latter group includes <a href="/wiki/Nikolai_Danilevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolai Danilevsky">Nikolai Danilevsky</a> and <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Leontiev" title="Konstantin Leontiev">Konstantin Leontiev</a>, the founders of <a href="/wiki/Eurasianism" title="Eurasianism">eurasianism</a>. In its further development Russian philosophy was always marked by a deep connection to literature and interest in creativity, society, politics and nationalism; <a href="/wiki/Russian_cosmism" title="Russian cosmism">Russian cosmism</a> and religious philosophy were other major areas. Notable philosophers of the late 19th and the early 20th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Solovyov_(philosopher)" title="Vladimir Solovyov (philosopher)">Vladimir Solovyev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Bulgakov" title="Sergei Bulgakov">Sergei Bulgakov</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Vernadsky" title="Vladimir Vernadsky">Vladimir Vernadsky</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:AleksandrPushkin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/AleksandrPushkin.jpg/170px-AleksandrPushkin.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/AleksandrPushkin.jpg/255px-AleksandrPushkin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/AleksandrPushkin.jpg/340px-AleksandrPushkin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1268" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:AleksandrPushkin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Alexander_Pushkin" title="Alexander Pushkin">Alexander Pushkin</a> (portrait by <a href="/wiki/Vasily_Tropinin" title="Vasily Tropinin">Vasily Tropinin</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Revolution" title="Russian Revolution">Russian Revolution</a> of 1917 many prominent writers and philosophers left the country, including Bunin, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Nabokov" title="Vladimir Nabokov">Vladimir Nabokov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nikolay_Berdyayev" class="mw-redirect" title="Nikolay Berdyayev">Nikolay Berdyayev</a>, while a new generation of talented authors joined together in an effort to create a distinctive <a href="/wiki/Working-class_culture" title="Working-class culture">working-class culture</a> appropriate for the new Soviet state. In the 1930s censorship over literature was tightened in line with the policy of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_realism" title="Socialist realism">socialist realism</a>. In the late 1950s restrictions on literature were eased, and by the 1970s and 1980s, writers were increasingly ignoring official guidelines. Leading authors of the Soviet era include novelists <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Zamyatin" title="Yevgeny Zamyatin">Yevgeny Zamyatin</a> (emigrated), <a href="/wiki/Ilf_and_Petrov" title="Ilf and Petrov">Ilf and Petrov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Bulgakov" title="Mikhail Bulgakov">Mikhail Bulgakov</a> (censored) and <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Sholokhov" title="Mikhail Sholokhov">Mikhail Sholokhov</a>, and poets <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Mayakovsky" title="Vladimir Mayakovsky">Vladimir Mayakovsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yevgeny_Yevtushenko" title="Yevgeny Yevtushenko">Yevgeny Yevtushenko</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Andrey_Voznesensky" class="mw-redirect" title="Andrey Voznesensky">Andrey Voznesensky</a>.
</p><p>The Soviet Union was also a major producer of science fiction, written by authors like <a href="/wiki/Arkady_and_Boris_Strugatsky" title="Arkady and Boris Strugatsky">Arkady and Boris Strugatsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kir_Bulychov" class="mw-redirect" title="Kir Bulychov">Kir Bulychov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Belayev" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexander Belayev">Alexander Belayev</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Yefremov" title="Ivan Yefremov">Ivan Yefremov</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">&#91;406&#93;</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This citation requires a reference to the specific page or range of pages in which the material appears. (August 2019)">page&#160;needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Traditions of <a href="/wiki/Russian_science_fiction_and_fantasy" title="Russian science fiction and fantasy">Russian science fiction and fantasy</a> are continued today by numerous writers.
</p>
<h3><span id="Cinema.2C_animation_and_media"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema,_animation_and_media">Cinema, animation and media</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Russia" title="Cinema of Russia">Cinema of Russia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_animation" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian animation">Russian animation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Television_in_Russia" title="Television in Russia">Television in Russia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Russia" title="Media of Russia">Media of Russia</a></div>
