<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/170px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="240" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/255px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Vintage_Potemkin.jpg/340px-Vintage_Potemkin.jpg 2x" data-file-width="354" data-file-height="500" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Vintage_Potemkin.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Poster of <a href="/wiki/Battleship_Potemkin" title="Battleship Potemkin">Battleship Potemkin</a> (1925) by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a>, which was named the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">greatest film of all time</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Expo_58" title="Expo 58">Brussels World's Fair</a> in 1958</div></div></div>
<p>Russian and later <a href="/wiki/Soviet_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet cinema">Soviet cinema</a> was a hotbed of invention in the period immediately following 1917, resulting in world-renowned films such as <i><a href="/wiki/The_Battleship_Potemkin" class="mw-redirect" title="The Battleship Potemkin">The Battleship Potemkin</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Eisenstein" title="Sergei Eisenstein">Sergei Eisenstein</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-film_414-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-film-414">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup> Eisenstein was a student of filmmaker and theorist <a href="/wiki/Lev_Kuleshov" title="Lev Kuleshov">Lev Kuleshov</a>, who developed the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_montage_theory" title="Soviet montage theory">Soviet montage theory</a> of film editing at the world's first film school, the <a href="/wiki/All-Union_Institute_of_Cinematography" class="mw-redirect" title="All-Union Institute of Cinematography">All-Union Institute of Cinematography</a>. <a href="/wiki/Dziga_Vertov" title="Dziga Vertov">Dziga Vertov</a>, whose <i>kino-glaz</i> ("film-eye") theory—that the camera, like the human eye, is best used to explore real life—had a huge impact on the development of documentary film making and cinema realism. The subsequent state policy of socialist realism somewhat limited creativity; however, many Soviet films in this style were artistically successful, including <i><a href="/wiki/Chapaev_(film)" title="Chapaev (film)">Chapaev</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Cranes_Are_Flying" title="The Cranes Are Flying">The Cranes Are Flying</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Ballad_of_a_Soldier" title="Ballad of a Soldier">Ballad of a Soldier</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-film_414-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-film-414">&#91;407&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1960s and 1970s saw a greater variety of artistic styles in Soviet cinema. <a href="/wiki/Eldar_Ryazanov" title="Eldar Ryazanov">Eldar Ryazanov</a>'s and <a href="/wiki/Leonid_Gaidai" title="Leonid Gaidai">Leonid Gaidai</a>'s comedies of that time were immensely popular, with many of the catch phrases still in use today. In 1961–68 <a href="/wiki/Sergey_Bondarchuk" class="mw-redirect" title="Sergey Bondarchuk">Sergey Bondarchuk</a> directed an <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Oscar</a>-winning <a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace_(film_series)" title="War and Peace (film series)">film adaptation</a> of Leo Tolstoy's epic <i><a href="/wiki/War_and_Peace" title="War and Peace">War and Peace</a></i>, which was <a href="/wiki/The_most_expensive_film" class="mw-redirect" title="The most expensive film">the most expensive film</a> made in the Soviet Union.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">&#91;408&#93;</a></sup> In 1969, <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Motyl" title="Vladimir Motyl">Vladimir Motyl</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/White_Sun_of_the_Desert" title="White Sun of the Desert">White Sun of the Desert</a></i> was released, a very popular film in a genre of <a href="/wiki/Ostern" title="Ostern">ostern</a>; the film is traditionally watched by <a href="/wiki/Cosmonauts" class="mw-redirect" title="Cosmonauts">cosmonauts</a> before any trip into space.<sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">&#91;409&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg/220px-Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="136" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg/330px-Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg/440px-Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1100" data-file-height="678" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Medvedev_-_Russia_Today_3.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dmitry Medvedev in the <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington</a> studio of <a href="/wiki/Russia_Today_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia Today TV">Russia Today TV</a> with <a href="/wiki/Margarita_Simonyan" title="Margarita Simonyan">Margarita Simonyan</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Russian_animation" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian animation">Russian animation</a> dates back to late <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> times. During the Soviet era, <a href="/wiki/Soyuzmultfilm" title="Soyuzmultfilm">Soyuzmultfilm</a> studio was the largest animation producer. Soviet animators developed a great variety of pioneering techniques and aesthetic styles, with prominent directors including <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Ivanov-Vano" title="Ivan Ivanov-Vano">Ivan Ivanov-Vano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fyodor_Khitruk" title="Fyodor Khitruk">Fyodor Khitruk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Tatarsky" class="mw-redirect" title="Aleksandr Tatarsky">Aleksandr Tatarsky</a>. Many Soviet cartoon heroes such as the Russian-style <a href="/wiki/Winnie-the-Pooh" title="Winnie-the-Pooh">Winnie-the-Pooh</a>, cute little <a href="/wiki/Cheburashka" title="Cheburashka">Cheburashka</a>, Wolf and Hare from <i><a href="/wiki/Nu,_Pogodi!" class="mw-redirect" title="Nu, Pogodi!">Nu, Pogodi!</a></i>, are iconic images in Russia and many surrounding countries.
</p><p>The late 1980s and 1990s were a period of crisis in Russian cinema and animation. Although Russian filmmakers became free to express themselves, state subsidies were drastically reduced, resulting in fewer films produced. The early years of the 21st century have brought increased viewership and subsequent prosperity to the industry on the back of the economic revival. Production levels are already higher than in Britain and Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">&#91;410&#93;</a></sup> Russia's total box-office revenue in 2007 was $565&#160;million, up 37% from the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">&#91;411&#93;</a></sup> In 2002 the <i><a href="/wiki/Russian_Ark" title="Russian Ark">Russian Ark</a></i> became the first feature film ever to be shot in a single take. The traditions of Soviet animation were developed recently by such directors as <a href="/wiki/Aleksandr_Petrov_(animator)" title="Aleksandr Petrov (animator)">Aleksandr Petrov</a> and studios like <a href="/wiki/Melnitsa_Animation" class="mw-redirect" title="Melnitsa Animation">Melnitsa Animation</a>.
</p><p>While there were few stations or channels in the Soviet time, in the past two decades many new state and privately owned <a href="/wiki/Russian_language_radio_stations" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian language radio stations">radio stations</a> and <a href="/wiki/TV_in_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="TV in Russia">TV channels</a> have appeared. In 2005 a state-run English language <a href="/wiki/Russia_Today_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Russia Today TV">Russia Today TV</a> started broadcasting, and its Arabic version <a href="/wiki/Rusiya_Al-Yaum" class="mw-redirect" title="Rusiya Al-Yaum">Rusiya Al-Yaum</a> was launched in 2007. Censorship and <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Russia" title="Media freedom in Russia">Media freedom in Russia</a> has always been a main theme of Russian media.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Russia" title="Sport in Russia">Sport in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg/220px-Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg/330px-Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg/440px-Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Russia_vs_Egypt_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Russia_national_football_team" title="Russia national football team">Russia national football team</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a> in Russia</div></div></div>
<p>Soviet and later <a href="/wiki/Russia_at_the_Olympics" title="Russia at the Olympics">Russian athletes</a> have always been in the top four for the number of gold medals collected at the Summer Olympics. Soviet gymnasts, track-and-field athletes, weightlifters, wrestlers, boxers, fencers, shooters, cross country skiers, biathletes, speed skaters and figure skaters were consistently among the best in the world, along with Soviet basketball, handball, volleyball and ice hockey players.<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">&#91;412&#93;</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1980_Summer_Olympics" title="1980 Summer Olympics">1980 Summer Olympics</a> were held in Moscow while the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> were hosted in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg/220px-%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg/330px-%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/28/%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg/440px-%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3500" data-file-height="2333" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:%D0%91%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B5%D1%82-%D0%A5%D0%BE%D0%BB%D0%BB_%D0%9A%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%81%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0%D1%80_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Basket-Hall_Krasnodar" title="Basket-Hall Krasnodar">Basket-Hall Krasnodar</a>, home of <a href="/wiki/PBC_Lokomotiv_Kuban" title="PBC Lokomotiv Kuban">PBC Lokomotiv Kuban</a>, during a <a href="/wiki/VTB_United_League" title="VTB United League">VTB United League</a> game</div></div></div>
<p>Although <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey" title="Ice hockey">ice hockey</a> was only introduced during the Soviet era, the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Soviet Union national ice hockey team">Soviet Union national team</a> managed to win gold at almost all the <a href="/wiki/Ice_hockey_at_the_Olympic_Games" title="Ice hockey at the Olympic Games">Olympics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice_Hockey_World_Championships" title="Ice Hockey World Championships">World Championships</a> they contested. Russian players <a href="/wiki/Valery_Kharlamov" class="mw-redirect" title="Valery Kharlamov">Valery Kharlamov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sergei_Makarov_(ice_hockey)" title="Sergei Makarov (ice hockey)">Sergei Makarov</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vyacheslav_Fetisov" class="mw-redirect" title="Vyacheslav Fetisov">Vyacheslav Fetisov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladislav_Tretiak" title="Vladislav Tretiak">Vladislav Tretiak</a> hold four of six positions in the <a href="/wiki/IIHF" class="mw-redirect" title="IIHF">IIHF</a> <i>Team of the Century</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">&#91;413&#93;</a></sup> Russia has not won the Olympic ice hockey tournament since the <a href="/wiki/Unified_Team_at_the_Olympics" title="Unified Team at the Olympics">Unified Team</a> won gold in 1992. Russia won the <a href="/wiki/1993_IIHF_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="1993 IIHF World Championship">1993</a>, <a href="/wiki/2008_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2008 IIHF World Championship">2008</a>, <a href="/wiki/2009_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2009 IIHF World Championship">2009</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">&#91;414&#93;</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/2012_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2012 IIHF World Championship">2012</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_IIHF_World_Championship" title="2014 IIHF World Championship">2014 IIHF World Championships</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">&#91;415&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League" title="Kontinental Hockey League">Kontinental Hockey League</a> (KHL) was founded in 2008 as a successor to the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Superleague" title="Russian Superleague">Russian Superleague</a>. It is ranked the top hockey league in Europe as of 2009<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>,<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">&#91;416&#93;</a></sup> and the second-best in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">&#91;417&#93;</a></sup> It is an international professional ice hockey league in <a href="/wiki/Eurasia" title="Eurasia">Eurasia</a> and consists of 29 teams, of which 21 are based in Russia and 7 more are located in <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan" title="Kazakhstan">Kazakhstan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovakia" title="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. KHL is on the 4th place by attendance in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">&#91;418&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Bandy" title="Bandy">Bandy</a>, also known as <a href="/wiki/Russian_hockey" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian hockey">Russian hockey</a>, is another traditionally popular ice sport.<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">&#91;419&#93;</a></sup> The Soviet Union won all the <a href="/wiki/Bandy_World_Championship" title="Bandy World Championship">Bandy World Championships</a> for men between 1957–79<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">&#91;420&#93;</a></sup> and some thereafter too. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Russia has continuously been one of the most successful teams, winning many world championships.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg/220px-Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg/330px-Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/52/Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg/440px-Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="334" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Dmitry_Medvedev_20_May_2008-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Dmitry Medvedev with the <a href="/wiki/Russia_men%27s_national_ice_hockey_team" title="Russia men&#39;s national ice hockey team">Russia men's national ice hockey team</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg/220px-2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg/330px-2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg/440px-2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2017_Gagarin_Cup_Playoffs_-_Western_Semifinals_-_SKA_v_Dinamo_Msk_-_Game_3_-_Start_of_the_game.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/VTB_Ice_Palace" class="mw-redirect" title="VTB Ice Palace">VTB Ice Palace</a> during a game of <a href="/wiki/Kontinental_Hockey_League" title="Kontinental Hockey League">KHL</a>, a league considered to be the second-best in the world</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a> is one of the most popular sports in modern Russia. The Soviet national team became the first European Champions by winning <a href="/wiki/Euro_1960" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1960">Euro 1960</a>. Appearing in four <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cups</a> from 1958 to 1970, <a href="/wiki/Lev_Yashin" title="Lev Yashin">Lev Yashin</a> is regarded as one of the greatest goalkeepers in the history of football, and was chosen on the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup_Dream_Team" title="FIFA World Cup Dream Team">FIFA World Cup Dream Team</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FIFA_428-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIFA-428">&#91;421&#93;</a></sup> The Soviet national team reached the finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_1988" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 1988">Euro 1988</a>. In 1956 and 1988, the Soviet Union won gold at the <a href="/wiki/Football_at_the_Summer_Olympics#Men&#39;s_results" title="Football at the Summer Olympics">Olympic football tournament</a>. Russian clubs <a href="/wiki/PFC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PFC CSKA Moscow">CSKA Moscow</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zenit_St_Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Zenit St Petersburg">Zenit St Petersburg</a> won the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Cup">UEFA Cup</a> in 2005 and 2008. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_football_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national football team">Russian national football team</a> reached the semi-finals of <a href="/wiki/Euro_2008" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2008">Euro 2008</a>, losing only to the eventual champions Spain. Russia was the host nation for the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>. The matches were held from 14 June to 15 July 2018 in the stadiums of 11 host cities located in the European part of the country and in the Ural region.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">&#91;422&#93;</a></sup> This was the first <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a> World Cup ever held in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, and the first held in Europe since 2006. Russia will also host games of <a href="/wiki/Euro_2020" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2020">Euro 2020</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg/220px-2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg/330px-2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg/440px-2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1152" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2018_World_Cup_Round_of_16_-_Russia_v_Spain.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Luzhniki_Stadium" title="Luzhniki Stadium">Luzhniki Stadium</a> in <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a>, which hosted games of the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national basketball team">Russian national basketball team</a> won the <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket_2007" title="EuroBasket 2007">European Basketball Championship</a>. The Russian basketball club <a href="/wiki/PBC_CSKA_Moscow" title="PBC CSKA Moscow">PBC CSKA Moscow</a> is one of the top teams in Europe, winning the <a href="/wiki/Euroleague" class="mw-redirect" title="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> in <a href="/wiki/2005%E2%80%9306_Euroleague" title="2005–06 Euroleague">2006</a> and <a href="/wiki/2007%E2%80%9308_Euroleague" title="2007–08 Euroleague">2008</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Larisa_Latynina" title="Larisa Latynina">Larisa Latynina</a>, who currently holds the record for the most gold Olympic medals won by a woman, established the USSR as the dominant force in gymnastics for many years.<sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">&#91;423&#93;</a></sup> Today, Russia is the leading nation in <a href="/wiki/Rhythmic_gymnastics" title="Rhythmic gymnastics">rhythmic gymnastics</a> with <a href="/wiki/Yevgeniya_Kanayeva" title="Yevgeniya Kanayeva">Yevgeniya Kanayeva</a>. Double 50&#160;m and 100&#160;m freestyle Olympic gold medalist <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Popov_(swimmer)" title="Alexander Popov (swimmer)">Alexander Popov</a> is widely considered the greatest sprint swimmer in history.<sup id="cite_ref-431" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-431">&#91;424&#93;</a></sup> Russian <a href="/wiki/Synchronized_swimming" class="mw-redirect" title="Synchronized swimming">synchronized swimming</a> is the best in the world, with almost all gold medals at Olympics and World Championships having been swept by Russians in recent decades. <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating" title="Figure skating">Figure skating</a> is another popular sport in Russia, especially <a href="/wiki/Pair_skating" title="Pair skating">pair skating</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ice_dancing" class="mw-redirect" title="Ice dancing">ice dancing</a>. With the exception of <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2010_Winter_Olympics" title="Figure skating at the 2010 Winter Olympics">2010</a> and <a href="/wiki/Figure_skating_at_the_2018_Winter_Olympics" title="Figure skating at the 2018 Winter Olympics">2018</a> a Soviet or Russian pair has won gold at every Winter Olympics since 1964.
</p><p>Since the end of the Soviet era, tennis has grown in popularity and Russia has produced a number of famous players, including <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>. In martial arts, Russia produced the sport <a href="/wiki/Sambo_(martial_art)" title="Sambo (martial art)">Sambo</a> and renowned fighters, like <a href="/wiki/Fedor_Emelianenko" title="Fedor Emelianenko">Fedor Emelianenko</a>. <a href="/wiki/Chess" title="Chess">Chess</a> is a widely popular pastime in Russia; from 1927, Russian grandmasters have held the <a href="/wiki/World_chess_championship" class="mw-redirect" title="World chess championship">world chess championship</a> almost continuously.<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">&#91;425&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a> were held in Sochi in the south of Russia. In 2016 the <a href="/wiki/McLaren_Report" title="McLaren Report">McLaren Report</a> found evidence of widespread <a href="/wiki/Doping_in_Russia" title="Doping in Russia">state-sponsored doping</a> and an institutional conspiracy to cover up Russian competitors' positive drug tests.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">&#91;426&#93;</a></sup> As of 1&#160;December&#160;2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Russia&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup> 25 athletes are disqualified, 11 medals are stripped.
</p><p>Formula One is also becoming increasingly popular in Russia. In 2010 <a href="/wiki/Vitaly_Petrov" title="Vitaly Petrov">Vitaly Petrov</a> of <a href="/wiki/Vyborg" title="Vyborg">Vyborg</a> became the first Russian to drive in Formula One, and was soon followed by a second – <a href="/wiki/Daniil_Kvyat" title="Daniil Kvyat">Daniil Kvyat</a>, from <a href="/wiki/Ufa" title="Ufa">Ufa</a> – in 2014. There had only been two Russian Grands Prix (in 1913 and 1914), but the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Grand_Prix" title="Russian Grand Prix">Russian Grand Prix</a> returned as part of the <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> season in <a href="/wiki/2014_Formula_One_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Formula One season">2014</a>, as part of a six-year deal.<sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">&#91;427&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Doping_in_Russia" title="Doping in Russia">Doping in Russia</a></div>
<p>Russia has the most Olympic medals stripped for doping violations (<a href="/wiki/List_of_stripped_Olympic_medals" title="List of stripped Olympic medals">51</a>), the most of any country, four times the number of the runner-up, and more than a third of the global total, and 129 athletes caught <a href="/wiki/Doping_at_the_Olympic_Games" title="Doping at the Olympic Games">doping at the Olympics</a>, also the most of any country. From 2011 to 2015, more than a thousand Russian competitors in various sports, including summer, winter, and Paralympic sports, benefited from a state-sponsored cover-up,<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">&#91;428&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">&#91;429&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYT161209_437-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT161209-437">&#91;430&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Guardian161209_438-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian161209-438">&#91;431&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">&#91;432&#93;</a></sup> with no indication that the program has ceased since then.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">&#91;433&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="National_holidays_and_symbols">National holidays and symbols</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Russia" title="Public holidays in Russia">Public holidays in Russia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_icons_of_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Cultural icons of Russia">Cultural icons of Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Alyye_parusa.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Alyye_parusa.jpg/220px-Alyye_parusa.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Alyye_parusa.jpg/330px-Alyye_parusa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Alyye_parusa.jpg/440px-Alyye_parusa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1195" data-file-height="795" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Alyye_parusa.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Scarlet_Sails_(tradition)" title="Scarlet Sails (tradition)">Scarlet Sails</a> celebration on the <a href="/wiki/Neva" class="mw-redirect" title="Neva">Neva</a> river in <a href="/wiki/Saint_Petersburg" title="Saint Petersburg">Saint Petersburg</a></div></div></div>
<p>There are seven <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Russia" title="Public holidays in Russia">public holidays in Russia</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">&#91;434&#93;</a></sup> except those always celebrated on Sunday. Russian New Year traditions resemble those of the Western Christmas, with <a href="/wiki/New_Year_Tree" class="mw-redirect" title="New Year Tree">New Year Trees</a> and gifts, and <a href="/wiki/Ded_Moroz" title="Ded Moroz">Ded Moroz</a> (<a href="/wiki/Father_Frost" class="mw-redirect" title="Father Frost">Father Frost</a>) playing the same role as <a href="/wiki/Santa_Claus" title="Santa Claus">Santa Claus</a>. <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Christmas" class="mw-redirect" title="Orthodox Christmas">Orthodox Christmas</a> falls on 7 January, because the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Orthodox_Church" title="Russian Orthodox Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a> still follows the <a href="/wiki/Julian_calendar" title="Julian calendar">Julian calendar</a>, and all Orthodox holidays are 13 days after Western ones. Two other major Christian holidays are Easter and <a href="/wiki/Trinity_Sunday" title="Trinity Sunday">Trinity Sunday</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kurban_Bayram" class="mw-redirect" title="Kurban Bayram">Kurban Bayram</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uraza_Bayram" class="mw-redirect" title="Uraza Bayram">Uraza Bayram</a> are celebrated by Russian Muslims.
</p><p>Further Russian public holidays include <a href="/wiki/Defender_of_the_Fatherland_Day" title="Defender of the Fatherland Day">Defender of the Fatherland Day</a> (23 February), which honors Russian men, especially those serving in the army; <a href="/wiki/International_Women%27s_Day" title="International Women&#39;s Day">International Women's Day</a> (8 March), which combines the traditions of <a href="/wiki/Mother%27s_Day" title="Mother&#39;s Day">Mother's Day</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valentine%27s_Day" title="Valentine&#39;s Day">Valentine's Day</a>; <a href="/wiki/Spring_and_Labor_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="Spring and Labor Day">Spring and Labor Day</a> (1 May); <a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(May_9)" class="mw-redirect" title="Victory Day (May 9)">Victory Day</a> (9 May); <a href="/wiki/Russia_Day" title="Russia Day">Russia Day</a> (12 June); and <a href="/wiki/Unity_Day_(Russia)" title="Unity Day (Russia)">Unity Day</a> (4 November), commemorating the popular uprising which expelled the Polish occupation force from Moscow in 1612.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Victory_Day_(May_9)" class="mw-redirect" title="Victory Day (May 9)">Victory Day</a> is the second most popular holiday in Russia; it commemorates the victory over <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> and its allies in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Patriotic_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Patriotic War">Great Patriotic War</a>. A huge <a href="/wiki/Military_parade" title="Military parade">military parade</a>, hosted by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">President of Russia</a>, is annually organised in Moscow on <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>. Similar parades take place in all major Russian cities and cities with the status <i><a href="/wiki/Hero_city" class="mw-redirect" title="Hero city">Hero city</a></i> or <i>City of Military Glory</i>.
</p><p>Popular non-public holidays include <a href="/wiki/Old_New_Year" title="Old New Year">Old New Year</a> (the New Year according to the Julian Calendar on 14 January), <a href="/wiki/Tatiana_Day" title="Tatiana Day">Tatiana Day</a> (students holiday on 25 January), <a href="/wiki/Maslenitsa" title="Maslenitsa">Maslenitsa</a> (a pre-Christian spring holiday a week before the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lent" title="Great Lent">Great Lent</a>), <a href="/wiki/Cosmonautics_Day" title="Cosmonautics Day">Cosmonautics Day</a> (in tribute to the first human trip into space), <a href="/wiki/Ivan_Kupala_Day" class="mw-redirect" title="Ivan Kupala Day">Ivan Kupala Day</a> (another pre-Christian holiday on 7 July) and <a href="/wiki/Peter_and_Fevronia_Day" title="Peter and Fevronia Day">Peter and Fevronia Day</a> (which takes place on 8 July and is the Russian analogue of Valentine's Day, focusing, however, on family love and fidelity).
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Russian_Dolls_(4891096981).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg/220px-Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg/330px-Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg/440px-Russian_Dolls_%284891096981%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="2848" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Russian_Dolls_(4891096981).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Matryoshka_doll" title="Matryoshka doll">Matryoshka doll</a> taken apart</div></div></div>
<p>State symbols of Russia include the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> <a href="/wiki/Double-headed_eagle" title="Double-headed eagle">double-headed eagle</a>, combined with <a href="/wiki/St._George_of_Moscow" class="mw-redirect" title="St. George of Moscow">St. George of Moscow</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Russian_coat_of_arms" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian coat of arms">Russian coat of arms</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_flag" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian flag">Russian flag</a> dates from the late <a href="/wiki/Tsardom_of_Russia" title="Tsardom of Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a> period and has been widely used since the time of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_anthem" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian anthem">Russian anthem</a> shares its music with the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Anthem" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet Anthem">Soviet Anthem</a>, though not the lyrics. The imperial <a href="/wiki/Motto" title="Motto">motto</a> <i>God is with us</i> and the Soviet motto <i>Proletarians of all countries, unite!</i> are now obsolete and no new motto has replaced them. The <a href="/wiki/Hammer_and_sickle" title="Hammer and sickle">hammer and sickle</a> and the full <a href="/wiki/Soviet_coat_of_arms" class="mw-redirect" title="Soviet coat of arms">Soviet coat of arms</a> are still widely seen in Russian cities as a part of old architectural decorations. The Soviet <a href="/wiki/Red_Star" class="mw-redirect" title="Red Star">Red Stars</a> are also encountered, often on military equipment and war memorials. The <a href="/wiki/Red_Banner" title="Red Banner">Red Banner</a> continues to be honored, especially the <a href="/wiki/Banner_of_Victory" class="mw-redirect" title="Banner of Victory">Banner of Victory</a> of 1945.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Matryoshka_doll" title="Matryoshka doll">Matryoshka doll</a> is a recognizable symbol of Russia, and the towers of <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" title="Moscow Kremlin">Moscow Kremlin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Basil%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Basil&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Basil's Cathedral</a> in Moscow are Russia's main architectural icons. <a href="/wiki/Cheburashka" title="Cheburashka">Cheburashka</a> is a mascot of the <a href="/wiki/Russian_national_Olympic_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian national Olympic team">Russian national Olympic team</a>. <a href="/wiki/St._Mary" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Mary">St. Mary</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Nicholas" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Nicholas">St. Nicholas</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Andrew" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Andrew">St. Andrew</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._George" class="mw-redirect" title="St. George">St. George</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Alexander_Nevsky" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Alexander Nevsky">St. Alexander Nevsky</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Sergius_of_Radonezh" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Sergius of Radonezh">St. Sergius of Radonezh</a> and <a href="/wiki/St._Seraphim_of_Sarov" class="mw-redirect" title="St. Seraphim of Sarov">St. Seraphim of Sarov</a> are Russia's <a href="/wiki/Patron_saint" title="Patron saint">patron saints</a>. <a href="/wiki/Chamomile" title="Chamomile">Chamomile</a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_flower" class="mw-redirect" title="National flower">national flower</a>, while <a href="/wiki/Birch" title="Birch">birch</a> is the <a href="/wiki/National_tree" class="mw-redirect" title="National tree">national tree</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Russian_bear" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian bear">Russian bear</a> is an animal symbol and <a href="/wiki/Mother_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Mother Russia">Mother Russia</a> a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of Russia, though the bear image has a Western origin and Russians themselves have accepted it only fairly recently.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Russia" title="Tourism in Russia">Tourism in Russia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg/220px-Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg/330px-Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg/440px-Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3200" data-file-height="2119" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Grand_Cascade_of_Peterhof_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace#The_Grand_Cascade_and_Samson_Fountain" title="Peterhof Palace">Grand Cascade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof</a>, a popular tourist destination in Saint Petersburg</div></div></div>
<p>Tourism in Russia has seen rapid growth since the late Soviet period, first domestic tourism and then international tourism, fueled by the rich cultural heritage and great natural variety of the country. Major tourist routes in Russia include a journey around the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Ring_(Russia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Ring (Russia)">Golden Ring</a> <a href="/wiki/Theme_route" class="mw-redirect" title="Theme route">theme route</a> of ancient cities, cruises on the big rivers like the <a href="/wiki/Volga" class="mw-redirect" title="Volga">Volga</a>, and long journeys on the famous <a href="/wiki/Trans-Siberian_Railway" title="Trans-Siberian Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a>. In 2013, Russia was visited by 28.4 million <a href="/wiki/Tourist" class="mw-redirect" title="Tourist">tourists</a>; it is the ninth most visited country in the world and the seventh most visited in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">&#91;435&#93;</a></sup> The number of Western visitors dropped in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">&#91;436&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mamaev_kurgan_(%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG/170px-Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG/255px-Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG/340px-Mamaev_kurgan_%28%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2240" data-file-height="3011" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mamaev_kurgan_(%D0%9E%D0%9A%D0%9D).JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Motherland_Calls" title="The Motherland Calls">The Motherland Calls</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/Volgograd" title="Volgograd">Volgograd</a> is the tallest statue of a woman in the world (not including pedestals).</div></div></div>
<p>The most visited destinations in Russia are Moscow and Saint Petersburg, the current and former capitals of the country. Recognized as <a href="/wiki/World_Cities" class="mw-redirect" title="World Cities">World Cities</a>, they feature such world-renowned museums as the <a href="/wiki/Tretyakov_Gallery" title="Tretyakov Gallery">Tretyakov Gallery</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hermitage_Museum" title="Hermitage Museum">Hermitage</a>, famous theaters like <a href="/wiki/Bolshoi_Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolshoi Theater">Bolshoi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mariinsky_Theater" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariinsky Theater">Mariinsky</a>, ornate churches like Saint Basil's Cathedral, <a href="/wiki/Cathedral_of_Christ_the_Saviour" title="Cathedral of Christ the Saviour">Cathedral of Christ the Saviour</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Isaac%27s_Cathedral" title="Saint Isaac&#39;s Cathedral">Saint Isaac's Cathedral</a> and <a href="/wiki/Church_of_the_Savior_on_Blood" title="Church of the Savior on Blood">Church of the Savior on Blood</a>, impressive fortifications like the <a href="/wiki/Moscow_Kremlin" title="Moscow Kremlin">Kremlin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_and_Paul_Fortress" title="Peter and Paul Fortress">Peter and Paul Fortress</a>, beautiful squares and streets like <a href="/wiki/Red_Square" title="Red Square">Red Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palace_Square" title="Palace Square">Palace Square</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tverskaya_Street" title="Tverskaya Street">Tverskaya Street</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nevsky_Prospect" title="Nevsky Prospect">Nevsky Prospect</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Arbat_Street" title="Arbat Street">Arbat Street</a>. Rich palaces and parks are found in the former imperial residences in suburbs of <a href="/wiki/Moscow" title="Moscow">Moscow</a> (<a href="/wiki/Kolomenskoye" title="Kolomenskoye">Kolomenskoye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tsaritsyno_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Tsaritsyno Park">Tsaritsyno</a>) and St Petersburg (<a href="/wiki/Peterhof_Palace" title="Peterhof Palace">Peterhof</a>, <a href="/wiki/Strelna" title="Strelna">Strelna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oranienbaum,_Russia" title="Oranienbaum, Russia">Oranienbaum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gatchina_Palace" title="Gatchina Palace">Gatchina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pavlovsk_Palace" title="Pavlovsk Palace">Pavlovsk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tsarskoye_Selo" title="Tsarskoye Selo">Tsarskoye Selo</a>). Moscow displays <a href="/wiki/Stalinist_architecture" title="Stalinist architecture">Soviet architecture</a> at its best, along with <a href="/wiki/Moscow_International_Business_Center" title="Moscow International Business Center">modern skyscrapers</a>, while St Petersburg, nicknamed <i>Venice of the North</i>, boasts of its classical architecture, many rivers, canals and <a href="/wiki/Bridges_in_Saint_Petersburg" class="mw-redirect" title="Bridges in Saint Petersburg">bridges</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kazan" title="Kazan">Kazan</a>, the capital of <a href="/wiki/Tatarstan" title="Tatarstan">Tatarstan</a>, shows a mix of Christian Russian and Muslim Tatar cultures. The city has registered a brand <i>The Third Capital of Russia</i>, though a number of other major cities compete for this status, including <a href="/wiki/Novosibirsk" title="Novosibirsk">Novosibirsk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yekaterinburg" title="Yekaterinburg">Yekaterinburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nizhny_Novgorod" title="Nizhny Novgorod">Nizhny Novgorod</a>.
</p><p>The warm subtropical Black Sea coast of Russia is the site for a number of popular sea resorts, like <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a>, the follow-up host of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Winter_Olympics" title="2014 Winter Olympics">2014 Winter Olympics</a>. The mountains of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Caucasus" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Caucasus">Northern Caucasus</a> contain popular ski resorts such as <a href="/wiki/Dombay,_Russia" class="mw-redirect" title="Dombay, Russia">Dombay</a>. The most famous natural destination in Russia is <a href="/wiki/Lake_Baikal" title="Lake Baikal">Lake Baikal</a>, <i>the Blue Eye of Siberia</i>. This unique lake, the oldest and deepest in the world, has crystal-clear waters and is surrounded by <a href="/wiki/Taiga" title="Taiga">taiga</a>-covered mountains. Other popular natural destinations include <a href="/wiki/Kamchatka" class="mw-redirect" title="Kamchatka">Kamchatka</a> with its volcanoes and geysers, <a href="/wiki/Karelia" title="Karelia">Karelia</a> with its lakes and <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a> rocks, the snowy <a href="/wiki/Altai_Mountains" title="Altai Mountains">Altai Mountains</a>, and the wild steppes of <a href="/wiki/Tuva" title="Tuva">Tuva</a>.
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-6"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-6">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Soviet_of_Russia" title="Supreme Soviet of Russia">Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR</a> ratified the accords on 12 December, denouncing the 1922 treaty.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">On 25 December, Russian SFSR was renamed the Russian Federation and the following day the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Soviet_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union">Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union</a> ratified the accords, effectively dissolving the Soviet Union.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-crimealanguages-342"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-crimealanguages_342-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-crimealanguages_342-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">Annexed by Russia in 2014</a> Voted to join Russian Federation in 2014; recognized as a part of <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> by most of the international community.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-ArenaIslam-357"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ArenaIslam_357-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Sreda Arena Atlas 2012 did not count the populations of two Muslim-majority federal subjects of Russia, namely <a href="/wiki/Chechnya" title="Chechnya">Chechnya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ingushetia" title="Ingushetia">Ingushetia</a>, which together had a population of nearly 2 million, thus the proportion of Muslims may be slightly underestimated.<sup id="cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_356-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-356">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-359"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-359">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The category included <a href="/wiki/Slavic_Native_Faith" title="Slavic Native Faith">Rodnovers</a> accounting for 44%, and other Pagan religions and Siberian Tengrists and shamans accounting for the rest.<sup id="cite_ref-Filina_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filina-358">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: decimal;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Crimean Peninsula, claimed and de facto <a href="/wiki/Annexation_of_Crimea_by_the_Russian_Federation" title="Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation">administered</a> by Russia, is <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_Resolution_68/262" title="United Nations General Assembly Resolution 68/262">recognized</a> as territory of <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> by a majority of UN member nations.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">&#91;1&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Areanote-10"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Areanote_10-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">When including the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Crimea" title="Republic of Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sevastopol" title="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>, the total area of Russia rises to 17,125,191&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (6,612,073&#160;sq&#160;mi)<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">&#91;6&#93;</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://unstats.un.org/unsd/publications/pocketbook/files/world-stats-pocketbook-2016.pdf#page=182">"World Statistics Pocketbook 2016 edition"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs. Statistics Division<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">24 April</span> 2018</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=World+Statistics+Pocketbook+2016+edition&amp;rft.pub=United+Nations+Department+of+Economic+and+Social+Affairs.+Statistics+Division&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Funstats.un.org%2Funsd%2Fpublications%2Fpocketbook%2Ffiles%2Fworld-stats-pocketbook-2016.pdf%23page%3D182&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" <li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation book">Chaliand, Gérard (1967). Introduction. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1xOTdQWlpGYC"><i>The Mongol Empire: Its Rise and Legacy</i></a>. By <a href="/wiki/Michael_Prawdin" title="Michael Prawdin">Prawdin, Michael</a>. Transaction Publishers. pp.&#160;512–550. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Book_Number" title="International Standard Book Number">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-1-4128-2897-0" title="Special:BookSources/978-1-4128-2897-0"><bdi>978-1-4128-2897-0</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=Introduction&amp;rft.btitle=The+Mongol+Empire%3A+Its+Rise+and+Legacy&amp;rft.pages=512-550&amp;rft.pub=Transaction+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1967&amp;rft.isbn=978-1-4128-2897-0&amp;rft.aulast=Chaliand&amp;rft.aufirst=G%C3%A9rard&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1xOTdQWlpGYC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>

<li id="cite_note-164"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-164">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://wikileaks.org/gifiles/docs/27/2704254_re-russian-reserve-forces-.html">"The Global Intelligence Files"</a>. <i>wikileaks.org</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 April</span> 2015</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=wikileaks.org&amp;rft.atitle=The+Global+Intelligence+Files&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwikileaks.org%2Fgifiles%2Fdocs%2F27%2F2704254_re-russian-reserve-forces-.html&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> IISS listed total reserves as 20,000,000 for many years, assuming a Soviet-style callup. <li id="cite_note-341"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-341">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_chuvash/chapter/1/#block_8">"Конституция Чувашской Республики (принята Государственным Советом Чувашской Республики 30 ноября 2000 г.) / Глава 1. <li id="cite_note-Mari-El-350"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Mari-El_350-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Mari-El_350-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://constitution.garant.ru/region/cons_mariy/chapter/1/#block_1150">"Конституция Республики Марий Эл (принята Конституционным Собранием Республики Марий Эл 24 июня 1995 г.) / Глава I. <li id="cite_note-ArenaAtlas2012-356"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_356-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_356-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ArenaAtlas2012_356-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://docviewer.yandex.com/view/0/?*=rvAv5PGTc%2Fw%2BBFV6QOUZtaf5gYF7InVybCI6InlhLWRpc2stcHVibGljOi8vMWV1aDl5RDFpcnZKeVZNNSswWWFaZktqRFhoOXZDNWhldUlGTU5uQU4zQT0iLCJ0aXRsZSI6IlNyZWRhX2Jsb2tfcHJlc3Nfc20yLnBkZiIsInVpZCI6IjAiLCJub2lmcmFtZSI6ZmFsc2UsInRzIjoxNTI0NDg3NTUzMTcwfQ%3D%3D&amp;page=1">"Арена: Атлас религий и национальностей"</a> &#91;Arena: Atlas of Religions and Nationalities&#93; <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. Среда (Sreda). 2012.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=%D0%90%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BD%D0%B0%3A+%D0%90%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81+%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%B8+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9&amp;rft.pub=%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B4%D0%B0+%28Sreda%29&amp;rft.date=2012&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fdocviewer.yandex.com%2Fview%2F0%2F%3F%2A%3DrvAv5PGTc%252Fw%252BBFV6QOUZtaf5gYF7InVybCI6InlhLWRpc2stcHVibGljOi8vMWV1aDl5RDFpcnZKeVZNNSswWWFaZktqRFhoOXZDNWhldUlGTU5uQU4zQT0iLCJ0aXRsZSI6IlNyZWRhX2Jsb2tfcHJlc3Nfc20yLnBkZiIsInVpZCI6IjAiLCJub2lmcmFtZSI6ZmFsc2UsInRzIjoxNTI0NDg3NTUzMTcwfQ%253D%253D%26page%3D1&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> See also the results' <b><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sreda.org/arena">main interactive mapping</a></b> and the static mappings: <cite class="citation map"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170421154615/http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg">"Religions in Russia by federal subject"</a> (Map). <i>Ogonek</i>. <b>34</b> (5243). 27 August 2012. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://c2.kommersant.ru/ISSUES.PHOTO/OGONIOK/2012/034/ogcyhjk2.jpg">the original</a> on 21 April 2017.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Ogonek&amp;rft.atitle=Religions+in+Russia+by+federal+subject&amp;rft.volume=34&amp;rft.issue=5243&amp;rft.date=2012-08-27&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fc2.kommersant.ru%2FISSUES.PHOTO%2FOGONIOK%2F2012%2F034%2Fogcyhjk2.jpg&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/> The Sreda Arena Atlas was realised in cooperation with the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sreda.org/arena/maps?mainsection=census">All-Russia Population Census 2010 (Всероссийской переписи населения 2010)</a>, the <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sreda.org/arena/maps?mainsection=minust">Russian Ministry of Justice (Минюста РФ)</a>, the Public Opinion Foundation (Фонда Общественного Мнения) and presented among others by the Analytical Department of the Synodal Information Department of the Russian Orthodox Church. See: <cite class="citation web"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://russ.ru/Mirovaya-povestka/Proekt-ARENA-Atlas-religij-i-nacional-nostej">"Проект АРЕНА: Атлас религий и национальностей"</a> &#91;Project ARENA: Atlas of religions and nationalities&#93;. <i>Russian Journal</i>. 10 December 2012.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Russian+Journal&amp;rft.atitle=%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%82+%D0%90%D0%A0%D0%95%D0%9D%D0%90%3A+%D0%90%D1%82%D0%BB%D0%B0%D1%81+%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%B3%D0%B8%D0%B9+%D0%B8+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%86%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%B0%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%BD%D0%BE%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B5%D0%B9&amp;rft.date=2012-12-10&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fruss.ru%2FMirovaya-povestka%2FProekt-ARENA-Atlas-religij-i-nacional-nostej&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3ARussia" class="Z3988"></span><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r886058088"/></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Filina-358"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Filina_358-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Filina_358-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Filina_358-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Filina, Olga (30 August 2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180423161152/https://www.rbth.com/articles/2012/08/30/mapping_russias_religious_landscape_17819.html">"Mapping Russia's Religious Landscape"</a>. <i>Russia Beyond</i>. <li id="cite_note-film-414"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-film_414-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-film_414-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation encyclopaedia"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/513251/Russia">"Russia:Motion pictures"</a>. <i>Encyclopædia Britannica</i>. 2007<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-435"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-435">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Ruiz, Rebecca (18 July 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/19/sports/report-confirms-state-sponsored-doping-by-russia-at-olympics.html">"Russia May Face Olympics Ban as Doping Scheme Is Confirmed"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/International_Standard_Serial_Number" title="International Standard Serial Number">ISSN</a>&#160;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0362-4331">0362-4331</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li><a href="/wiki/Khanty-Mansi_Autonomous_Okrug" title="Khanty-Mansi Autonomous Okrug">Khanty-Mansi</a><sup>2</sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nenets_Autonomous_Okrug" title="Nenets Autonomous Okrug">Nenets</a><sup>3</sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Yamalo-Nenets_Autonomous_Okrug" title="Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug">Yamalo-Nenets</a><sup>2</sup></li></ul>
</div></td></tr><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div>
<ul><li><sup>1</sup>Claimed by <a href="/wiki/Ukraine" title="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and considered by most of the international community to be part of Ukraine</li>
<li><sup>2</sup>Administratively subordinated to <a href="/wiki/Tyumen_Oblast" title="Tyumen Oblast">Tyumen Oblast</a></li>
<li><sup>3</sup>Administratively subordinated to <a href="/wiki/Arkhangelsk_Oblast" title="Arkhangelsk Oblast">Arkhangelsk Oblast</a></li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><td class="navbox-abovebelow" colspan="2"><div id="Internal_additional_non-constitutional_divisions_by_different_institutions"><b>Internal additional non-constitutional divisions by different institutions</b></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Federal_districts_of_Russia" title="Federal districts of Russia">Federal districts</a> (by <a href="/wiki/President_of_Russia" title="President of Russia">President</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Economic_regions_of_Russia" title="Economic regions of Russia">Economic regions</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Economic_Development_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Economic Development (Russia)">Ministry of Economic Development</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Military_districts_of_Russia" title="Military districts of Russia">Military districts</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Russia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Russia)">Ministry of Defence</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Arbitration_Courts_of_Appeal_of_Russia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arbitration Courts of Appeal of Russia (page does not exist)">Judicial districts</a> (by law "On arbitration courts")</li></ul>
</div></td></tr></tbody></table><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table></div>

<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg/23px-Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg/35px-Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg/45px-Imperial_Standard_of_the_Emperor_of_Russia_%281858%E2%80%931917%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600" /></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_monarchs" title="List of Russian monarchs">862–1917</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic" title="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic"><img alt="Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Russian_Soviet_Federative_Socialist_Republic_%281918%E2%80%931937%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="600" data-file-height="300" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Russian_SFSR" title="List of leaders of the Russian SFSR">1917–1922</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union"><img alt="Soviet Union" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_Soviet_Union.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></a></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_leaders_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of leaders of the Soviet Union">1922–1991</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/15px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png" decoding="async" width="15" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/23px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg/30px-Standard_of_the_President_of_the_Russian_Federation.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1200" /></span> <a href="/wiki/List_of_presidents_of_Russia" title="List of presidents of Russia">1991–present</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="Premier of the Soviet Union">Soviet premiers</a> (<a href="/wiki/First_Deputy_Premier_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union">1st deputies</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_state_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of heads of state of the Soviet Union">Soviet heads of state</a> (<a href="/wiki/List_of_spouses_of_the_heads_of_state_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of spouses of the heads of state of the Soviet Union">and their spouses</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Government.ru_logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="Government.ru logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Government.ru_logo.svg/20px-Government.ru_logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="18" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Government.ru_logo.svg/30px-Government.ru_logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Government.ru_logo.svg/40px-Government.ru_logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="132" data-file-height="117" /></a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_heads_of_government_of_Russia" title="List of heads of government of Russia">Prime ministers</a> (<a href="/wiki/First_Deputy_Prime_Minister_of_Russia" title="First Deputy Prime Minister of Russia">1st deputies</a>)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Emblem of Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg/20px-Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="22" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg/30px-Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg/40px-Emblem_of_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="562" /></a> <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Foreign_Affairs_(Russia)" title="Minister of Foreign Affairs (Russia)">Foreign ministers</a></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/File:Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg" class="image"><img alt="Emblem of the Office of the Prosecutor General of Russia.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg/20px-Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="20" height="21" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg/30px-Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg/40px-Emblem_of_the_Office_of_the_Prosecutor_General_of_Russia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="524" data-file-height="558" /></a> <a href="/wiki/List_of_Prosecutor_Generals_of_Russia_and_the_Soviet_Union" title="List of Prosecutor Generals of Russia and the Soviet Union">Prosecutors general</a></span></li></ul>
</div></td><td class="navbox-image" rowspan="6" style="width:1px;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px"><div><a href="/wiki/File:Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg" class="image" title="Three generations of Russians in the late Russian Empire"><img alt="Three generations of Russians in the late Russian Empire" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg/180px-Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="157" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg/270px-Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg/360px-Prokudin-Gorskii-05.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3284" data-file-height="2858" /></a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Military figures<br />and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Russian_explorers" title="List of Russian explorers">explorers</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td><td class="navbox-image" rowspan="3" style="width:1px;padding:0px 0px 0px 2px"><div><a href="/wiki/File:APEC_Logo.svg" class="image"><img alt="APEC Logo.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/APEC_Logo.svg/80px-APEC_Logo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="80" height="47" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/APEC_Logo.svg/120px-APEC_Logo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/APEC_Logo.svg/160px-APEC_Logo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="300" data-file-height="178" /></a></div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Summits</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/BRICS_U-17_Football_Cup" title="BRICS U-17 Football Cup">BRICS U-17 Football Cup</a></th><td class="navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">

padding:0;">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation_(BSEC)" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation (BSEC)</a></div></th></tr><tr><td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd plainlist" style="width:100%;padding:0px;background:transparent;color:inherit;"><div style="padding:0px;"><table class="navbox-columns-table" style="border-spacing: 0px; text-align:left;width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;"><tbody><tr style="vertical-align:top;"><td style="width:6.5em;">&#160;&#160;&#160;</td><td class="navbox-list" style="padding:0px;;;;width:12.75em;"><div>
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/21px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png" decoding="async" width="21" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/32px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Flag_of_Albania.svg/42px-Flag_of_Albania.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="980" data-file-height="700" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a></li>
<li><span class="flagicon"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_Armenia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Armenia.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_Armenia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Armenia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Flag_of_Armenia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Armenia.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" />&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Armenia" title="Armenia">Armenia</a></li>

<div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="Security_Council_of_the_United_Nations" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible autocollapse navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2"><div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:UN_Security_Council" title="Template:UN Security Council"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:UN_Security_Council" title="Template talk:UN Security Council"><abbr title="Discuss this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:UN_Security_Council&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;-moz-box-shadow:none;-webkit-box-shadow:none;box-shadow:none; padding:0;">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Security_Council_of_the_United_Nations" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">Security Council</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Power</th><td class="navbox-list navbox-odd" style="text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid;width:100%;padding:0px"><div style="padding:0em 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Charter_of_the_United_Nations" title="Charter of the United Nations">Charter of the United Nations</a>
